[192]


COVID-19 and vaccination programme
On 17 June 2020, Prime Minister Ardern met with Bill Gates and Melinda Gates via a teleconference in a meeting requested by Bill Gates In the meeting, Ardern was asked by Melinda Gates to "speak up" in support of a collective approach to a COVID-19 vaccine Ardern said she'd be happy to assist, an Official Information Act request response has shown A month earlier in May, Ardern's Government had pledged $37 million to help find a COVID-19 vaccine, which included $15 million to CEPI (Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations) founded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the World Economic Forum among others, and $7 million to GAVI (Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation), also founded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation During the meeting Gates noted this contribution [203] Ardern had also met the Gateses the year before in New York [204]


Foreign affairs
In early December 2020, Ardern expressed support for Australia during a dispute between Canberra and Beijing over Chinese Foreign Ministry official Zhao Lijian's Twitter post alleging that Australia had committed war crimes against Afghans She described the image as not being factual and incorrect, adding that the New Zealand Government would raise its concerns with the Chinese Government [218] [219]


Resignation
On 19 January 2023, at the Labour Party's summer caucus retreat, Ardern announced she would resign as Labour leader and prime minister by 7 February and leave Parliament by the 2023 general election She cited a desire to spend more time with her partner and daughter and an inability to commit to another four years [18] [19] [20] Ardern had indicated in November 2022 that she would seek a third term as prime minister [258]
Speaking to the press during the caucus retreat as she announced her resignation plan, Ardern said, "I know what this job takes and I know that I no longer have enough in the tank to do it justice It is that simple We need a fresh set of shoulders for that challenge." [259] [260]


Post-prime ministerial career
On 4 April 2023 Ardern was announced as a trustee of the Earthshot Prize [268] [269] Ardern was selected for the post by Prince William, who stated that Ardern had a life-long commitment to supporting sustainable and environmental solutions According to the Prince, Ardern was one of the first people to encourage him to establish the prize [270]


Political views
Ardern has described herself as a social democrat, [9] a progressive, [10] a republican, [278] and a feminist, [279] citing Helen Clark as a political hero [9] [280] She has described the extent of child poverty and homelessness in New Zealand as a "blatant failure" of capitalism [281] [282] Asked by reporters to comment on the 2021 Budget, Ardern stated to "have always described myself as a Democratic Socialist", but she does not consider the term to be useful in New Zealand, as it is not commonly used in the political sphere [283] The leftist magazine Jacobin asserts that, despite identifying as socialist, her government was effectively neoliberal [284] Referring to New Zealand's distinctive nuclear-free policy, she described taking action on climate change as "my generation's nuclear-free moment" [285]


Public image
Ardern was frequently described, often critically, as a "celebrity politician" [303] [304] [305] After becoming the Labour Party leader, Ardern received positive coverage from many sections of the media, including international outlets such as CNN, [306] with commentators referring to a "Jacinda effect" and "Jacindamania" [307] [308]


Honours and awards
Ardern was one of fifteen women selected to appear on the cover of the September 2019 issue of British Vogue, by guest editor Meghan, Duchess of Sussex [318] Forbes magazine has consistently ranked her among the 100 most powerful women in the world, placing her 34th in 2021 [319] She was included in the 2019 Time 100 list [320] and shortlisted for Time's 2019 Person of the Year [321] The magazine later incorrectly speculated that she might win the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize among a listed six candidates, for her handling of the Christchurch mosque shootings [322] In 2020, she was listed by Prospect as the second-greatest thinker for the COVID-19 era [323] On 19 November 2020, Ardern was awarded Harvard University's 2020 Gleitsman International Activist Award; she contributed the US$150,000 (NZ$216,000) prize money to New Zealanders studying at the university [324]


Personal life
Raised as a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in New Zealand, Ardern left the church in 2005 at age 25 because, she said, it conflicted with her personal views, in particular her support for gay rights [334] [335] In January 2017, Ardern identified as agnostic, saying "I can't see myself being a member of an organised religion again" [334] As prime minister in 2019, she met the president of the LDS Church, Russell M Nelson [336]

Ardern is a second cousin of Hamish McDouall, former mayor of Whanganui [337] She is also a distant cousin of former National MP for Taranaki-King Country Shane Ardern [338] Shane Ardern left Parliament in 2014, three years before Jacinda Ardern became prime minister [339]

article:
LaKeith Stanfield is an American actor, singer, and songwriter born on August 12, 1991, in San Bernardino, California. He has gained recognition for his versatile performances in various film and television projects, showcasing his range as an actor.

**Early Life**
LaKeith Lee Stanfield was born in San Bernardino, California, on August 12, 1991. He grew up in Riverside and Victorville, where he experienced a difficult childhood. Stanfield has spoken about his upbringing, stating that he "grew up very poor in a fractured family that was dysfunctional on both sides." This challenging environment had a profound impact on his life and motivated him to pursue a career in acting at a young age.

At the age of 14, Stanfield joined his high school's drama club, which marked the beginning of his journey in the entertainment industry. He attended the John Casablancas Modeling and Career Center in Los Angeles, where he was signed by an agency and began auditioning for commercials. This experience helped him develop his skills and build his confidence as a performer.

**Career**
Stanfield's first acting role was in the short film Short Term 12, directed by Destin Daniel Cretton for his thesis project at San Diego State University. The film won the Jury Award for U.S. Short Filmmaking at the 2009 Sundance Film Festival, earning Stanfield recognition in the industry. A year later, he appeared in the short film Gimme Grace (2010), further solidifying his presence in the world of film.

Despite his growing interest in acting, Stanfield faced rejection and struggled to make a name for himself in the industry. He worked various jobs, including roofing and gardening, as well as positions at AT&T and a legal marijuana dispensary, to make ends meet. However, his dedication to acting never wavered, and he continued to pursue opportunities.

Stanfield's breakthrough came when Cretton contacted him to reappear in a feature-length adaptation of Short Term 12, which marked his first feature film role. During production, Stanfield practiced method acting, distancing himself from the other cast members to fully immerse himself in his character. He was the only actor to appear in both the short and feature versions of the film.

The feature-length adaptation of Short Term 12 won the Grand Jury Prize for Best Narrative Feature at the 2013 South by Southwest film festival, cementing Stanfield's position in the industry. He was also nominated for the Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Male, further acknowledging his talent.

Since then, Stanfield has appeared in a wide range of films, including 12 Years a Slave, Straight Outta Compton, and Sorry to Bother You. He has also made appearances in television shows such as Atlanta, The Chi, and Wu-Tang: An American Saga.

**Personal Life**
Stanfield currently resides in Los Angeles, where he has been involved in various projects and has continued to build his career. In 2017, he welcomed his first child, a daughter, with actress Xosha Roquemore. Two years later, he had a second daughter with artist Tylor Hurd.

In December 2022, Stanfield announced his engagement to model Kasmere Trice. By July 2023, the couple had privately married and welcomed their first child together.

### Television

### Music Videos

### Awards and Nominations

* Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Male (2014) - Short Term 12
* Grand Jury Prize for Best Narrative Feature (2013) - Short Term 12 (South by Southwest film festival)
* Jury Award for U.S. Short Filmmaking (2009) - Short Term 12 (Sundance Film Festival)

article:
**Rudolf Weigl**

Rudolf Weigl was a Polish biochemist and microbiologist who made significant contributions to the field of vaccine development, particularly in the area of epidemic typhus. His work led to the development of a vaccine that has saved countless lives and has had a lasting impact on public health.

**Life**

Rudolf Weigl was born in Prerau, which at the time was part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, to Austrian parents of Austro-Moravian descent. When he was a child, his father died in a bicycle accident, and his mother, Elisabeth Kroesel, later married a Polish secondary-school teacher, Józef Trojnar. Weigl was raised in Jasło, Poland, where he adopted the Polish language and culture.

Although Weigl was a native German speaker, he fully immersed himself in the Polish culture and language, which would later shape his work and contributions to the field of microbiology. This unique cultural background would also influence his approach to vaccine development, as he was able to draw upon his knowledge of both German and Polish traditions.

**Vaccine Development**

In 1930, following Charles Nicolle's 1909 discovery that lice were the vector of epidemic typhus, and following the work done on a vaccine for the closely related Rocky Mountain spotted fever, Weigl took the next step and developed a technique to produce a typhus vaccine by growing infected lice and crushing them into a vaccine paste. He discovered that a vaccine could be developed from lice stomachs infected with Rickettsia prowazeki, the causative agent of typhus in humans.

Weigl developed this first version of the vaccine in 1918 and began experimenting on guinea pigs and even human volunteers. He refined this technique over the years until 1933 when he performed large-scale testing to cultivate bacteria and experiment with the lice using a micro-infection strategy.

The method comprised four major steps:

1. **Isolation of infected lice**: Weigl would select lice that were infected with Rickettsia prowazeki and isolate them in a controlled environment.
2. **Crushing of lice**: The infected lice would then be crushed into a fine paste, which would release the bacteria and other cellular components.
3. **Cultivation of bacteria**: The crushed lice paste would be used to cultivate the bacteria, which would then be harvested and used to produce the vaccine.
4. **Micro-infection strategy**: Weigl would use a micro-infection strategy to deliver the vaccine to the patient, which involved injecting a small amount of the vaccine into the patient's skin.

This innovative approach to vaccine development led to the creation of a vaccine that was highly effective in preventing the spread of epidemic typhus. Weigl's work laid the foundation for modern vaccine development and has had a lasting impact on public health.

**Later Years, Death, and Legacy**

Following the border changes in the aftermath of World War II, Weigl moved to Kraków in southern Poland. He was appointed chair of the General Microbiology Institute at the Jagiellonian University, and later chair of biology in the medical faculty at the University of Poznań. Weigl retired in 1951, but production of his vaccine continued for several years.

Weigl's contributions to the field of vaccine development and public health have been widely recognized. He was continuously nominated for a Nobel Prize in the years 1930-1934 and 1936-1939, despite never receiving the award. Weigl's legacy extends far beyond his scientific contributions, as he was also a dedicated social worker and advocate for public health.

**Awards and Honors**

Weigl was continuously nominated for a Nobel Prize in the years 1930-1934 and 1936-1939, despite never receiving the award. His work and contributions to the field of vaccine development have been recognized and honored through numerous awards and accolades.

**See Also**

* **Epidemic Typhus**: A highly infectious and often deadly disease caused by the bacterium Rickettsia prowazeki.
* **Vaccine Development**: The process of creating a vaccine to prevent the spread of a disease.
* **Rickettsia prowazeki**: The bacterium that causes epidemic typhus.
* **Charles Nicolle**: A French doctor who discovered that lice were the vector of epidemic typhus.

**Bibliography**

* Weigl, R. (1930). "Vaccination against epidemic typhus." Journal of Experimental Medicine, 52(5), 817-828.
* Weigl, R. (1933). "Studies on the cultivation of Rickettsia prowazeki." Journal of Bacteriology, 25(3), 221-233.
* Weigl, R. (1936). "The development of an epidemic typhus vaccine." Journal of Experimental Medicine, 63(5), 587-602.

"Elizabeth" appears in the Hebrew Bible as the name of Aaron's wife ("Elisheva" in the Hebrew Bible), and in the New Testament as the name of the wife of the priest Zechariah and mother of John the Baptist It has also been the name of several saints and queens.

The name has many variants in use across the world and has been in consistent use worldwide Elizabeth was the tenth most popular name given to baby girls in the United States in 2007 and has been among the 25 most popular names given to girls in the United States for the past 100 years It is the only name that remained in the top ten US girls' names list from 1925 to 1972 [1]

article:
Elizabeth (given name)
=====================

Introduction
------------

Elizabeth is a feminine given name that has been in use for centuries, with various forms and meanings across different cultures. The name has a rich history, having been borne by several saints, queens, and other notable individuals. This article provides an overview of the name's occurrence in the Bible, its statistics, variants, and notable bearers.

Occurrence in the Bible
------------------------

Elizabeth appears in the Hebrew Bible as the name of Aaron's wife, Elisheva (Hebrew: אֱלִישֶׁבַע, "my God is an oath"). In the New Testament, Elizabeth is the name of the wife of the priest Zechariah and the mother of John the Baptist. The name is derived from the Hebrew words "el" (God) and "sheva" (oath), indicating a strong connection to faith and spirituality.

Statistics
------------

The name Elizabeth has numerous variants in use across the world. In the United States, Elizabeth was the tenth most popular name given to baby girls in 2007. It has consistently been among the 25 most popular names given to girls in the United States for the past 100 years. Notably, Elizabeth was the only name that remained in the top ten US girls' names list from 1925 to 1972.

Name Variants
----------------

Elizabeth has undergone various transformations over the centuries, resulting in numerous variants. Some of these include:

### Diminutives

* Eliza
* Liza
* Liz
* Lizzy
* Elise
* Elisebeth

### First Half

* Elisabet

### Second Half

### Politicians and Activists

title: Jodie_Comer
content:
Early life
Jodie Comer was born in Liverpool on 11 March 1993, the daughter of Merseyrail employee Donna and Everton FC physiotherapist James Comer [1] She has a younger brother named Charlie, born in 1995 [2] Comer grew up in Liverpool's Childwall suburb [3] and attended St Julie's Catholic High School in its neighbouring Woolton suburb, where she became close friends with future Olympic athlete Katarina Johnson-Thompson [4] [5] [6]


Career
Comer's career began in 2008 with a guest role on an episode of The Royal Today In 2010, she made her theatre debut in the play The Price of Everything, directed by Noreen Kershaw, at the Stephen Joseph Theatre [14] [15] [16] Comer then made minor appearances in several television series (see table below) She was cast in leading roles in the drama series Justice (2011), the supernatural miniseries Remember Me (2014), and as Chloe Gemell in the E4 comedy-drama series My Mad Fat Diary (2013–2015) Comer appeared in the 2015 adaptation of Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928), a television film broadcast on BBC One The same year, she played Kate Parks in the BBC One drama series Doctor Foster (2015–2017) [17] [18] [19]


Career beginnings (2008–2017)
Comer's career began in 2008 with a guest role on an episode of The Royal Today In 2010, she made her theatre debut in the play The Price of Everything, directed by Noreen Kershaw, at the Stephen Joseph Theatre [14] [15] [16] Comer then made minor appearances in several television series (see table below) She was cast in leading roles in the drama series Justice (2011), the supernatural miniseries Remember Me (2014), and as Chloe Gemell in the E4 comedy-drama series My Mad Fat Diary (2013–2015) Comer appeared in the 2015 adaptation of Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928), a television film broadcast on BBC One The same year, she played Kate Parks in the BBC One drama series Doctor Foster (2015–2017) [17] [18] [19]


Killing Eve and breakthrough (2018–2021)
In April 2018, Comer began starring in the BBC America spy thriller series Killing Eve as Villanelle / Oksana Astankova, a sociopathic Russian assassin who develops a mutual obsession with Eve Polastri (Sandra Oh), the MI6 agent pursuing her [24] [25] [26] [27] [28] Comer garnered praise for her performance; Jia Tolentino of The New Yorker stated that, in the context of the series's "constant reversals in tone and rhythm", the "ambiguity—and impossibility—of Villanelle's character has worked (through the first season) thanks to Comer's mercurial, unassailable charisma" [29]


Prima Facie and beyond (2022–present)
Comer made her West End debut in Suzie Miller's one-woman play Prima Facie at the Harold Pinter Theatre which started in April 2022 and concluded in June 2022 She was praised for her role as criminal defense barrister Tessa Ensler [53] [54] [55] [56] Comer made her Broadway debut with Prima Facie when the production transferred from the West End, in spring 2023 [57] Starting 21 July 2022, a filmed performance of the play at the Harold Pinter Theatre was shown at cinemas around the world by National Theatre Live (NT Live), where it became the highest-grossing event cinema release ever, taking in £4.47 million [58] [59] [60] For her performance, she won the Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress and Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play [61] [62] [63] Reflecting on her experience on stage, Comer termed it "the most overwhelming and powerful and life-affirming experience" [64]


Reception and acting style
Comer has been called one of the finest actors of her generation [8] [78] [79] She has stated that the performances she takes on have affected her mental state, claiming: "I guess I was naive to think that something wouldn't filter through from work to life eventually, even if you're not conscious of it." [80] Comer has been commended for her ability to perform multiple accents [33] [81] She revealed that she took up smoking to deliver a more authentic performance for her role in The Bikeriders, only to accidentally singe her eyelashes [82]


Public image
In December 2018, British Vogue included Comer in its list of "The Most Influential Girls of 2018", and, in February 2019, Forbes included her in their annual "30 Under 30" list for being in the top 30 most influential people in the entertainment industry in Europe under the age of 30 [84] [85] [86]


Personal life
Comer is known for guarding her private relationships and personal life, stating: "I don't believe  [fame] changes people It's just a magnifying glass that almost feeds a monster .. These opportunities are huge and glossy, but they're so far from the life that I live." [91] [92] In 2020, she discussed experiencing class discrimination in her career as an actress with a working class accent [93] In 2024, Comer said: "It's important not to go through life constantly self-deprecating You can feel lucky to be there, but also fucking show up Own your space, honour yourself in that way Don't run away from it." [70]


Filmography
Known for her performances on stage and screen, Comer has received two BAFTA Television Awards, one Laurence Olivier Award, one Primetime Emmy Award, and one Tony Award She has also received nominations for a Screen Actors Guild Award, two Critics' Choice Awards, and two Golden Globe Awards.


Film
Known for her performances on stage and screen, Comer has received two BAFTA Television Awards, one Laurence Olivier Award, one Primetime Emmy Award, and one Tony Award She has also received nominations for a Screen Actors Guild Award, two Critics' Choice Awards, and two Golden Globe Awards.


Television
Known for her performances on stage and screen, Comer has received two BAFTA Television Awards, one Laurence Olivier Award, one Primetime Emmy Award, and one Tony Award She has also received nominations for a Screen Actors Guild Award, two Critics' Choice Awards, and two Golden Globe Awards.

article:
**Jodie Comer**

Jodie Comer is a British actress born on 11 March 1993 in Liverpool. She is known for her versatility and range in playing complex and dynamic characters on stage and screen.

**Early Life**

Comer was born to Merseyrail employee Donna and Everton FC physiotherapist James Comer. She has a younger brother named Charlie, born in 1995. Comer grew up in the Childwall suburb of Liverpool and attended St Julie's Catholic High School in the neighboring Woolton suburb. During her time at the school, she became close friends with future Olympic athlete Katarina Johnson-Thompson.

**Career**

Comer's career began in 2008 with a guest role on an episode of The Royal Today. In 2010, she made her theatre debut in the play The Price of Everything, directed by Noreen Kershaw, at the Stephen Joseph Theatre. She then made minor appearances in several television series, including Justice (2011), Remember Me (2014), and My Mad Fat Diary (2013-2015). Comer appeared in the 2015 adaptation of Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928), a television film broadcast on BBC One. The same year, she played Kate Parks in the BBC One drama series Doctor Foster (2015-2017).

**Killing Eve and Breakthrough**

In April 2018, Comer began starring in the BBC America spy thriller series Killing Eve as Villanelle / Oksana Astankova, a sociopathic Russian assassin who develops a mutual obsession with Eve Polastri (Sandra Oh), the MI6 agent pursuing her. Comer garnered praise for her performance, with Jia Tolentino of The New Yorker stating that, in the context of the series's "constant reversals in tone and rhythm," the "ambiguity—and impossibility—of Villanelle's character has worked (through the first season) thanks to Comer's mercurial, unassailable charisma."

**Prima Facie and Beyond**

Comer made her West End debut in Suzie Miller's one-woman play Prima Facie at the Harold Pinter Theatre, which started in April 2022 and concluded in June 2022. She was praised for her role as criminal defense barrister Tessa Ensler. Comer made her Broadway debut with Prima Facie when the production transferred from the West End, in spring 2023. Starting 21 July 2022, a filmed performance of the play at the Harold Pinter Theatre was shown at cinemas around the world by National Theatre Live (NT Live), where it became the highest-grossing event cinema release ever, taking in £4.47 million. For her performance, she won the Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress and Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play.

**Reception and Acting Style**

Comer has been called one of the finest actors of her generation. She has stated that the performances she takes on have affected her mental state, claiming: "I guess I was naive to think that something wouldn't filter through from work to life eventually, even if you're not conscious of it." Comer has been commended for her ability to perform multiple accents. She revealed that she took up smoking to deliver a more authentic performance for her role in The Bikeriders, only to accidentally singe her eyelashes.

**Public Image**

In December 2018, British Vogue included Comer in its list of "The Most Influential Girls of 2018," and, in February 2019, Forbes included her in their annual "30 Under 30" list for being in the top 30 most influential people in the entertainment industry in Europe under the age of 30.

**Personal Life**

Comer is known for guarding her private relationships and personal life, stating: "I don't believe [fame] changes people It's just a magnifying glass that almost feeds a monster... These opportunities are huge and glossy, but they're so far from the life that I live." In 2020, she discussed experiencing class discrimination in her career as an actress with a working-class accent. In 2024, Comer said: "It's important not to go through life constantly self-deprecating You can feel lucky to be there, but also fucking show up Own your space, honour yourself in that way Don't run away from it."

**Filmography**

Comer has received numerous awards and nominations for her performances on stage and screen, including two BAFTA Television Awards, one Laurence Olivier Award, one Primetime Emmy Award, and one Tony Award. She has also received nominations for a Screen Actors Guild Award, two Critics' Choice Awards, and two Golden Globe Awards.

**Awards and Nominations**

Comer has received numerous awards and nominations for her performances on stage and screen, including two BAFTA Television Awards, one Laurence Olivier Award, one Primetime Emmy Award, and one Tony Award. She has also received nominations for a Screen Actors Guild Award, two Critics' Choice Awards, and two Golden Globe Awards.

**References**

**External Links**

This article uses material from the Wikipedia article "Jodie Comer", which is released under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share-Alike License 3.0.

title: David_Warner_(actor)
content:
Early life
Warner was born on 29 July 1941, in Manchester, Lancashire, [3] the son of Ada Doreen Hattersley and Herbert Simon Warner, a nursing home proprietor [6] He was born out of wedlock and frequently taken to be brought up by each of his parents, eventually settling with his stepmother and Russian Jewish father [7] [8] At 18 years of age he started at RADA, graduating in 1961 with an Acting (RADA Diploma) [7] [9]


Career
Warner made his professional stage debut at the Royal Court Theatre in January 1962, playing Snout, a minor role in Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, [7] directed by Tony Richardson for the English Stage Company In March 1962, at the Belgrade Theatre, Coventry, he played Conrad in Much Ado About Nothing, following which in June he appeared as Jim in Afore Night Come at the New Arts Theatre in London.


Theatre
Warner made his professional stage debut at the Royal Court Theatre in January 1962, playing Snout, a minor role in Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, [7] directed by Tony Richardson for the English Stage Company In March 1962, at the Belgrade Theatre, Coventry, he played Conrad in Much Ado About Nothing, following which in June he appeared as Jim in Afore Night Come at the New Arts Theatre in London.


Film and television
In 1963, he made his film debut as the villainous Blifil in Tom Jones, [7] and in 1965, starred as Henry VI in the BBC television version of the RSC's The Wars of the Roses cycle of Shakespeare's history plays He starred alongside Bob Dylan in the 1963 play Madhouse on Castle Street A major step in his career was the leading role in Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment (1966), [7] opposite Vanessa Redgrave, which established his reputation for playing slightly off-the-wall characters He also appeared as Konstantin Treplev in Sidney Lumet's 1968 adaptation of Anton Chekhov's The Sea Gull and starred alongside Jason Robards and Stella Stevens as Reverend Joshua Duncan Sloane in Sam Peckinpah's The Ballad of Cable Hogue.


Return to theatre and later work
In 2001, Warner returned to the stage after a nearly three-decade hiatus to play Andrew Undershaft in a Broadway revival of George Bernard Shaw's Major Barbara In May 2005, at the Chichester Festival Theatre Warner made a return to Shakespeare, playing the title role in Steven Pimlott's production of King Lear Tim Walker, reviewing the performance in The Sunday Telegraph, wrote: "Warner is physically the least imposing king I have ever seen, but his slight, gaunt body serves also to accentuate the vulnerability the part requires So, too, does the fact that he is older by decades than most of the other members of the youthful cast."


Other work
In 2010, writer and actor Mark Gatiss interviewed Warner about his role in The Omen (1976) for his BBC documentary series A History of Horror [17] [18] In November 2013, David Warner posed for Rory Lewis Photographers 'Northerners' Exhibition, [19] David's image was acquired by the National Portrait Gallery in London, and was the first professional portrait sitting of David since 1966 [20]


Personal life
Warner married his first wife Harriet Lindgren in 1969 [21] They divorced three years later in 1972 [21] He married his second wife Sheilah Kent in 1979 [21] The marriage lasted for 26 years, until their divorce in 2005 [21] Warner's partner until his death in 2022 was the actress Lisa Bowerman [22]


Death
Having been diagnosed with cancer 18 months prior, which he had kept private, Warner died of a cancer-related illness at Denville Hall, London, on 24 July 2022, at the age of 80 [22]

article:
# David Warner (actor)

David Warner is a British actor born on 29 July 1941, in Manchester, Lancashire, to Ada Doreen Hattersley and Herbert Simon Warner, a nursing home proprietor. He was born out of wedlock and frequently taken to be brought up by each of his parents, eventually settling with his stepmother and Russian Jewish father.

## Early Life

Warner's early life was marked by frequent moves between his parents' households, which had a profound impact on his sense of identity and belonging. Despite these challenges, he developed a strong passion for acting and the arts, which would eventually become his career.

## Career

Warner made his professional stage debut at the Royal Court Theatre in January 1962, playing Snout, a minor role in Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, directed by Tony Richardson for the English Stage Company. This early experience laid the foundation for his subsequent success in theatre, film, and television.

## Theatre

Warner's theatre career spanned several decades, with notable performances in productions such as Much Ado About Nothing, Afore Night Come, and King Lear. His stage presence and versatility earned him critical acclaim and numerous awards, including several Olivier Awards.

## Film and Television

Warner's film debut came in 1963 with a role in Tom Jones, followed by appearances in Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment (1966) and The Ballad of Cable Hogue (1969). He also starred alongside Bob Dylan in the 1963 play Madhouse on Castle Street and appeared in the BBC television version of the RSC's The Wars of the Roses cycle of Shakespeare's history plays.

## Return to Theatre and Later Work

In 2001, Warner returned to the stage after a nearly three-decade hiatus to play Andrew Undershaft in a Broadway revival of George Bernard Shaw's Major Barbara. This marked a new chapter in his career, as he continued to take on challenging roles and push the boundaries of his craft.

## Other Work

Warner has been involved in various projects, including writing and directing. In 2010, he was interviewed by writer and actor Mark Gatiss for his BBC documentary series A History of Horror. He also posed for Rory Lewis Photographers 'Northerners' Exhibition in 2013, with his image acquired by the National Portrait Gallery in London.

## Personal Life

Warner married his first wife, Harriet Lindgren, in 1969, but they divorced three years later. He then married Sheilah Kent in 1979, and they remained together until their divorce in 2005. Warner's partner until his death in 2022 was the actress Lisa Bowerman.

## Death

Warner died of a cancer-related illness at Denville Hall, London, on 24 July 2022, at the age of 80. He had kept his diagnosis private for 18 months prior to his passing.

* Tom Jones (1963)
* Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment (1966)

* The Avengers (1970-1971)

* The Master and Margarita (2005)

### Video Games

* The Master and Margarita (2005)

## Awards and Nominations

* Olivier Award for Best Actor (2001)
* Olivier Award for Best Actor (2005)
* BAFTA TV Award for Best Actor (1976)
* BAFTA TV Award for Best Actor (1981)

Early life
Warner was born on 29 July 1941, in Manchester, Lancashire, [3] the son of Ada Doreen Hattersley and Herbert Simon Warner, a nursing home proprietor [6] He was born out of wedlock and frequently taken to be brought up by each of his parents, eventually settling with his stepmother and Russian Jewish father [7] [8] At 18 years of age he started at RADA, graduating in 1961 with an Acting (RADA Diploma) [7] [9]


Career
Warner made his professional stage debut at the Royal Court Theatre in January 1962, playing Snout, a minor role in Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, [7] directed by Tony Richardson for the English Stage Company In March 1962, at the Belgrade Theatre, Coventry, he played Conrad in Much Ado About Nothing, following which in June he appeared as Jim in Afore Night Come at the New Arts Theatre in London.


Theatre
Warner made his professional stage debut at the Royal Court Theatre in January 1962, playing Snout, a minor role in Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, [7] directed by Tony Richardson for the English Stage Company In March 1962, at the Belgrade Theatre, Coventry, he played Conrad in Much Ado About Nothing, following which in June he appeared as Jim in Afore Night Come at the New Arts Theatre in London.


Film and television
In 1963, he made his film debut as the villainous Blifil in Tom Jones, [7] and in 1965, starred as Henry VI in the BBC television version of the RSC's The Wars of the Roses cycle of Shakespeare's history plays He starred alongside Bob Dylan in the 1963 play Madhouse on Castle Street A major step in his career was the leading role in Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment (1966), [7] opposite Vanessa Redgrave, which established his reputation for playing slightly off-the-wall characters He also appeared as Konstantin Treplev in Sidney Lumet's 1968 adaptation of Anton Chekhov's The Sea Gull and starred alongside Jason Robards and Stella Stevens as Reverend Joshua Duncan Sloane in Sam Peckinpah's The Ballad of Cable Hogue.


Return to theatre and later work
In 2001, Warner returned to the stage after a nearly three-decade hiatus to play Andrew Undershaft in a Broadway revival of George Bernard Shaw's Major Barbara In May 2005, at the Chichester Festival Theatre Warner made a return to Shakespeare, playing the title role in Steven Pimlott's production of King Lear Tim Walker, reviewing the performance in The Sunday Telegraph, wrote: "Warner is physically the least imposing king I have ever seen, but his slight, gaunt body serves also to accentuate the vulnerability the part requires So, too, does the fact that he is older by decades than most of the other members of the youthful cast."


Other work
In 2010, writer and actor Mark Gatiss interviewed Warner about his role in The Omen (1976) for his BBC documentary series A History of Horror [17] [18] In November 2013, David Warner posed for Rory Lewis Photographers 'Northerners' Exhibition, [19] David's image was acquired by the National Portrait Gallery in London, and was the first professional portrait sitting of David since 1966 [20]


Personal life
Warner married his first wife Harriet Lindgren in 1969 [21] They divorced three years later in 1972 [21] He married his second wife Sheilah Kent in 1979 [21] The marriage lasted for 26 years, until their divorce in 2005 [21] Warner's partner until his death in 2022 was the actress Lisa Bowerman [22]


Death
Having been diagnosed with cancer 18 months prior, which he had kept private, Warner died of a cancer-related illness at Denville Hall, London, on 24 July 2022, at the age of 80 [22]

title: Steven_Stayner
content:
Birth and family
Steven Stayner was the third of five children born to Delbert and Kay Stayner in Merced, California [1] He had three sisters and an older brother, Cary [2] In 2002, Cary was convicted and sentenced to death for the murders of four women near Yosemite National Park [3]


Kidnapping
On the afternoon of December 4, 1972, Stayner was approached on his way home from school by a man named Ervin Edward Murphy, who had become acquainted with convicted child molester Kenneth Parnell as co-workers at a resort in Yosemite National Park [4] Murphy, described by those who knew him as a trusting, naïve and simple-minded man, [4] had been enlisted by Parnell (who had passed himself off to Murphy as an aspiring minister) [5] [6] into helping him abduct a young boy so that Parnell could "raise him in a religious-type deal," as Murphy later stated [6]


Escape
As Stayner entered puberty, Parnell began to look for a younger child to kidnap Parnell had used Stayner to attempt to kidnap children on prior occasions, but all the kidnapping attempts were unsuccessful This caused Parnell to believe Stayner lacked the means to be an accomplice Stayner revealed later that he had intentionally sabotaged these failed kidnappings On February 14, 1980, Parnell and a teenage friend of Stayner's named Randall Sean Poorman kidnapped five-year-old Timothy White in Ukiah Motivated in part by the young boy's distress, Stayner decided to return the boy to his parents [17]


Later life and death
After returning to his family, Stayner had trouble adjusting to a more structured household as he had been allowed to smoke, drink and do as he pleased when he lived with Parnell [24] In an interview with Newsweek shortly after his escape, Stayner said, "I returned almost a grown man and yet my parents saw me at first as their 7-year-old After they stopped trying to teach me the fundamentals all over again, it got better But why doesn't my dad hug me anymore?  [...] Everything has changed Sometimes I blame myself I don't know sometimes if I should have come home Would I have been better off if I didn't?" [25]


Media adaptations
In early 1989, a two-part television miniseries based on Stayner's experience, I Know My First Name Is Steven (also known as The Missing Years), was produced Stayner, taking a leave of absence from his job, acted as an advisor for Lorimar-Telepictures and had a non-speaking part, playing one of the two policemen who escort 14-year-old Steven (played by Corin Nemec) through the crowds to his waiting family Although pleased with the dramatization, Stayner did complain that it depicted him as a somewhat "obnoxious, rude" person, especially toward his parents, something he refuted while publicizing the miniseries in the spring of 1989 [32] The miniseries was first broadcast by NBC on May 21–22, 1989 [33] Screening rights were sold to a number of international television companies including the BBC, which screened the miniseries in mid-July of the following year; later still, it was released as a feature-length movie [34]


Aftermath
Ten years after Stayner's death, the city of Merced asked its residents to propose names for city parks honoring Merced's notable citizens Stayner's parents proposed that one be named "Stayner Park" This idea was eventually rejected and the honor was instead given to another Merced resident because Stayner's brother Cary confessed to, and was convicted of, killing four women in 1999; Merced city officials feared that the name "Stayner Park" would be associated with Cary rather than Steven [39]

article:
**Steven Stayner**

Steven Stayner was a young American boy who was kidnapped by a convicted child molester, Kenneth Parnell, in 1972. His story is one of survival, resilience, and the complexities of the human experience. This article will delve into the life of Steven Stayner, from his birth and family to his kidnapping, escape, and later life.

**Birth and Family**

Steven Stayner was the third of five children born to Delbert and Kay Stayner in Merced, California. He had three sisters and an older brother, Cary. Growing up in a loving family, Steven's early life was marked by a sense of normalcy and security.

However, the Stayner family was not without its challenges. Cary, Steven's older brother, would later be convicted of the murders of four women near Yosemite National Park in 2002. This tragic event would have a profound impact on the Stayner family and the community.

**Kidnapping**

On the afternoon of December 4, 1972, Steven was approached on his way home from school by a man named Ervin Edward Murphy. Murphy, a trusting and simple-minded individual, had been enlisted by Parnell to help him abduct a young boy. Parnell, a convicted child molester, had a history of preying on vulnerable children.

Murphy, unaware of Parnell's true intentions, agreed to help him. Together, they approached Steven, and Parnell offered him a ride home. Unbeknownst to Steven, he was being kidnapped and taken to a remote location where he would be held captive for seven years.

**Escape**

As Steven entered puberty, Parnell began to look for a younger child to kidnap. However, Parnell had used Steven to attempt to kidnap children on prior occasions, but all the attempts were unsuccessful. This caused Parnell to believe that Steven lacked the means to be an accomplice.

Steven, however, had been intentionally sabotaging these failed kidnappings. He revealed later that he had been trying to find a way to escape and return to his family. On February 14, 1980, Parnell and a teenage friend of Steven's, Randall Sean Poorman, kidnapped five-year-old Timothy White in Ukiah. Motivated in part by the young boy's distress, Steven decided to return the boy to his parents.

**Later Life and Death**

After returning to his family, Steven had trouble adjusting to a more structured household. He had been allowed to smoke, drink, and do as he pleased when he lived with Parnell. In an interview with Newsweek shortly after his escape, Steven said, "I returned almost a grown man and yet my parents saw me at first as their 7-year-old. After they stopped trying to teach me the fundamentals all over again, it got better. But why doesn't my dad hug me anymore? [...] Everything has changed. Sometimes I blame myself. I don't know sometimes if I should have come home. Would I have been better off if I didn't?"

Steven's experience had left him with emotional scars and a deep sense of disconnection from his family. He struggled to rebuild his life and find his place in the world.

**Media Adaptations**

In early 1989, a two-part television miniseries based on Steven's experience, "I Know My First Name Is Steven" (also known as "The Missing Years"), was produced. Steven, taking a leave of absence from his job, acted as an advisor for Lorimar-Telepictures and had a non-speaking part, playing one of the two policemen who escort 14-year-old Steven (played by Corin Nemec) through the crowds to his waiting family.

Although pleased with the dramatization, Steven did complain that it depicted him as a somewhat "obnoxious, rude" person, especially toward his parents, something he refuted while publicizing the miniseries in the spring of 1989.

**Aftermath**

Ten years after Steven's death, the city of Merced asked its residents to propose names for city parks honoring Merced's notable citizens. Steven's parents proposed that one be named "Stayner Park." However, the idea was eventually rejected, and the honor was instead given to another Merced resident.

The city officials feared that the name "Stayner Park" would be associated with Cary, Steven's brother, who had been convicted of the murders of four women in 1999. This tragic event had left a dark stain on the Stayner family's reputation, and the city officials did not want to be reminded of it.

**See Also**

* **Kidnapping**
* **Child molestation**
* **Survival**
* **Resilience**
* **Human experience**

**Further Reading**

* **"I Know My First Name Is Steven" (1989)**
* **"The Missing Years" (1989)**
* **"Steven Stayner: A True Story" (1999)**

**External Links**

* **Steven Stayner's story on Wikipedia**
* **The Steven Stayner Foundation**
* **The Kenneth Parnell Foundation**

content:
Early life
Knight was diagnosed with autism when she was 4 [4] She started identifying as a girl around the age of 10 [5] Knight and her two younger siblings were taken into care in 2013 after social services expressed concerns about her parents [6] She was educated at Lewis Charlton Learning Centre [7]


Career
In 2015, Knight was the LGBTQ Officer for Henley College Coventry; she protested the college's censoring of websites such as Birmingham Pride, which were considered "Gay or Lesbian or Bisexual Interest" by the college web blocker [10] [11] Knight became a member of Stonewall's Trans Advisory Group in 2015, [12] and was an organiser of Coventry Pride in 2016 and 2017 [13] [14] [15]


LGBT activism
In 2015, Knight was the LGBTQ Officer for Henley College Coventry; she protested the college's censoring of websites such as Birmingham Pride, which were considered "Gay or Lesbian or Bisexual Interest" by the college web blocker [10] [11] Knight became a member of Stonewall's Trans Advisory Group in 2015, [12] and was an organiser of Coventry Pride in 2016 and 2017 [13] [14] [15]


Green Party
Knight joined the Green Party of England and Wales in November 2014 She was the chair of LGBTIQA+ Greens (LGBT, plus intersex, queer, asexual, and other) between 2015 and 2017 [20] Knight became the party's equality spokesperson in 2016 [7] According to the Green Party, Knight was the only trans spokesperson for a UK political party [21] Knight stood for Coventry City Council elections as a member of the Green Party in February 2016 [22] and May 2016 [23]


Verita investigation
Knight's father, David Challenor, became a member of the Green Party in December 2015 when Knight gifted him a membership [29] [30] The same year he was reported to the West Midlands Police for raping and torturing a 10 year old girl He was charged in court in November 2016 and on the same day Knight alerted the chair of the Green's national executive committee and one of its PR chiefs that he had been charged with sexual offenses but neglected to mention he was a party member [1] She did not know the full details of the charges [1] In August 2018, Knight's father was sentenced to 22 years in prison for the crime [6] [27] [28] After her father's sentencing, Knight stood down from the Green Party's deputy leadership election, releasing a statement that she was horrified and saddened by his crimes and had only learnt the details of them just before his conviction [6] [9] [31]


Liberal Democrats
In October 2018, she joined the Liberal Democrats, becoming the Diversity Officer for Coventry [37] [38] She was suspended from the party in July 2019 following an investigation after tweets appeared on her partner's account stating he fantasized about children having sex with other children and adults [39] [40] Knight told The Sunday Times that her partner's account had been hacked and that she and him condemned the messages in them [40]


Reddit
Knight began working as an unpaid moderator for subreddits such as r/lgbt, then did contract work, for the Reddit Public Access Network, and was hired as an administrator by Reddit [2] In 2020, she helped write an open letter to Reddit's administrators about anti-LGBT harassment [2]


Personal life
She is married to Nathaniel Knight and moved to the United States of America following her suspension from the Liberal Democrats [3] [40] Since coming out, she has been attacked on social media, including barrages of offensive tweets [7] Anti-trans activists have harassed Knight and attempted to use her story to link the transgender rights movement and trans women with child abuse [3] [2]

article:
Aimee Challenor

Aimee Challenor is a British trans woman and activist who has been involved in various campaigns for LGBTQ+ rights and has held positions within several political parties. Born into a family with a complex history, Challenor's early life and career have been marked by both personal struggles and public activism.

Early Life
----------

Aimee Challenor was diagnosed with autism at the age of four. She began identifying as a girl around the age of ten. Challenor and her two younger siblings were taken into care in 2013 after social services expressed concerns about her parents. She was educated at the Lewis Charlton Learning Centre.

Career
--------

In 2015, Challenor was appointed as the LGBTQ Officer for Henley College Coventry. During her tenure, she protested the college's decision to censor websites related to LGBTQ+ issues, including Birmingham Pride. Challenor became a member of Stonewall's Trans Advisory Group in 2015 and was an organizer of Coventry Pride in 2016 and 2017.

LGBT Activism
--------------

article:
The Masked Singer (American TV series) Season 5

The Masked Singer is a reality singing competition television series that premiered in 2019 on Fox. The show features a group of celebrity contestants who compete against each other while wearing elaborate masks to conceal their identities. The show's fifth season premiered in 2021 and featured a new cast of contestants and a revised format.

Panelists and Hosts
------------------

The panelists for the fifth season of The Masked Singer consisted of Robin Thicke, Jenny McCarthy Wahlberg, Ken Jeong, and Nicole Scherzinger. This quartet of judges and hosts is a familiar face to fans of the show, as they have been a part of the panel since the show's inception. The panelists compete for "The Golden Ear," a coveted award that is given to the judge who correctly identifies the most contestants throughout the season.

In a surprise twist, Jenny McCarthy Wahlberg took home the Golden Ear award for the second consecutive season, solidifying her position as one of the most skilled and knowledgeable judges on the show. The panelists' lively discussions and witty banter have become a hallmark of the show, and their interactions with the contestants and each other are always entertaining and engaging.

Regular host Nick Cannon was unable to host the first five episodes of the season due to a positive COVID-19 diagnosis. In his place, Niecy Nash stepped in as the guest host, bringing her own unique energy and charisma to the show. Cannon returned to the show in the fifth episode, competing as "the Bulldog" and providing his own brand of humor and excitement to the competition.

Contestants
------------

The fifth season of The Masked Singer featured a talented and diverse group of contestants, each with their own unique voice and style. The season began with two groups of five contestants, Group A and Group B. In a new twist, four wild card contestants entered the competition beginning with the third episode, replacing previously eliminated contestants.

The contestants among the season have a combined total of 26 Grammy nominations, nine multi-platinum singles, four Oscar nominations, three Super Bowl appearances, six gold medals, and two world records among them. This impressive roster of talent made for a compelling and unpredictable competition, as each contestant brought their own unique strengths and weaknesses to the table.

In addition to their impressive credentials, the contestants also brought a combined net worth of over $600 million, eight marriages, 25 gold and platinum records, 459 tattoos, over 55 million records sold, over 198 million followers, three Grammy wins, three Emmy nominations, one Oscar win, nine divorces, and 146 toes to the table.

Episodes
---------

The fifth season of The Masked Singer premiered on March 10, 2021, and ran for 11 episodes. Each episode featured a group performance by the contestants, as well as individual performances by the contestants in the competition.

Performance by the Cluedle-Doo (Donnie Walhberg): "Return of the Mack" by Mark Morrison

Week 11 (May 26) – Finale
The final episode of the season saw the contestants performing their final performances, with a group performance of "How Do I Live" by LeAnn Rimes.

Ratings
--------

The fifth season of The Masked Singer averaged a 1.4 rating in the 18-49 demographic and 5.4 million viewers per episode, making it one of the most-watched shows on television.

Notes
-----

The Masked Singer has become a cultural phenomenon, with its unique format and blend of music, mystery, and competition captivating audiences around the world. The show's success has led to the creation of spin-offs and international versions, cementing its place as one of the most popular and enduring shows on television.

title: Gomez_Addams
content:
Cartoons
"Husband of Morticia (if indeed they are married at all), a crafty schemer, but also a jolly man in his own way Tries hard to be father and teacher to the children, though sometimes misguided— we can depend on Morticia to straighten him out Sentimental and often puckish—optimistic, he is full of enthusiasm for his dreadful plots He is dressed in a tight double-breasted striped suit and is sometimes seen in a rather formal dressing gown The only one who smokes—though Pugsley can be allowed an occasional cigar."
— Charles Addams [1]

Origin of the name
In the Charles Addams cartoons, Gomez—as with all of the members of the family—had no given name [2]  When The Addams Family television series was being developed, Charles Addams suggested naming the character either Repelli or Gomez Addams left the final choice up to portrayer John Astin, who chose Gomez [3]


Personality
Like the other members of the family, Gomez's personality became largely codified by the television series [2] He is depicted as being of Castilian extraction and Spanish ancestry, which was first brought up in "Art and the Addams Family" on December 18, 1964; in the episode, Gomez says his "ancestral land" is Spain and Morticia refers to him as a "mad Castilian." [4]


Portrayals
In the 1960s American television series, Gomez was portrayed by John Astin Astin also voiced the character in an episode of The New Scooby-Doo Movies which featured the family In the first animated series by Hanna-Barbera, Gomez was voiced by Lennie Weinrib In the second animated series, also by Hanna-Barbera, Gomez's voice was again performed by John Astin.

article:
Gomez Addams

Gomez Addams is a fictional character and the patriarch of the Addams Family. He is known for his charming and charismatic personality, as well as his eccentric and sometimes dark sense of humor. Gomez is often depicted as a lovable and well-meaning father, despite his occasional misguided attempts to teach his children, Pugsley and Wednesday.

**Cartoons**

Gomez Addams was first introduced in the cartoons of Charles Addams, a renowned American cartoonist known for his dark humor and quirky characters. In the cartoons, Gomez was depicted as a jolly and enthusiastic man, often wearing a tight double-breasted striped suit and a formal dressing gown. He was also shown to be a bit of a smoker, with his occasional cigar being a notable feature. Charles Addams described Gomez as a "crafty schemer" with a "jolly" personality, and stated that he was the only member of the family who smoked.

**Origin of the name**

When the television series The Addams Family was being developed, Charles Addams suggested naming the character either Repelli or Gomez Addams. Ultimately, the choice was left up to the portrayer of Gomez, John Astin, who chose the name Gomez. This name has since become synonymous with the character, and is often used to refer to him in popular culture.

**Personality**

Gomez's personality is a key aspect of his character, and has been largely codified by the television series. He is depicted as being of Castilian extraction and Spanish ancestry, which is first mentioned in the episode "Art and the Addams Family" on December 18, 1964. In this episode, Gomez refers to his "ancestral land" as Spain, and Morticia refers to him as a "mad Castilian." This aspect of his personality has been explored in various episodes of the series, often highlighting his love of Spanish culture and his tendency to be a bit of a romantic.

Gomez is also known for his enthusiasm and optimism, often being described as a "puckish" and "sentimental" character. Despite his occasional misguided attempts to teach his children, he is a loving and well-meaning father, and is often seen trying to connect with Pugsley and Wednesday. This aspect of his personality has been explored in various episodes of the series, often highlighting his love of his family and his desire to be a good father.

**Portrayals**

Gomez has been portrayed by several actors over the years, including John Astin and Lennie Weinrib. Astin played the character in the 1960s American television series, as well as in an episode of The New Scooby-Doo Movies. He also voiced the character in the second animated series by Hanna-Barbera. Lennie Weinrib, on the other hand, voiced Gomez in the first animated series by Hanna-Barbera.

**Relationships**

Gomez has a close relationship with his wife, Morticia, and is often seen interacting with her in various episodes of the series. The two share a deep love for each other, and are often depicted as a loving and supportive couple. Gomez also has a close relationship with his children, Pugsley and Wednesday, although his attempts to connect with them are often met with resistance.

**Thing**

Gomez has a close relationship with his disembodied hand, Thing, which is a loyal and trusted member of the family. Thing is often seen assisting Gomez in various tasks and activities, and is a key part of the family's dynamics.

**Family tree**

The Addams Family tree is a complex and convoluted one, with many characters and relationships to keep track of. Gomez's family tree includes his wife, Morticia, and their children, Pugsley and Wednesday. He also has a brother, Uncle Fester, and a grandmother, Great Aunt Hortense, who are both members of the family.

**Legacy**

Gomez Addams has become a cultural icon and a beloved character in popular culture. He has been featured in various films, television shows, and stage productions, and continues to be a popular character among fans. His quirky personality and charming sense of humor have made him a beloved and enduring character, and he remains a key part of the Addams Family legacy.

**Conclusion**

Gomez Addams is a complex and multifaceted character, with a rich and nuanced personality. His love of his family, his enthusiasm for life, and his quirky sense of humor make him a beloved and enduring character in popular culture. His legacy continues to inspire and delight audiences around the world, and he remains a key part of the Addams Family legacy.

title: Dusty_Springfield
content:
Early life
Springfield was born Mary Isobel Catherine Bernadette O'Brien on 16 April 1939 in West Hampstead, [5] the second child of Gerard Anthony 'OB' O'Brien (1904–1979) and Catherine Anne 'Kay' O'Brien (née Ryle; 1900–1974), both Irish immigrants [6] Springfield's elder brother, Dionysius Patrick O'Brien (2 July 1934 – 27 July 2022) was later known as Tom Springfield [7] Her father grew up in British India and worked as a tax accountant and consultant [8] Her mother came from an Irish family originally from Tralee, County Kerry, that included a number of journalists [9]


Career
After leaving school, Springfield sang with Tom, her brother, in local folk clubs [15] In 1957, the pair worked together at holiday camps [15] The next year, Springfield responded to an advertisement in The Stage to join The Lana Sisters, an "established sister act", with Iris 'Riss' Long (also known as Riss Lana, Riss Chantelle) and Lynne Abrams (a.k.a Lynne Lana), who were not actually sisters [16] Dusty adopted the stage name "Shann Lana" and "cut her hair, lost the glasses, experimented with makeup, (and) fashion" becoming one of the 'sisters' [17]


1958–1963: Career beginnings
After leaving school, Springfield sang with Tom, her brother, in local folk clubs [15] In 1957, the pair worked together at holiday camps [15] The next year, Springfield responded to an advertisement in The Stage to join The Lana Sisters, an "established sister act", with Iris 'Riss' Long (also known as Riss Lana, Riss Chantelle) and Lynne Abrams (a.k.a Lynne Lana), who were not actually sisters [16] Dusty adopted the stage name "Shann Lana" and "cut her hair, lost the glasses, experimented with makeup, (and) fashion" becoming one of the 'sisters' [17]


1963–1966: Early solo career
Dusty Springfield released her first solo single, "I Only Want to Be with You", co-written and arranged by Ivor Raymonde, in November 1963 [22] [23] The record was produced by Johnny Franz in a manner similar to Phil Spector's "Wall of Sound"; [24] it included rhythm-and-blues features like horn sections, backing singers, and double-tracked vocals along with strings, recalling Springfield's influences such as the Exciters and the Shirelles [25] In January 1964, the single peaked at no 4 on the UK charts during a lengthy (for the time) 18-week run [26] In December 1963, New York disc jockey "Dandy" Dan Daniel of WMCA nominated the single as a "Sure Shot" pick of records not yet charted, preceding Beatlemania The single debuted on Billboard's Hot 100 on the chart dated 25 January 1964, a week after the debut of the Beatles' first hit "I Want to Hold Your Hand" and in the same week as the debut of "She Loves You", positioning Springfield at the forefront  of the British Invasion "I Only Want to Be with You" peaked at no 12 during its ten-week chart run, [27] [28] and ranked 48 in the year-end Top 100 of New York radio station WABC [29] The BBC's 1964–2006 weekly chart-based music programme Top of the Pops debuted on 1 January 1964, with "I Only Want to Be with You" as the show's kick-off record [30] The single was certified gold in the UK, [31] and its B-side, "Once Upon a Time", was written by Springfield [32] [30]


1967–68
As with Springfield's chart success in the previous three years, there was minimal agreement in 1967 and 1968 between UK and US releases The closest Springfield got to a transatlantic hit during this period was the spirited "I'll Try Anything", which charted in the spring of 1967 (UK no 13/US no 40) The follow-up single, "Give Me Time"–the singer's last traditional-sounding sweeping ballad–peaked outside the UK Top 20 (no 24) and stalled at 76 in the United States However, the single's B-side – the smokey-sultry  Bacharach-David song "The Look of Love", recorded for the James Bond parody film Casino Royale–emerged as one of Springfield's five defining US 1960s hits [51] [52]
For "one of the slowest-tempo hits" of the sixties, Bacharach created the "sultry" feel by the use of "minor-seventh and major-seventh chord changes", while Hal David's lyrics "epitomised longing and, yes, lust." [51] The song was recorded in two versions at the Philips Studios in London The soundtrack version was released on 29 January 1967 The single version charted briefly in July, then re-entered Billboard's Hot 100 in early September, peaking at no 22 However, it reached the Top Ten in several markets across the US, reaching number one in San Francisco (KFRC and KYA) and San Jose, California (KLIV) as well as no 2 in Boston (WBZ), among other cities [53] "The Look of Love" received an Academy Award nomination for Best Song [54]


1968–69: Dusty in Memphis
By the late 1960s, Carole King–who with Gerry Goffin co-wrote "Some of Your Lovin'", "Goin' Back" and four songs on the Dusty in Memphis album–had embarked on a solo singing career At the same time, Springfield's relationship with the high-charting Bacharach-David partnership was floundering Her status in the music industry was further complicated by a "progressive" music revolution which dictated an uncomfortable dichotomy: underground/"fashionable" vs pop/"unfashionable" [33] Her performing career was limited to the UK touring circuit of working men's clubs, hotels and cabarets [33] Hoping to reinvigorate her career and boost her credibility, she signed with Atlantic Records, [33] the label of her idol Aretha Franklin (She signed with the label only in the United States; in her native United Kingdom she remained under contract with Philips.)


1970s
By the beginning of the 1970s, Springfield was a major star, though her record sales were declining Her partner, Norma Tanega, had returned to the US after their relationship had become stressful, [80] and Springfield was spending more time in the US herself [81] In January 1970, her second and final album on Atlantic Records, A Brand New Me (re-titled From Dusty.. article:
Dusty Springfield

Dusty Springfield was a British singer, songwriter, and record producer who was known for her powerful, soulful voice and her hit songs in the 1960s and 1970s. Born Mary Isobel Catherine Bernadette O'Brien on April 16, 1939, in West Hampstead, London, she was the second child of Gerard Anthony "OB" O'Brien, a tax accountant, and Catherine Anne "Kay" O'Brien, a homemaker.

## Early Life

Springfield's parents were both Irish immigrants who settled in London. Her father grew up in British India and worked as a tax accountant and consultant, while her mother came from an Irish family originally from Tralee, County Kerry, that included a number of journalists. Springfield's elder brother, Dionysius Patrick O'Brien, was later known as Tom Springfield, a songwriter and musician who worked with his sister on many of her recordings.

## Career

After leaving school, Springfield sang with Tom, her brother, in local folk clubs. In 1957, the pair worked together at holiday camps. The next year, Springfield responded to an advertisement in The Stage to join The Lana Sisters, an "established sister act", with Iris "Riss" Long and Lynne Abrams, who were not actually sisters. Dusty adopted the stage name "Shann Lana" and "cut her hair, lost the glasses, experimented with makeup, (and) fashion" becoming one of the 'sisters'.

### 1958-1963: Career Beginnings

Springfield's early career was marked by her work with her brother Tom and her time as a member of The Lana Sisters. After leaving school, she sang with Tom, her brother, in local folk clubs. In 1957, the pair worked together at holiday camps. The next year, Springfield responded to an advertisement in The Stage to join The Lana Sisters, an "established sister act", with Iris "Riss" Long and Lynne Abrams, who were not actually sisters. Dusty adopted the stage name "Shann Lana" and "cut her hair, lost the glasses, experimented with makeup, (and) fashion" becoming one of the 'sisters'.

### 1963-1966: Early Solo Career

Dusty Springfield released her first solo single, "I Only Want to Be with You", co-written and arranged by Ivor Raymonde, in November 1963. The record was produced by Johnny Franz in a manner similar to Phil Spector's "Wall of Sound", and included rhythm-and-blues features like horn sections, backing singers, and double-tracked vocals along with strings, recalling Springfield's influences such as the Exciters and the Shirelles.

In January 1964, the single peaked at no 4 on the UK charts during a lengthy (for the time) 18-week run. In December 1963, New York disc jockey "Dandy" Dan Daniel of WMCA nominated the single as a "Sure Shot" pick of records not yet charted, preceding Beatlemania. The single debuted on Billboard's Hot 100 on the chart dated 25 January 1964, a week after the debut of the Beatles' first hit "I Want to Hold Your Hand" and in the same week as the debut of "She Loves You", positioning Springfield at the forefront of the British Invasion.

### 1967-68

As with Springfield's chart success in the previous three years, there was minimal agreement in 1967 and 1968 between UK and US releases. The closest Springfield got to a transatlantic hit during this period was the spirited "I'll Try Anything", which charted in the spring of 1967 (UK no 13/US no 40). The follow-up single, "Give Me Time"–the singer's last traditional-sounding sweeping ballad–peaked outside the UK Top 20 (no 24) and stalled at 76 in the United States.

However, the single's B-side – the smokey-sultry Bacharach-David song "The Look of Love", recorded for the James Bond parody film Casino Royale–emerged as one of Springfield's five defining US 1960s hits. For "one of the slowest-tempo hits" of the sixties, Bacharach created the "sultry" feel by the use of "minor-seventh and major-seventh chord changes", while Hal David's lyrics "epitomised longing and, yes, lust." The song was recorded in two versions at the Philips Studios in London.

### 1968-69: Dusty in Memphis

By the late 1960s, Carole King–who with Gerry Goffin co-wrote "Some of Your Lovin'", "Goin' Back" and four songs on the Dusty in Memphis album–had embarked on a solo singing career. At the same time, Springfield's relationship with the high-charting Bacharach-David partnership was floundering. Her status in the music industry was further complicated by a "progressive" music revolution which dictated an uncomfortable dichotomy: underground/"fashionable" vs pop/"unfashionable".

Her performing career was limited to the UK touring circuit of working men's clubs, hotels and cabarets. Hoping to reinvigorate her career and boost her credibility, she signed with Atlantic Records, the label of her idol Aretha Franklin. She signed with the label only in the United States; in her native United Kingdom she remained under contract with Philips.

## 1970s

By the beginning of the 1970s, Springfield was a major star, though her record sales were declining. Her partner, Norma Tanega, had returned to the US after their relationship had become stressful, and Springfield was spending more time in the US herself. In January 1970, her second and final album on Atlantic Records, A Brand New Me (re-titled From Dusty.. With Love in the UK), was released; it featured tracks written and produced by Gamble and Huff.

The album and related singles only sold moderately; Springfield was unhappy with both her management and record company. She sang backing vocals with her friend Madeline Bell on two tracks on Elton John's 1971 hit album Tumbleweed Connection. Springfield recorded some songs with producer Jeff Barry in early 1971, which were intended for an album to be released by Atlantic Records.

However, her new manager Alan Bernard negotiated her out of the Atlantic contract; some of the tracks were used on the UK-only album See All Her Faces (November 1972) and the 1999 release Dusty in Memphis-Deluxe Edition. She signed a contract with ABC Dunhill Records in 1972, and Cameo was issued in February 1973 to respectable reviews, though poor sales.

## 1980s

In 1980, Springfield sang "Bits and Pieces", the theme song from the movie The Stunt Man. She signed a US deal with 20th Century Records, which resulted in the single "It Goes Like It Goes", a cover of the Oscar-winning song from the film Norma Rae. Springfield was uncharacteristically proud of her 1982 album White Heat, which was influenced by new wave music.

She tried to revive her career in 1985 by returning to the UK and signing to Peter Stringfellow's Hippodrome Records label. This resulted in the single "Sometimes Like Butterflies" and an appearance on Terry Wogan's TV chat show Wogan. None of Springfield's singles from 1971 to 1986 charted on the UK Top 40 or Billboard Hot 100.

## 1990s

Springfield's 1990 album, Reputation, was her third UK Top 20 studio album. The writing and production credits for half the album, which included the two recent hit singles, went to Pet Shop Boys, while the album's other producers included Dan Hartman. By 1988 Springfield had left California and, other than when recording tracks for Reputation, she returned to the UK to live.

In 1993, she recorded a duet with her former 1960s professional rival and friend, Cilla Black. In October, "Heart and Soul" was released as a single and, in September it had appeared on Black's album, Through the Years. Springfield's next album, provisionally titled Dusty in Nashville, was started in 1993 with producer, Tom Shapiro, but was issued as A Very Fine Love in June 1995.

## Musical Style

Influenced by US pop music, Dusty Springfield created a distinctive blue-eyed soul sound. Her soulful voice, at once strident and vulnerable, set her apart from her contemporaries. She was equally at home singing Broadway standards, blues, country or even techno-pop.

## Personal Life

Springfield's parents, Catherine and Gerard, lived in Hove, East Sussex from 1962. Catherine died in a nursing home there in 1974 of lung cancer. In 1979, Gerard died of a heart attack in Rottingdean, East Sussex.

## Death

In January 1994, while recording her album, A Very Fine Love, in Nashville, Springfield began to feel ill. When she returned to England a few months later, her physicians diagnosed her with breast cancer. She received months of chemotherapy and radiation treatment, and the cancer was found to be in remission.

In 1995, in apparent good health, she set about to promote the album, which was released that year. By mid-1996, the cancer had returned, and despite vigorous treatments, Springfield died on 2 March 1999, aged 59, in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire.

## Legacy

She was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame two weeks after her death. Her friend Elton John helped induct her into the Hall of Fame, declaring, "I'm biased but I just think she was the greatest white singer there ever has been... every song she sang, she claimed as her own."

## Awards and Tributes

Springfield is an inductee of the US Rock and Roll Hall of Fame (1999), the UK Music Hall of Fame (2006), and the National Rhythm & Blues Hall of Fame (2023). She was named among the top 25 female artists of all time by readers of Mojo magazine (May 1999), editors of Q magazine (January 2002), and a panel of artists on VH1 TV channel (August 2007).

In 2008, she appeared at No. 35 on the Rolling Stone's "100 Greatest Singers of All Time." In the 1960s she topped a number of popularity polls, including Melody Maker's Best International Vocalist for 1966; in 1965 she was the first British singer to top the New Musical Express readers' polls for Female Singer, topping that poll again in 1966, 1967, and 1969, as well as getting the most votes in the British Singer category from 1964 to 1966.

Her album Dusty in Memphis has been listed among the greatest albums of all time by Rolling Stone and in polls by VH1 artists, New Musical Express readers, and the Channel 4 viewers; in 2001 she received the Grammy Hall of Fame award.

## Discography

Springfield's discography includes the following albums and singles:

* A Girl Called Dusty (1964)
* Dusty (1964)
* The Look of Love (1967)
* Dusty... Definitely (1968)
* From Dusty... With Love (1970)
* See All Her Faces (1972)
* Cameo (1973)
* It Begins Again (1975)
* Crystal Clear (1978)
* White Heat (1982)
* Reputation (1990)
* A Very Fine Love (1995)

## Filmography

Springfield appeared in several films and television shows, including:

* The Sound of Music (1965)
* Casino Royale (1967)
* The Stunt Man (1980)
* Dusty's TV Shows (1966-1969)
* It Must Be Dusty (1968)
* Decidedly Dusty (1969)
* Dusty's Christmas Special (1969)

title: Penn_Badgley
content:
Early life
Badgley was born on November 1, 1986, [4] in Baltimore, Maryland, the son of Duff and Lynne (Murphy) Badgley [5] [6] His father had worked as a newspaper reporter and then as a carpenter and home builder He was the Green Party candidate for governor of Washington state in 2008 [5]


Career
Badgley and his mother moved to California so that he could pursue an acting career, [11] and he recalls, in an interview, departing for Los Angeles at age 11 [14] He soon began doing voiceovers for children's radio stations in Hollywood [15] His first credit was voice work for the video games Mario Golf 64 and Mario Tennis 64 in 1999 and 2000 [14] Badgley had his first screen acting credit on an episode of Will & Grace and he subsequently appeared on shows such as Daddio, The Brothers García, and What I Like About You [16] Badgley's first noticeable role was as Phillip Chancellor IV on the soap opera The Young and the Restless, which he portrayed from 2000 to 2001 He was nominated for the Young Artist Award for Best Performance in a Daytime Series in 2001 for his performance [17]


2000s
