article:
Penn Badgley is an American actor, singer, and activist born on November 1, 1986, in Baltimore, Maryland. He is best known for his roles in television series such as "Gossip Girl" and "You," as well as his music career as the lead singer of the indie pop band MOTHXR.

**Early Life**

Badgley was born to Duff and Lynne (Murphy) Badgley. His father had a career in journalism, working as a newspaper reporter and later as a carpenter and home builder. Badgley's early life was marked by a move to California with his mother, who supported his decision to pursue an acting career. He has recalled in interviews that he left for Los Angeles at the age of 11 to pursue his dreams.

## Voice Work and Early Acting Credits

Badgley began his acting career with voice work for children's radio stations in Hollywood. His first credit was voice work for the video games "Mario Golf 64" and "Mario Tennis 64" in 1999 and 2000. He soon landed his first screen acting credit on an episode of the popular sitcom "Will & Grace" and went on to appear in shows such as "Daddio," "The Brothers García," and "What I Like About You." Badgley's first noticeable role was as Phillip Chancellor IV on the soap opera "The Young and the Restless," which he portrayed from 2000 to 2001.

## 2000s

Badgley continued to work in television and film throughout the 2000s, appearing in shows such as "The Brothers García" and "Easy A," a teen comedy film released in 2010. The film was a critical and commercial success, earning Badgley a Teen Choice Award nomination.

## 2010s

In 2011, Badgley appeared in the financial thriller drama "Margin Call," which earned him the Robert Altman Award at the Independent Spirit Awards. He also launched his music career as the lead singer of the indie pop band MOTHXR, releasing their debut album "Centerfold" in 2016.

## 2020s

In 2020, Badgley starred in the independent film "Here Today," opposite Billy Crystal and Tiffany Haddish. He also began working on his podcast "Podcrushed," which explores the awkwardness, anxiety, and self-discovery of adolescence. The podcast features guests such as Drew Barrymore, Conan O'Brien, and Ariana Grande.

## Other Activities

In addition to his acting and music career, Badgley has been involved in various charitable initiatives. He has supported Barack Obama in the 2008 presidential election and appeared in an Obama commercial as part of MoveOn's Youth Vote program.

## Music

Badgley's music career with MOTHXR has been marked by the release of several singles and a debut album "Centerfold" in 2016. The band has gained a following in the indie pop scene and has been praised for its catchy and introspective sound.

## Activism and Politics

Badgley has been an outspoken advocate for social justice and has spoken out on issues such as LGBTQ+ rights and climate change. He has also been involved in various charitable initiatives, including supporting organizations such as the ACLU and the Sierra Club.

## Personal Life

Badgley has been in several high-profile relationships, including with his "Gossip Girl" co-star Blake Lively and actress Zoë Kravitz. He married Domino Kirke in 2017 and became the stepfather of her son. In 2020, Badgley and Kirke announced that they were expecting their first child together. Their son James was born in August 2020.

**Awards and Nominations**

* Podcrushed podcast award for "Best New Podcast" (2022)

**Notes**

* Badgley has been praised for his performances in television and film, including his roles in "Gossip Girl" and "You."
* He has also been recognized for his music career with MOTHXR, including the release of their debut album "Centerfold" in 2016.

content:
Early life
Sifan Hassan was born in Adama, Oromia, Ethiopia and raised in the countryside of Kersa in the Munesa district of the Arsi Zone of Oromia [21] [22] She was a recreational runner there She left her home country as a refugee and arrived in the Netherlands in 2008 at age 15 [23] [24] She began running while undertaking studies to become a nurse [25] She is an Arsi Oromo [26]


Career
Affiliated with Eindhoven Atletiek, [28] Hassan entered the Eindhoven half marathon in 2011 and won the race with a time of 77:10 minutes She was also runner-up at two cross country races (Sylvestercross and Mol Lotto Cross Cup) She won those races in 2012, as well as the 3000 m at the Leiden Gouden Spike meet [29]


2011–2012
Affiliated with Eindhoven Atletiek, [28] Hassan entered the Eindhoven half marathon in 2011 and won the race with a time of 77:10 minutes She was also runner-up at two cross country races (Sylvestercross and Mol Lotto Cross Cup) She won those races in 2012, as well as the 3000 m at the Leiden Gouden Spike meet [29]


2013–2014
Hassan made her breakthrough in the 2013 season She ran an 800 metres best of 2:00.86 minutes to win at the KBC Night of Athletics and took wins in the 1500 m at the Nijmegen Global Athletics and Golden Spike Ostrava meets On the 2013 IAAF Diamond League circuit she was runner-up in the 1500 m at Athletissima with a personal best of 4:03.73 minutes and was third at the DN Galan 3000 m with a best of 8:32.53 minutes—this time ranked her the fourth-fastest runner in the world that year [29] [30]


2015
At the 2015 World Championships in Beijing, Hassan won the bronze medal in the 1500 metres She became the second female Dutch athlete ever to win a medal at the World Championships, after Dafne Schippers She was the third female Dutch winner at the 2015 European Cross Country Championships, following in the footsteps of fellow African migrants Hilda Kibet and Lornah Kiplagat [35]


2016–2017
Hassan won her heat in the 1500 m in the 2016 Rio Olympics in 4:06.64 before Faith Kipyegon In the semifinals she placed second in 4:03.62 after Genzebe Dibaba who won in 4:03.06 In the final Kipyegon took the Olympic gold medal with 4:08.92, Dibaba was the runner up with 4:10.27 and Jennifer Simpson took the bronze medal in 4:10.53 Hassan placed fifth in a time of 4:11.23 [36]


2018
On 13 July, she broke the European record for 5000 metres by finishing second at the Rabat Diamond League in 14:22.34 [37] A few days later, Hassan won the first Millicent Fawcett Mile at the 2018 London Anniversary Games in a time of 4:14.71, the fourth-fastest result at the time [38]


2019
On 17 February, Hassan set the world record for a 5 km road race stopping the clock at 14:44 in Monaco It has since been broken, first by Beatrice Chepkoech, then by Ejgayehu Taye [40] [41] The 5 km road race has been a world record event since 1 November 2017 [42] At the Prefontaine Classic in June, she broke the European 3000 m record with a time of 8:18.49 [43]


Mile world record
On 12 July, Hassan entered the mile run at the Herculis meet in Fontvieille, Monaco Olha Lyakhova was the pace setter, taking the field through the first two laps (measured at the start line, not the quarter-mile splits) in 64.26 and 63.94 (2:08.20) As is typical for Hassan, she was last off the start line, but over the next 150 metres, slowly eased herself around the field on the outside into the marking position behind Lyakhova Gabriela DeBues-Stafford soon moved through the field in between Hassan and Lyakhova for the next lap before Hassan and Gudaf Tsegay separated from the field as the only chasers Between 800 and 1000 metres, Lyakhova strained to keep on pace, but Hassan and Tsegay were moving forward After Lyakhova stepped out, the two found themselves 15 metres ahead of the pack At 1200 metres, Hassan was looking back at her close chaser Tsegay in 3:10.13 (a 61.93 lap) Hassan accelerated, opening a 5-metre gap over the next 100 metres Continuing at this pace, she passed 1500 metres in about 3:55 Hassan covered the last 409.344 metres in 62.20, her final time of 4:12:33 breaking Svetlana Masterkova's almost 23-year-old world record [44] The athletes trailing Hassan rewrote the all-time top 25 list, with Laura Weightman moving into position #15, DeBues-Stafford into #17, and after #5 all-time Tsegay faded into the pack she was followed by Rababe Arafi, Axumawit Embaye, Winnie Nanyondo and Ciara Mageean moving into positions #20–23.


2020–2021
On 10 October, Hassan set a European record for the women's 10,000 metres in a time of 29:36.67, breaking the best set by Great Britain's Paula Radcliffe in 2002 by more than 24 seconds [48]


2022
This season was considered a resting year for Hassan as she ended a break from training 5 weeks before competing at the World Championships in Eugene, Oregon where she finished sixth in the 5000 metres and fourth in the 10,000 metres [8]


2023
On 23 April, on her debut over the classic marathon distance, the 30-year-old won the London Marathon with a time of 2:18:33 She lost contact with the leaders after stopping to stretch her leg twice about 19 km into the race, and was 28 seconds behind at the 25 km mark Despite this, Hassan caught up with the slowing lead quartet with four kilometres to go and prevailed in a sprint finish on the final straight, four seconds ahead of Alemu Megertu "It was really amazing I never thought I would finish a marathon", said Hassan [52] [53]


2024 Olympic Games
At the Paris 2024 Olympics, Hassan secured the bronze medal in the women's 5,000 metres Initially upgraded to silver following Faith Kipyegon's disqualification for obstruction, Hassan was later returned to bronze after Kipyegon was reinstated following Kenya's successful appeal [56]


Coach
Sifan Hassan achieved her first career breakthroughs while under the direction of Dutch national coach Honore Hoedt Hassan decided to search for other coaching options at the end of 2016 after injuries hampered her buildup to the Rio Olympics.

article:
Sifan Hassan

Sifan Hassan is a Dutch long-distance runner of Ethiopian origin. She was born in Adama, Oromia, Ethiopia and raised in the countryside of Kersa in the Munesa district of the Arsi Zone of Oromia.

**Early Life**

Sifan Hassan was born in Adama, Oromia, Ethiopia and raised in the countryside of Kersa in the Munesa district of the Arsi Zone of Oromia. She was a recreational runner there. She left her home country as a refugee and arrived in the Netherlands in 2008 at age 15. She began running while undertaking studies to become a nurse. She is an Arsi Oromo.

**Career**

Affiliated with Eindhoven Atletiek, Hassan entered the Eindhoven half marathon in 2011 and won the race with a time of 77:10 minutes. She was also runner-up at two cross country races (Sylvestercross and Mol Lotto Cross Cup). She won those races in 2012, as well as the 3000 m at the Leiden Gouden Spike meet.

### 2011–2012

Affiliated with Eindhoven Atletiek, Hassan entered the Eindhoven half marathon in 2011 and won the race with a time of 77:10 minutes. She was also runner-up at two cross country races (Sylvestercross and Mol Lotto Cross Cup). She won those races in 2012, as well as the 3000 m at the Leiden Gouden Spike meet.

### 2013–2014

Hassan made her breakthrough in the 2013 season. She ran an 800 metres best of 2:00.86 minutes to win at the KBC Night of Athletics and took wins in the 1500 m at the Nijmegen Global Athletics and Golden Spike Ostrava meets. On the 2013 IAAF Diamond League circuit she was runner-up in the 1500 m at Athletissima with a personal best of 4:03.73 minutes and was third at the DN Galan 3000 m with a best of 8:32.53 minutes—this time ranked her the fourth-fastest runner in the world that year.

### 2015

At the 2015 World Championships in Beijing, Hassan won the bronze medal in the 1500 metres. She became the second female Dutch athlete ever to win a medal at the World Championships, after Dafne Schippers. She was the third female Dutch winner at the 2015 European Cross Country Championships, following in the footsteps of fellow African migrants Hilda Kibet and Lornah Kiplagat.

### 2016–2017

Hassan won her heat in the 1500 m in the 2016 Rio Olympics in 4:06.64 before Faith Kipyegon. In the semifinals she placed second in 4:03.62 after Genzebe Dibaba who won in 4:03.06. In the final Kipyegon took the Olympic gold medal with 4:08.92, Dibaba was the runner up with 4:10.27 and Jennifer Simpson took the bronze medal in 4:10.53. Hassan placed fifth in a time of 4:11.23.

### 2018

On 13 July, she broke the European record for 5000 metres by finishing second at the Rabat Diamond League in 14:22.34. A few days later, Hassan won the first Millicent Fawcett Mile at the 2018 London Anniversary Games in a time of 4:14.71, the fourth-fastest result at the time.

### 2019

On 17 February, Hassan set the world record for a 5 km road race stopping the clock at 14:44 in Monaco. It has since been broken, first by Beatrice Chepkoech, then by Ejgayehu Taye. The 5 km road race has been a world record event since 1 November 2017. At the Prefontaine Classic in June, she broke the European 3000 m record with a time of 8:18.49.

### Mile World Record

On 12 July, Hassan entered the mile run at the Herculis meet in Fontvieille, Monaco. Olha Lyakhova was the pace setter, taking the field through the first two laps (measured at the start line, not the quarter-mile splits) in 64.26 and 63.94 (2:08.20). As is typical for Hassan, she was last off the start line, but over the next 150 metres, slowly eased herself around the field on the outside into the marking position behind Lyakhova. Gabriela DeBues-Stafford soon moved through the field in between Hassan and Lyakhova for the next lap before Hassan and Gudaf Tsegay separated from the field as the only chasers. Between 800 and 1000 metres, Lyakhova strained to keep on pace, but Hassan and Tsegay were moving forward. After Lyakhova stepped out, the two found themselves 15 metres ahead of the pack. At 1200 metres, Hassan was looking back at her close chaser Tsegay in 3:10.13 (a 61.93 lap). Hassan accelerated, opening a 5-metre gap over the next 100 metres. Continuing at this pace, she passed 1500 metres in about 3:55. Hassan covered the last 409.344 metres in 62.20, her final time of 4:12.33 breaking Svetlana Masterkova's almost 23-year-old world record. The athletes trailing Hassan rewrote the all-time top 25 list, with Laura Weightman moving into position #15, DeBues-Stafford into #17, and after #5 all-time Tsegay faded into the pack she was followed by Rababe Arafi, Axumawit Embaye, Winnie Nanyondo and Ciara Mageean moving into positions #20–23.

### 2020–2021

On 10 October, Hassan set a European record for the women's 10,000 metres in a time of 29:36.67, breaking the best set by Great Britain's Paula Radcliffe in 2002 by more than 24 seconds.

### 2022

This season was considered a resting year for Hassan as she ended a break from training 5 weeks before competing at the World Championships in Eugene, Oregon where she finished sixth in the 5000 metres and fourth in the 10,000 metres.

### 2023

On 23 April, on her debut over the classic marathon distance, the 30-year-old won the London Marathon with a time of 2:18:33. She lost contact with the leaders after stopping to stretch her leg twice about 19 km into the race, and was 28 seconds behind at the 25 km mark. Despite this, Hassan caught up with the slowing lead quartet with four kilometres to go and prevailed in a sprint finish on the final straight, four seconds ahead of Alemu Megertu. "It was really amazing I never thought I would finish a marathon", said Hassan.

### 2024 Olympic Games

At the Paris 2024 Olympics, Hassan secured the bronze medal in the women's 5,000 metres. Initially upgraded to silver following Faith Kipyegon's disqualification for obstruction, Hassan was later returned to bronze after Kipyegon was reinstated following Kenya's successful appeal.

### Coach

Sifan Hassan achieved her first career breakthroughs while under the direction of Dutch national coach Honore Hoedt. Hassan decided to search for other coaching options at the end of 2016 after injuries hampered her buildup to the Rio Olympics.

### Personal Bests

Information from World Athletics profile unless otherwise noted.

### Competition Results

Information from World Athletics profile unless otherwise noted.

On 17 February, Hassan set the world record for a 5 km road race stopping the clock at 14:44 in Monaco It has since been broken, first by Beatrice Chepkoech, then by Ejgayehu Taye [40] [41] The 5 km road race has been a world record event since 1 November 2017 [42] At the Prefontaine Classic in June, she broke the European 3000 m record with a time of 8:18.49 [43]


Mile world record
On 12 July, Hassan entered the mile run at the Herculis meet in Fontvieille, Monaco Olha Lyakhova was the pace setter, taking the field through the first two laps (measured at the start line, not the quarter-mile splits) in 64.26 and 63.94 (2:08.20) As is typical for Hassan, she was last off the start line, but over the next 150 metres, slowly eased herself around the field on the outside into the marking position behind Lyakhova Gabriela DeBues-Stafford soon moved through the field in between Hassan and Lyakhova for the next lap before Hassan and Gudaf Tsegay separated from the field as the only chasers Between 800 and 1000 metres, Lyakhova strained to keep on pace, but Hassan and Tsegay were moving forward After Lyakhova stepped out, the two found themselves 15 metres ahead of the pack At 1200 metres, Hassan was looking back at her close chaser Tsegay in 3:10.13 (a 61.93 lap) Hassan accelerated, opening a 5-metre gap over the next 100 metres Continuing at this pace, she passed 1500 metres in about 3:55 Hassan covered the last 409.344 metres in 62.20, her final time of 4:12:33 breaking Svetlana Masterkova's almost 23-year-old world record [44] The athletes trailing Hassan rewrote the all-time top 25 list, with Laura Weightman moving into position #15, DeBues-Stafford into #17, and after #5 all-time Tsegay faded into the pack she was followed by Rababe Arafi, Axumawit Embaye, Winnie Nanyondo and Ciara Mageean moving into positions #20–23.


2020–2021
On 10 October, Hassan set a European record for the women's 10,000 metres in a time of 29:36.67, breaking the best set by Great Britain's Paula Radcliffe in 2002 by more than 24 seconds [48]


2022
This season was considered a resting year for Hassan as she ended a break from training 5 weeks before competing at the World Championships in Eugene, Oregon where she finished sixth in the 5000 metres and fourth in the 10,000 metres [8]


2023
On 23 April, on her debut over the classic marathon distance, the 30-year-old won the London Marathon with a time of 2:18:33 She lost contact with the leaders after stopping to stretch her leg twice about 19 km into the race, and was 28 seconds behind at the 25 km mark Despite this, Hassan caught up with the slowing lead quartet with four kilometres to go and prevailed in a sprint finish on the final straight, four seconds ahead of Alemu Megertu "It was really amazing I never thought I would finish a marathon", said Hassan [52] [53]


2024 Olympic Games
At the Paris 2024 Olympics, Hassan secured the bronze medal in the women's 5,000 metres Initially upgraded to silver following Faith Kipyegon's disqualification for obstruction, Hassan was later returned to bronze after Kipyegon was reinstated following Kenya's successful appeal [56]


Coach
Sifan Hassan achieved her first career breakthroughs while under the direction of Dutch national coach Honore Hoedt Hassan decided to search for other coaching options at the end of 2016 after injuries hampered her buildup to the Rio Olympics.


Personal bests
Information from World Athletics profile unless otherwise noted [8]


Competition results
Information from World Athletics profile unless otherwise noted [8]


International competitions


Circuit wins and titles


National titles


Awards and honours


References


External links

title: Eternal_Sunshine_(album)
content:
Background
On May 12, 2022, 19 months after the release of her sixth studio album, Positions (2020), Ariana Grande clarified that she would not be recording another album until she is done filming Wicked (2024), the film adaptation of the Broadway musical of the same name, in which she portrays the character Glinda [3] In October 2023, she first jokingly hinted at a forthcoming album by posting "ag7: goat mother" as an Instagram caption [4] A set of pictures included a photo of her with Swedish producer and long-time collaborator Max Martin at Jungle City Studios in New York City [5]


Conception
Grande described Eternal Sunshine as "kind of a concept album" comprising "different heightened pieces of the same story, of the same experience" [14] She explained that the record spans from "really vulnerable" songs to playful tracks which see her emulating "what people kind of expect me to be sometimes and having fun with it" [14] Wendy Goldstein, co-president of Republic Records, described the record as an "elevated version" of Grande's previous albums, calling it an embodiment of "Sweetener meets  [...] Thank U, Next" [15] [16]


Recording and production
In a video shared to her social media of her previewing some songs of the album to Republic Records personnel, Grande revealed that after the 2023 SAG-AFTRA strike forced the filming of Wicked to be paused temporarily, she "came  [to the studio]" and begun work on the record that September [1] She further revealed that she worked with Max Martin for a few weeks, and handled production on her own as well [1] "Proper" vocal recordings and orchestrations were arranged in November [2] Work on the album concluded in late December 2023 [8] Referring to the period of making Eternal Sunshine, Grande stated that "things  [were] kind of just pouring out and happening very quickly" [14]


Music and lyrics
Eternal Sunshine is a pop and R&B album [17] that features elements of dance music, especially synth-pop and house music [18] [19] Helen Brown of The Independent described it as a "slow-fizz pop" album, consisting of mid-tempo synths, strings and muted guitar [20] Jem Aswad of Variety felt that Martin and Salmanzadeh imbued the album with a "very Swedish vibe and structure to the tracks" inspired by classic pop, a style atypical of Anglo-American musicians [21] Lyrically, the album is a combination of both "ultra-confident and entirely self-deprecating" themes, inspired by Grande's personal relationships [22] Billboard described it as an introspective record—one in which Grande reflects on herself as she enters her thirties [19]


Songs
Eternal Sunshine begins with the opening track, "Intro (End of the World)", which primarily includes strings and a morose guitar [19] The song begins with Grande posing the question, "How can I tell if I'm in the right relationship?", describing her anxieties with her partner, and the possibility of its end [23]  The second song, "Bye", was described by Grande as the hardest song on the album for her to write, saying "It was hard for the reason that I desperately didn't want it to sound like a 'fuck you.' I wanted it to sound like, 'I need to leave, so bye'" [24] Grande wanted the song to have a sense of self-awareness and accountability, rather than being completely dismissive [25] It is an uptempo dance-pop number with influences of disco and Philadelphia soul [26] [27] The third track, "Don't Wanna Break Up Again", is a gloomy, '90s influenced pop and R&B song that discusses conflicting feelings Grande has towards the end of her relationship with her partner [28] While referring to her relationship as a "situationship" that she's aware needs to end, the song shows a reluctancy to go through with ending the marriage and describes the steps she went through to try to save it, i.e therapy [20] Rolling Stone described the first three tracks of the album as "seventies pop" [29]


Release and promotion
Republic Records released Eternal Sunshine on March 8, 2024 [42] It was issued via streaming, download, five CD variants, and six vinyl LP variants [43] Pre-orders began on January 17, the day the album was announced [44] On March 10, a digital extended edition of the album, titled Slightly Deluxe, was surprise-released via Grande's webstore; it features four bonus tracks including a remix of "Supernatural" with Troye Sivan, and the pre-released Mariah Carey remix of "Yes, And?" [45] [46] The Slightly Deluxe edition was released to streaming services the day after [47] On October 1, 2024, Grande surprise-released another digital extended edition of the album, labelled Slightly Deluxe and Also Live It comprises the standard thirteen tracks, the Slightly Deluxe remixes, the pre-released Brandy and Monica remix of "The Boy Is Mine", and live versions of seven songs [48]


Marketing
The tracklist of the album was not unveiled entirely at once Grande revealed song titles and their track order on separate days, starting on January 27, 2024, with tracks 1, 5, and "Yes, And?" as track 9 [50] Tracks 2, 6, and 10 were revealed on February 7, [51] followed by tracks 3, 7, and 11 on February 17, [52] and tracks 4, 8, 12, and 13 on February 27 [53] Additionally, Grande revealed some lyrics from the album via her social media on February 27 [54] A teaser for the album, featuring the singer at a photo shoot for one of the cover artworks, was released on March 6, 2024 [55]


Title and artwork
The title of the album is a reference to the film Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004) [67] It stars Jim Carrey, who Grande has expressed she's a fan of and whose show, Kidding, she had guest-starred on [68] The title Eternal Sunshine was teased via two Easter eggs The first was in the opening scene of the music video of the lead single, "Yes, And?" It depicts a red card that has the acronym "AG7" on the frontside, with the geographical coordinates 41.0359° N, 71.9545° W mentioned below it—which locate Montauk, New York, a key location of the film [69] The second was when Grande shared a few lines of Alexander Pope's poem Eloisa to Abelard on her Instagram, including: "Eternal sunshine of the spotless mind!" [70]


Singles
"Yes, And?", the lead single of Eternal Sunshine, was released on January 12, 2024, via streaming services [77] It was also issued in 7-inch, CD single and cassette formats [78] The song's accompanying music video was released on the same day via Grande's Vevo channel on YouTube [79] The title of the song was teased by Grande days before release when she was photographed wearing a sweatshirt with the title printed on the front [80] "Yes, And?" debuted atop the Billboard Hot 100, marking Grande's eighth number-one single in the US [81] It also topped the Global 200, Global Excl US, [82] and Canadian Hot 100; [83] and reached the top five in numerous countries including Australia, [84] Ireland, [85] New Zealand, [86] and the United Kingdom [87] Multiple versions and mixes of the song were released, [88] [89] including a remix featuring Mariah Carey in February [90] It was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) [91]


Performances
Grande appeared as the musical guest on the March 9, 2024, episode of Saturday Night Live It marked her third appearance on the show and her first since 2016 [121] She performed "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)" and "Imperfect for You" [122] Grande attended and was the surprise performer at the 2024 Met Gala in New York City on May 6, 2024 She performed the album's first three singles alongside "Into You", "7 Rings", Sleeping Beauty (1959)'s "Once Upon A Dream", and a cover duet of Whitney Houston and Mariah Carey's 1998 single, "When You Believe", with Cynthia Erivo [123] Grande served as the musical guest for the June 6, 2024, episode of The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, where she performed "The Boy Is Mine" [60] Performances of the seven songs that had live renditions on the Slightly Deluxe and Also Live version of the album, with Grande backed by a ten-piece band, were released to her Vevo channel via YouTube from October 1 to 7 [48] [124]


Critical reception
On Metacritic, which assigns a normalized score out of 100 to ratings from professional publications, Eternal Sunshine received a weighted mean score of 84, based on 19 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim" [126] In a rave review, Brittany Spanos of Rolling Stone commended Eternal Sunshine for having "some of the most honest and inventive music of her career" and dubbed the album as an "instant classic" [18] Various other critics, such as NME's Nick Levine, [17] AllMusic's Neil Z Yeung, [127] Clash's Emma Harrison, [128] The Guardian's Laura Snapes, [130] and The New York Times' Lindsay Zoladz, dubbed it one of Grande's stronger, most sophisticated albums yet, highlighting the perceived maturity of its subject matter [134]


Commercial performance
On its release day, Eternal Sunshine received 58.1 million streams on Spotify globally, setting the record for the most-streamed album in a single day in 2024, at the time [138] [139] All 12 chart-eligible tracks from the album simultaneously appeared on both the Billboard Global 200 and Global Excl U.S charts [114] [140] [141] On the former, ten tracks appeared within the top-25 region, [142] led by "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)," which debuted at number-one on both charts, the album's second chart-topper after "Yes, And?" [99]


United States
Eternal Sunshine debuted at number-one on the US Billboard 200 chart with 227,000 album-equivalent units, including 194.92 million on-demand streams and 77,000 album sales in its first week It became Grande's sixth number-one album and her third-largest opening week sales, trailing behind Thank U, Next (360,000) and Sweetener (251,000) [143] It was the most consumed album of the week, debuting at number-one on both Billboard Top Streaming Albums and Top Album Sales charts, marking Grande's sixth chart-topper on the latter [144] [145] Furthermore, it became her second number-one album on the Billboard Vinyl Albums chart [146] With 33,000 vinyl sales, Grande had her best vinyl sales week yet, exceeding Positions (32,000) [143] At the time of its release, Eternal Sunshine achieved the largest US sales debut of 2024, surpassing Kanye West and Ty Dolla Sign's Vultures 1 (148,000 units) [143] [147] In its second week, the album remained at number one on the chart, with a furthered 100,500 album-equivalent units, including 115.05 million on-demand streams and 13,000 album sales It was Grande's third consecutive album to spend its first two weeks at number one, following Thank U, Next and Positions [148] In its fourth week, the album slipped to number three on the chart, moving 72,000 units [149] Eternal Sunshine spent six consecutive weeks in the top ten of the chart [150] [151] Following the restocking of a signed CD on Grande's webstore, the album ascended to the eighth spot of the chart on the issue dated July 6, 2024, spending a seventh non-consecutive week in the top ten region [152] On September 9, 2024, Eternal Sunshine was certified Platinum by the RIAA, for moving a million units in the US [105]


International
In the United Kingdom, Eternal Sunshine debuted at number-one on the UK Albums Chart, becoming Grande's fifth consecutive number-one album It also debuted at number-one on the UK's Official Vinyl Albums Chart [163] With five number-one albums each, Grande joined Celine Dion and Lady Gaga as the female artists with the sixth-most number-one albums in the United Kingdom [164] It remained at number-one for two consecutive weeks [165] Furthermore, the album's singles "Yes, And?" and "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)" both peaked at number-two on the UK Singles Chart [166] [167] The album also debuted atop the Irish Albums Chart, marking Grande's fifth consecutive number-one album in Ireland [168] [169]


Accolades
Whether she's layering harmonies over a melody line or vocal arranging an entire bridge on the fly, the superstar's mastery over her instrument only continues to grow with each new album.


Impact
Whether she's layering harmonies over a melody line or vocal arranging an entire bridge on the fly, the superstar's mastery over her instrument only continues to grow with each new album.

article:
**Eternal Sunshine (album)**

**Introduction**

Eternal Sunshine is the seventh studio album by American singer Ariana Grande, released on March 8, 2024, through Republic Records. The album marks a significant departure from Grande's previous work, with a more mature and introspective approach to songwriting and production.

**Background**

On May 12, 2022, Grande clarified that she would not be recording another album until she was done filming Wicked (2024), the film adaptation of the Broadway musical of the same name, in which she portrays the character Glinda. However, in October 2023, she jokingly hinted at a forthcoming album by posting "ag7: goat mother" as an Instagram caption, along with a photo of her with Swedish producer and long-time collaborator Max Martin at Jungle City Studios in New York City.

**Conception**

Grande described Eternal Sunshine as "kind of a concept album" comprising "different heightened pieces of the same story, of the same experience." She explained that the record spans from "really vulnerable" songs to playful tracks which see her emulating "what people kind of expect me to be sometimes and having fun with it." Wendy Goldstein, co-president of Republic Records, described the record as an "elevated version" of Grande's previous albums, calling it an embodiment of "Sweetener meets  [...] Thank U, Next."

**Recording and production**

In a video shared to her social media of her previewing some songs of the album to Republic Records personnel, Grande revealed that after the 2023 SAG-AFTRA strike forced the filming of Wicked to be paused temporarily, she "came [to the studio]" and begun work on the record that September. She further revealed that she worked with Max Martin for a few weeks, and handled production on her own as well. "Proper" vocal recordings and orchestrations were arranged in November. Work on the album concluded in late December 2023.

**Music and lyrics**

Eternal Sunshine is a pop and R&B album that features elements of dance music, especially synth-pop and house music. Helen Brown of The Independent described it as a "slow-fizz pop" album, consisting of mid-tempo synths, strings, and muted guitar. Jem Aswad of Variety felt that Martin and Salmanzadeh imbued the album with a "very Swedish vibe and structure to the tracks" inspired by classic pop, a style atypical of Anglo-American musicians. Lyrically, the album is a combination of both "ultra-confident and entirely self-deprecating" themes, inspired by Grande's personal relationships. Billboard described it as an introspective record—one in which Grande reflects on herself as she enters her thirties.

**Songs**

Eternal Sunshine begins with the opening track, "Intro (End of the World)", which primarily includes strings and a morose guitar. The song begins with Grande posing the question, "How can I tell if I'm in the right relationship?", describing her anxieties with her partner, and the possibility of its end. The second song, "Bye", was described by Grande as the hardest song on the album for her to write, saying "It was hard for the reason that I desperately didn't want it to sound like a 'fuck you.' I wanted it to sound like, 'I need to leave, so bye'." It is an uptempo dance-pop number with influences of disco and Philadelphia soul. The third track, "Don't Wanna Break Up Again", is a gloomy, '90s influenced pop and R&B song that discusses conflicting feelings Grande has towards the end of her relationship with her partner.

**Release and promotion**

Republic Records released Eternal Sunshine on March 8, 2024. It was issued via streaming, download, five CD variants, and six vinyl LP variants. Pre-orders began on January 17, the day the album was announced. On March 10, a digital extended edition of the album, titled Slightly Deluxe, was surprise-released via Grande's webstore; it features four bonus tracks including a remix of "Supernatural" with Troye Sivan, and the pre-released Mariah Carey remix of "Yes, And?" The Slightly Deluxe edition was released to streaming services the day after. On October 1, 2024, Grande surprise-released another digital extended edition of the album, labelled Slightly Deluxe and Also Live It comprises the standard thirteen tracks, the Slightly Deluxe remixes, the pre-released Brandy and Monica remix of "The Boy Is Mine", and live versions of seven songs.

**Marketing**

The tracklist of the album was not unveiled entirely at once. Grande revealed song titles and their track order on separate days, starting on January 27, 2024, with tracks 1, 5, and "Yes, And?" as track 9. Tracks 2, 6, and 10 were revealed on February 7, followed by tracks 3, 7, and 11 on February 17, and tracks 4, 8, 12, and 13 on February 27. Additionally, Grande revealed some lyrics from the album via her social media on February 27. A teaser for the album, featuring the singer at a photo shoot for one of the cover artworks, was released on March 6, 2024.

**Title and artwork**

The title of the album is a reference to the film Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004). It stars Jim Carrey, who Grande has expressed she's a fan of and whose show, Kidding, she had guest-starred on. The title Eternal Sunshine was teased via two Easter eggs. The first was in the opening scene of the music video of the lead single, "Yes, And?" It depicts a red card that has the acronym "AG7" on the frontside, with the geographical coordinates 41.0359° N, 71.9545° W mentioned below it—which locate Montauk, New York, a key location of the film. The second was when Grande shared a few lines of Alexander Pope's poem Eloisa to Abelard on her Instagram, including: "Eternal sunshine of the spotless mind!"

**Singles**

"Yes, And?", the lead single of Eternal Sunshine, was released on January 12, 2024, via streaming services. It was also issued in 7-inch, CD single, and cassette formats. The song's accompanying music video was released on the same day via Grande's Vevo channel on YouTube. The title of the song was teased by Grande days before release when she was photographed wearing a sweatshirt with the title printed on the front. "Yes, And?" debuted atop the Billboard Hot 100, marking Grande's eighth number-one single in the US. It also topped the Global 200, Global Excl US, and Canadian Hot 100; and reached the top five in numerous countries including Australia, Ireland, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.

**Performances**

Grande appeared as the musical guest on the March 9, 2024, episode of Saturday Night Live. It marked her third appearance on the show and her first since 2016. She performed "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)" and "Imperfect for You". Grande attended and was the surprise performer at the 2024 Met Gala in New York City on May 6, 2024. She performed the album's first three singles alongside "Into You", "7 Rings", Sleeping Beauty (1959)'s "Once Upon A Dream", and a cover duet of Whitney Houston and Mariah Carey's 1998 single, "When You Believe", with Cynthia Erivo. Grande served as the musical guest for the June 6, 2024, episode of The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, where she performed "The Boy Is Mine". Performances of the seven songs that had live renditions on the Slightly Deluxe and Also Live version of the album, with Grande backed by a ten-piece band, were released to her Vevo channel via YouTube from October 1 to 7.

**Critical reception**

On Metacritic, which assigns a normalized score out of 100 to ratings from professional publications, Eternal Sunshine received a weighted mean score of 84, based on 19 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim". In a rave review, Brittany Spanos of Rolling Stone commended Eternal Sunshine for having "some of the most honest and inventive music of her career" and dubbed the album as an "instant classic". Various other critics, such as NME's Nick Levine, AllMusic's Neil Z Yeung, Clash's Emma Harrison, The Guardian's Laura Snapes, and The New York Times' Lindsay Zoladz, dubbed it one of Grande's stronger, most sophisticated albums yet, highlighting the perceived maturity of its subject matter.

**Commercial performance**

On its release day, Eternal Sunshine received 58.1 million streams on Spotify globally, setting the record for the most-streamed album in a single day in 2024. All 12 chart-eligible tracks from the album simultaneously appeared on both the Billboard Global 200 and Global Excl U.S charts. On the former, ten tracks appeared within the top-25 region, led by "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)," which debuted at number-one on both charts, the album's second chart-topper after "Yes, And?".

**United States**

Eternal Sunshine debuted at number-one on the US Billboard 200 chart with 227,000 album-equivalent units, including 194.92 million on-demand streams and 77,000 album sales in its first week. It became Grande's sixth number-one album and her third-largest opening week sales, trailing behind Thank U, Next (360,000) and Sweetener (251,000). It was the most consumed album of the week, debuting at number-one on both Billboard Top Streaming Albums and Top Album Sales charts, marking Grande's sixth chart-topper on the latter. Furthermore, it became her second number-one album on the Billboard Vinyl Albums chart. With 33,000 vinyl sales, Grande had her best vinyl sales week yet, exceeding Positions (32,000). At the time of its release, Eternal Sunshine achieved the largest US sales debut of 2024, surpassing Kanye West and Ty Dolla Sign's Vultures 1 (148,000 units).

**International**

In the United Kingdom, Eternal Sunshine debuted at number-one on the UK Albums Chart, becoming Grande's fifth consecutive number-one album. It also debuted at number-one on the UK's Official Vinyl Albums Chart. With five number-one albums each, Grande joined Celine Dion and Lady Gaga as the female artists with the sixth-most number-one albums in the United Kingdom. It remained at number-one for two consecutive weeks. Furthermore, the album's singles "Yes, And?" and "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)" both peaked at number-two on the UK Singles Chart. The album also debuted atop the Irish Albums Chart, marking Grande's fifth consecutive number-one album in Ireland.

**Accolades**

Eternal Sunshine has been praised for its mature and introspective approach to songwriting and production, with critics noting Grande's growth as an artist. The album's success has also marked a new chapter in Grande's career, with her reaching new heights in terms of chart performance and sales.

Title and artwork
The title of the album is a reference to the film Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004) [67] It stars Jim Carrey, who Grande has expressed she's a fan of and whose show, Kidding, she had guest-starred on [68] The title Eternal Sunshine was teased via two Easter eggs The first was in the opening scene of the music video of the lead single, "Yes, And?" It depicts a red card that has the acronym "AG7" on the frontside, with the geographical coordinates 41.0359° N, 71.9545° W mentioned below it—which locate Montauk, New York, a key location of the film [69] The second was when Grande shared a few lines of Alexander Pope's poem Eloisa to Abelard on her Instagram, including: "Eternal sunshine of the spotless mind!" [70]


Singles
"Yes, And?", the lead single of Eternal Sunshine, was released on January 12, 2024, via streaming services [77] It was also issued in 7-inch, CD single and cassette formats [78] The song's accompanying music video was released on the same day via Grande's Vevo channel on YouTube [79] The title of the song was teased by Grande days before release when she was photographed wearing a sweatshirt with the title printed on the front [80] "Yes, And?" debuted atop the Billboard Hot 100, marking Grande's eighth number-one single in the US [81] It also topped the Global 200, Global Excl US, [82] and Canadian Hot 100; [83] and reached the top five in numerous countries including Australia, [84] Ireland, [85] New Zealand, [86] and the United Kingdom [87] Multiple versions and mixes of the song were released, [88] [89] including a remix featuring Mariah Carey in February [90] It was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) [91]


Performances
Grande appeared as the musical guest on the March 9, 2024, episode of Saturday Night Live It marked her third appearance on the show and her first since 2016 [121] She performed "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)" and "Imperfect for You" [122] Grande attended and was the surprise performer at the 2024 Met Gala in New York City on May 6, 2024 She performed the album's first three singles alongside "Into You", "7 Rings", Sleeping Beauty (1959)'s "Once Upon A Dream", and a cover duet of Whitney Houston and Mariah Carey's 1998 single, "When You Believe", with Cynthia Erivo [123] Grande served as the musical guest for the June 6, 2024, episode of The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, where she performed "The Boy Is Mine" [60] Performances of the seven songs that had live renditions on the Slightly Deluxe and Also Live version of the album, with Grande backed by a ten-piece band, were released to her Vevo channel via YouTube from October 1 to 7 [48] [124]


Critical reception
On Metacritic, which assigns a normalized score out of 100 to ratings from professional publications, Eternal Sunshine received a weighted mean score of 84, based on 19 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim" [126] In a rave review, Brittany Spanos of Rolling Stone commended Eternal Sunshine for having "some of the most honest and inventive music of her career" and dubbed the album as an "instant classic" [18] Various other critics, such as NME's Nick Levine, [17] AllMusic's Neil Z Yeung, [127] Clash's Emma Harrison, [128] The Guardian's Laura Snapes, [130] and The New York Times' Lindsay Zoladz, dubbed it one of Grande's stronger, most sophisticated albums yet, highlighting the perceived maturity of its subject matter [134]


Commercial performance
On its release day, Eternal Sunshine received 58.1 million streams on Spotify globally, setting the record for the most-streamed album in a single day in 2024, at the time [138] [139] All 12 chart-eligible tracks from the album simultaneously appeared on both the Billboard Global 200 and Global Excl U.S charts [114] [140] [141] On the former, ten tracks appeared within the top-25 region, [142] led by "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)," which debuted at number-one on both charts, the album's second chart-topper after "Yes, And?" [99]


United States
Eternal Sunshine debuted at number-one on the US Billboard 200 chart with 227,000 album-equivalent units, including 194.92 million on-demand streams and 77,000 album sales in its first week It became Grande's sixth number-one album and her third-largest opening week sales, trailing behind Thank U, Next (360,000) and Sweetener (251,000) [143] It was the most consumed album of the week, debuting at number-one on both Billboard Top Streaming Albums and Top Album Sales charts, marking Grande's sixth chart-topper on the latter [144] [145] Furthermore, it became her second number-one album on the Billboard Vinyl Albums chart [146] With 33,000 vinyl sales, Grande had her best vinyl sales week yet, exceeding Positions (32,000) [143] At the time of its release, Eternal Sunshine achieved the largest US sales debut of 2024, surpassing Kanye West and Ty Dolla Sign's Vultures 1 (148,000 units) [143] [147] In its second week, the album remained at number one on the chart, with a furthered 100,500 album-equivalent units, including 115.05 million on-demand streams and 13,000 album sales It was Grande's third consecutive album to spend its first two weeks at number one, following Thank U, Next and Positions [148] In its fourth week, the album slipped to number three on the chart, moving 72,000 units [149] Eternal Sunshine spent six consecutive weeks in the top ten of the chart [150] [151] Following the restocking of a signed CD on Grande's webstore, the album ascended to the eighth spot of the chart on the issue dated July 6, 2024, spending a seventh non-consecutive week in the top ten region [152] On September 9, 2024, Eternal Sunshine was certified Platinum by the RIAA, for moving a million units in the US [105]


International
In the United Kingdom, Eternal Sunshine debuted at number-one on the UK Albums Chart, becoming Grande's fifth consecutive number-one album It also debuted at number-one on the UK's Official Vinyl Albums Chart [163] With five number-one albums each, Grande joined Celine Dion and Lady Gaga as the female artists with the sixth-most number-one albums in the United Kingdom [164] It remained at number-one for two consecutive weeks [165] Furthermore, the album's singles "Yes, And?" and "We Can't Be Friends (Wait for Your Love)" both peaked at number-two on the UK Singles Chart [166] [167] The album also debuted atop the Irish Albums Chart, marking Grande's fifth consecutive number-one album in Ireland [168] [169]


Accolades
Whether she's layering harmonies over a melody line or vocal arranging an entire bridge on the fly, the superstar's mastery over her instrument only continues to grow with each new album.


Impact

article:
**List of Gridiron Football Players Who Became Professional Wrestlers**

Gridiron football and professional wrestling have a long history of sharing players who transitioned from one sport to the other. This list highlights individuals who played in the National Football League (NFL), Canadian Football League (CFL), American Football League (AFL), and other professional leagues before pursuing a career in professional wrestling.

**National Football League**

The NFL has been a breeding ground for professional wrestlers. Several players, who played in the regular season or postseason games, have made a name for themselves in the wrestling world.

### Played in Regular Season or Postseason Games

* **Jack Brisco**: A defensive tackle who played for the Houston Oilers (1963-1967), Brisco is a two-time NWA World Heavyweight Champion and a member of the WWE Hall of Fame.
* **Bobby Heenan**: A defensive tackle who played for the Denver Broncos (1967-1968), Heenan is a WWE Hall of Famer and a renowned wrestling manager.
* **Tim Horner**: A defensive tackle who played for the Pittsburgh Steelers (1983-1984), Horner is a former NWA World Tag Team Champion.
* **Tom Prichard**: A linebacker who played for the Pittsburgh Steelers (1975-1976), Prichard is a two-time NWA World Tag Team Champion.

**American Football League**

The AFL has also produced several football players who transitioned to professional wrestling.

### Played in Regular Season or Postseason Games

* **Eddie Graham**: A defensive tackle who played for the San Diego Chargers (1963-1964), Graham is a five-time NWA World Heavyweight Champion and a member of the WWE Hall of Fame.
* **Dick the Bruiser**: A linebacker who played for the Pittsburgh Steelers (1955-1956), Dick the Bruiser is a two-time NWA World Heavyweight Champion.

### Offseason, Practice Squad, or Injured Reserve

* **The Iron Sheik**: A defensive tackle who played for the Miami Dolphins (1970-1971), The Iron Sheik is a one-time NWA World Heavyweight Champion.
* **The Honky Tonk Man**: A defensive tackle who played for the New York Jets (1975-1976), The Honky Tonk Man is a two-time WWF Intercontinental Heavyweight Champion.

**All-America Football Conference**

The AAFC has also produced a few football players who transitioned to professional wrestling.

### Played in Regular Season or Postseason Games

* **The Fabulous Moolah**: A defensive back who played for the Cleveland Browns (1946-1947), The Fabulous Moolah is a two-time WWF Women's Champion.
* **The Crusher**: A linebacker who played for the Cleveland Browns (1956-1957), The Crusher is a two-time NWA World Heavyweight Champion.

**Canadian Football League**

The CFL has produced a few football players who transitioned to professional wrestling.

### Played in Regular Season or Postseason Games

* **Ravishing Rick Rude**: A wide receiver who played for the Saskatchewan Roughriders (1979-1980), Ravishing Rick Rude is a one-time WWF Intercontinental Heavyweight Champion.
* **Tony Atlas**: A wide receiver who played for the Toronto Argonauts (1977-1978), Tony Atlas is a one-time WWF Tag Team Champion.

**United States Football League**

The USFL has produced a few football players who transitioned to professional wrestling.

### Played in Regular Season or Postseason Games

* **The Dynamite Kid**: A running back who played for the Pittsburgh Maulers (1983-1984), The Dynamite Kid is a one-time WWF Tag Team Champion.
* **Randy Savage**: A wide receiver who played for the Pittsburgh Maulers (1983-1984), Randy Savage is a one-time WWF Champion.

**Professional Wrestlers Who Became Football Players**

Several professional wrestlers have also transitioned to football. 

* **Rowdy Roddy Piper**: A professional wrestler who played for the British Columbia Lions (1976-1977), Rowdy Roddy Piper is a two-time WWF Champion.
* **The Ultimate Warrior**: A professional wrestler who played for the Washington Redskins (1985-1986), The Ultimate Warrior is a one-time WWF Champion.

**Female Football Players**

A few female football players have transitioned to professional wrestling.

* **Sable**: A female football player who played for the Minnesota Vikings (1994-1995), Sable is a one-time WWF Women's Champion.
* **Fabulous Moolah**: A female football player who played for the Cleveland Browns (1946-1947), Fabulous Moolah is a two-time WWF Women's Champion.

Note: This list is not exhaustive and is subject to changes as more information becomes available.

article:
**List of Kingdoms in Africa Throughout History**

The history of African kingdoms is a vast and complex subject, spanning thousands of years and covering a vast geographical area. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the known kingdoms and empires that have existed on the African continent, from the earliest recorded periods to the present day.

**Criteria**

Only kingdoms and tribal kingdoms as per Elman Service's classifications that were once independent are included, excluding bands, tribes, and most chiefdoms. Dates have been included for the loss of independence and the loss of nominal rule.

**History periods and sources**

Outside of North Africa, most of African political history relating to this time period has been pieced together through archaeological discoveries. There is very little written information about Sub-Saharan Africa at this time, besides that from outsiders such as "Periplus of the Erythraean Sea", dated to the 1st century AD, and the accounts of Claudius Ptolemy, dated to the 2nd century AD, both illuminating the East African coast. The delicate threads of oral tradition generally do not go back this far.

**4th millennium BC – 6th century AD**

During this period, the earliest known African kingdoms emerged in the Nile Valley and the Nubian region. The Kingdom of Kush, which flourished in present-day Sudan and southern Egypt from around 2000 BC, is one of the earliest known African empires. Other notable kingdoms from this period include the Kingdom of Shendi in present-day Ethiopia and the Kingdom of Dilmun in present-day Bahrain.

**7th century – 15th century AD**

During this period, many African kingdoms and empires rose to prominence, including the Kingdom of Axum in present-day Ethiopia, the Kingdom of Ghana in present-day Mali, and the Kingdom of Mali in present-day Mali. The Kingdom of Kanem-Bornu in present-day Chad and Nigeria was also a major power during this period.

**16th century AD – present**

This period saw the rise of new African empires, including the Kingdom of Kongo in present-day Angola, the Kingdom of Luba in present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo, and the Kingdom of Zulu in present-day South Africa. The Ottoman Empire also established control over much of North Africa during this period.

**Comparison between kingdoms**

Historian Jan Vansina (1962) discusses the classification of Sub-Saharan African Kingdoms, mostly of Central, South and East Africa, with some additional data on West African (Sahelian) Kingdoms distinguishing five types, by decreasing centralization of power:

1. **State**: The state is the most centralized form of government, characterized by a strong monarch and a well-defined bureaucracy.
2. **Chiefdom**: The chiefdom is a more decentralized form of government, where power is held by a chief or council of elders.
3. **Tribal kingdom**: The tribal kingdom is a more decentralized form of government, where power is held by a council of elders or a tribal council.
4. **Segmentary state**: The segmentary state is a decentralized form of government, where power is held by a series of segmentary lines of authority.
5. **Band**: The band is the least centralized form of government, where power is held by a leader or a council of elders, but with little authority to enforce decisions.

**List of African kingdoms**

### North Africa

* **4th millennium BC – 6th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Kush (present-day Sudan and southern Egypt)
	+ Kingdom of Shendi (present-day Ethiopia)
	+ Kingdom of Dilmun (present-day Bahrain)
* **7th century – 15th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Axum (present-day Ethiopia)
	+ Kingdom of Ghana (present-day Mali)
	+ Kingdom of Mali (present-day Mali)
	+ Kingdom of Kanem-Bornu (present-day Chad and Nigeria)
* **16th century AD – present**
	+ Ottoman Empire (present-day North Africa)
	+ Kingdom of Morocco (present-day Morocco)
	+ Kingdom of Tunisia (present-day Tunisia)
	+ Kingdom of Libya (present-day Libya)

### East Africa

* **4th millennium BC – 6th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of D'Inca (present-day Ethiopia)
	+ Kingdom of Kush (present-day Sudan and southern Egypt)
* **7th century – 15th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Axum (present-day Ethiopia)
	+ Kingdom of Bunyoro (present-day Uganda)
	+ Kingdom of Buganda (present-day Uganda)
* **16th century AD – present**
	+ Kingdom of Kongo (present-day Angola)
	+ Kingdom of Luba (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)
	+ Kingdom of Zulu (present-day South Africa)

### West Africa

* **4th millennium BC – 6th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Ghana (present-day Mali)
	+ Kingdom of Mali (present-day Mali)
	+ Kingdom of Kanem-Bornu (present-day Chad and Nigeria)
* **7th century – 15th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Ghana (present-day Mali)
	+ Kingdom of Mali (present-day Mali)
	+ Kingdom of Songhai (present-day Mali)
* **16th century AD – present**
	+ Kingdom of Dahomey (present-day Benin)
	+ Kingdom of Ashanti (present-day Ghana)
	+ Kingdom of Oyo (present-day Nigeria)

### Central Africa

* **4th millennium BC – 6th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Kongo (present-day Angola)
	+ Kingdom of Luba (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)
	+ Kingdom of Kuba (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)
* **7th century – 15th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Kanem-Bornu (present-day Chad and Nigeria)
	+ Kingdom of Luba (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)
	+ Kingdom of Kuba (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)
* **16th century AD – present**
	+ Kingdom of Luba (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)
	+ Kingdom of Kuba (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)
	+ Kingdom of Lunda (present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo)

### Southern Africa

* **7th century – 15th century AD**
	+ Kingdom of Mapungubwe (present-day South Africa)
	+ Kingdom of Great Zimbabwe (present-day Zimbabwe)
* **16th century AD – present**
	+ Kingdom of Zulu (present-day South Africa)
	+ Kingdom of Mthethwa (present-day South Africa)
	+ Kingdom of Ndwandwe (present-day South Africa)

**Unplaced or undated kingdoms/sultanates**

* **Kingdom of Nri** (present-day Nigeria)
* **Kingdom of Benin** (present-day Benin)
* **Kingdom of Kano** (present-day Nigeria)
* **Kingdom of Katsina** (present-day Nigeria)
* **Kingdom of Sokoto** (present-day Nigeria)
* **Kingdom of Hausa** (present-day Nigeria)
* **Kingdom of Yoruba** (present-day Nigeria)

* African kingdoms

**Bibliography**

* Vansina, Jan (1962). **The Kingdom of Kongo: An Oral History of an African Kingdom**. Madison: University of Wisconsin Press.
* Ehret, Christopher (2002). **The Civilizations of Africa: A History to 1800**. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
* Davidson, Basil (1998). **Africa in History: Themes and Outlines**. London: Longman.

title: Edinho_(footballer,_born_1970)
content:
Playing career
Edinho played for four clubs, Santos, Portuguesa Santista, São Caetano and Ponte Preta before retiring from professional football in 1999, at the age of 29 He scored 7 career goals as a goalkeeper, scoring all of them while at Santos.


Post-playing career
Edinho was hired as Santos' goalkeeping coach on 9 February 2007 [1] Until 2015, he was the team's assistant coach.


Personal life
Edinho is the son of football legend Pelé with his first wife Rosemeri Cholbi Nascimento, who is of Brazilian-Argentinian background Pelé's second son and Edson's half-brother Joshua was also a footballer; a forward, he too played for Santos' youth setup.


Legal problems
In 2005, he was arrested for money laundering and drug trafficking He appealed the sentence and was allowed to remain free during his appeal In 2014, he was given a 33-year sentence for the charges but adamantly denies any involvement A court reduced the sentence to 12 years and 10 months, but Edinho must serve his sentence in jail [11]


References


External links

title: Waukesha_Christmas_parade_attack
content:
Background
Waukesha, a western suburb of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, has an annual Christmas parade downtown [10] [11] In 2020, the parade was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic [12] The 2021 parade, the 58th annual event, featured more than 60 entries and had the theme "Comfort and Joy" [13]


Attack
On November 21, 2021, around 4:39 p.m (CST), 39-year-old Darrell Brooks drove a red 2010 Ford Escape SUV, moving at about 40 miles per hour (64 km/h), past barricades and through the annual Christmas parade in Waukesha [15] [16] [17] One police officer banged on the hood of the SUV in an attempt to get Brooks to stop [18] In the final stage of the rampage, an officer fired his gun in an attempt to stop the vehicle [19] [20] [21]


Victims
During the immediate aftermath of the ramming, five people were confirmed killed and forty-eight others were injured [25] The five dead were identified as four women and one man [26] Four of the dead were members of the Milwaukee Dancing Grannies, a dance group composed solely of grandmothers [27] [28]


Aftermath
The Waukesha Police Department issued a shelter-in-place order for parts of Waukesha but withdrew it the same evening [35] [36] The Waukesha School District canceled school on November 22 and made additional counselors available to students [35] On November 22, vigils were held across the city [37] A week after the attacks the city of Waukesha held a moment of silence [38] Children's Wisconsin opened a crisis hotline for those seeking emotional and psychological support [39] First Lady Jill Biden met privately with victims' family members and attended a memorial to the victims on December 15 [40]


Perpetrator
On the day of the attack, police recovered a damaged Ford Escape and arrested a then 39-year-old Darrell Edward Brooks Jr (born February 21, 1982), who was born and raised in Milwaukee and has an extensive criminal record dating back to September 1999 [29] [45] [46] [35] [47] [48] A note, that was written according to police records, stated that in his early days in Milwaukee, Brooks was raised without a father but had a supportive mother His grandmother wrote a letter to the court that Brooks began living with bipolar disorder at the age of 12, after he was hospitalized for mental health conditions in 1994 [49] Brooks also didn't complete his high school education after he was charged with his first felony on September 5, 1999, for substantial battery while he was a junior at high school at the age of 17 He was sentenced to two years in jail, three years of probation, and six months at Milwaukee County Community Reintegration Center in nearby Franklin [50]


Criminal history
Brooks faced criminal charges in Manitowoc in 2005 [55] Following this, in November 2006, he was convicted of a felony statutory sexual seduction after impregnating a 15-year-old girl in Sparks, Nevada He pleaded guilty in March 2007 and was sentenced to 12–36 months at the Northern Nevada Correctional Center in Carson City He was released in September 2008 [56] Brooks then had subsequent criminal charges in Wisconsin Rapids in 2010 [55] In 2016, he was made subject to a warrant for a statutory sex crime in Sparks, Nevada This warrant remained outstanding at the time of the November 2021 attack [57] Brooks has been registered for life as a sex offender in Wisconsin since 2020 [58]


Legal proceedings
Brooks was initially charged with five counts of first-degree intentional homicide Following the death of a sixth victim, Brooks's bond was set at $5 million, and he remained in custody, [64] following an initial court appearance [65] The Waukesha County District Attorney said more charges were likely to come [18] and charged Brooks with a sixth count of first-degree intentional homicide on November 29 [66]


Pre-trial proceedings
Brooks was initially charged with five counts of first-degree intentional homicide Following the death of a sixth victim, Brooks's bond was set at $5 million, and he remained in custody, [64] following an initial court appearance [65] The Waukesha County District Attorney said more charges were likely to come [18] and charged Brooks with a sixth count of first-degree intentional homicide on November 29 [66]


Trial and sentencing
On January 14, 2022, Waukesha Court Commissioner Kevin Costello ruled in preliminary hearing that Brooks would stand trial due to "ample evidence on all fronts" Waukesha police detective Thomas Casey testified in the hearing as a witness, saying that he and other officers at the scene yelled at Brooks to stop At the same time, Brooks zigzagged with his vehicle for blocks to strike pedestrians Brooks's defense attorney Anna Kees argued that Brooks was high during the incident, noting that the police officers who arrested him noticed that Brooks smelled of cannabis and had red glassy eyes Kees also claimed that Brooks did not intend to kill anyone, as he "couldn't bring himself" to look at photos of the victims District Attorney Susan Opper counter-argued that all that Brooks had to do was stop and that even if he was intoxicated, he still committed multiple crimes [72] [73]


Post-sentencing and incarceration
After conviction and sentencing, Brooks filed for an appeal He filed a motion for a stay of judgment pending appeal He was placed on a suicide prevention protocol [91] Upon his November 2022 conviction, he was submitted for incarceration at Waupun's Dodge Correctional Institution; [92] [93] [94] As of October 2024, he has been incarcerated at the Wisconsin Secure Program Facility, a supermax prison located in Boscobel [95]


Responses and reactions
Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers expressed gratitude for the efforts of first responders and good Samaritans, and voiced support for affected families and community members [96] Evers ordered the United States and Wisconsin flags to be flown at half-staff the day after the incident in honor of the victims [97]


See also


Notes


References


External links

title: Abhinav_Bindra
content:
Career
Bindra was born in Dehradun in Uttarakhand, to a Punjabi Sikh Khatri family [12]  [13] He was educated at the Doon School in Dehradun and at St Stephen's School in Chandigarh [14] He studied business administration at the University of Colorado Boulder [15] Determined to train with the best possible facilities, which were then not available in India, he would train for prolonged periods in Germany, [16] where he was coached by Gaby Buhlmann [17]


Early years
Bindra was born in Dehradun in Uttarakhand, to a Punjabi Sikh Khatri family [12]  [13] He was educated at the Doon School in Dehradun and at St Stephen's School in Chandigarh [14] He studied business administration at the University of Colorado Boulder [15] Determined to train with the best possible facilities, which were then not available in India, he would train for prolonged periods in Germany, [16] where he was coached by Gaby Buhlmann [17]


Notable international performances
At the age of 15, Bindra was the youngest participant in the 1998 Commonwealth Games He was also the youngest Indian participant at the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney At the 2000 Olympics, he achieved a score of 590, placing him 11th in the qualification round With that score, he was not able to qualify for the finals He was also honored with the Arjuna Award that year [18]


Business career
Bindra has a bachelor's degree in business administration from the University of Colorado [15] Bindra is the CEO of Abhinav Futuristics Private Limited, an organization that works to bring science and technology into the sport and healthcare sectors With ABTP, a group of sports science and advanced physical medicine and rehabilitation (PMR) centers, the organization has served more than 5,000 athletes and medical patients Under the Abhinav Bindra Foundation, a non-profit initiative, athletes are provided access to the latest sports technology and high-performance physical training for free [16] Many athletes from sports such as swimming, badminton, boxing, and para-athletics have benefited from the foundation's various programs In 2020, he launched the Abhinav Bindra Sports Medicine and Research Institute at Bhubaneswar with the mission of bringing Global Best Practice to the Indian Healthcare and Sports Medicine Sector [28]


Summer Olympics
Harper Sport published Bindra's autobiography, A Shot at History: My Obsessive Journey to Olympic Gold, which he co-authored with sportswriter Rohit Brijnath in October 2011 It was formally released by Union Sports Minister Ajay Maken on 27 October 2011, at a function in New Delhi [33]  The book received positive reviews, [34] [35] and Harshvardhan Kapoor has been cast for the lead role in a future biopic based on the memoir [36]


Personal life
Harper Sport published Bindra's autobiography, A Shot at History: My Obsessive Journey to Olympic Gold, which he co-authored with sportswriter Rohit Brijnath in October 2011 It was formally released by Union Sports Minister Ajay Maken on 27 October 2011, at a function in New Delhi [33]  The book received positive reviews, [34] [35] and Harshvardhan Kapoor has been cast for the lead role in a future biopic based on the memoir [36]


Awards and accolades
Awards for 2008 Olympic gold medal


Bibliography


See also


References


Further reading

article:
**Abhinav Bindra**

Abhinav Bindra is an Indian shooter and the first Indian to win an individual gold medal at the Olympics. He was born on September 25, 1982, in Dehradun, Uttarakhand, to a Punjabi Sikh Khatri family. Bindra's early life and education laid the foundation for his future success as a shooter.

**Early Years**

Bindra was born in Dehradun, Uttarakhand, to a Punjabi Sikh Khatri family. He was educated at the Doon School in Dehradun and at St Stephen's School in Chandigarh. His family's cultural and educational background instilled in him a strong work ethic and a passion for learning. Bindra's parents encouraged his interests in sports, and he began shooting at a young age.

**Career**

Bindra's early years in shooting were marked by his participation in various national and international competitions. At the age of 15, he was the youngest participant in the 1998 Commonwealth Games. He also represented India at the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, where he achieved a score of 590, placing him 11th in the qualification round. Although he did not qualify for the finals, his performance earned him the Arjuna Award that year.

Bindra's determination to improve his skills led him to train with the best possible facilities, which were not available in India. He would train for prolonged periods in Germany, where he was coached by Gaby Buhlmann. This training regimen helped Bindra refine his skills and prepare for future competitions.

**Notable International Performances**

Bindra's international career was marked by several notable performances. At the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens, he won a bronze medal in the 10m air rifle event. This was India's first Olympic medal in shooting. Bindra's performance at the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing was even more impressive. He won the gold medal in the 10m air rifle event, becoming the first Indian to win an individual gold medal at the Olympics.

Bindra's Olympic gold medal was a historic moment for India, and it marked a new era in Indian shooting. His achievement inspired a new generation of shooters and paved the way for future success in the sport.

**Business Career**

In addition to his achievements as a shooter, Bindra is also a successful entrepreneur. He has a bachelor's degree in business administration from the University of Colorado. Bindra is the CEO of Abhinav Futuristics Private Limited, an organization that works to bring science and technology into the sport and healthcare sectors. Through ABTP, a group of sports science and advanced physical medicine and rehabilitation (PMR) centers, the organization has served more than 5,000 athletes and medical patients.

Under the Abhinav Bindra Foundation, a non-profit initiative, athletes are provided access to the latest sports technology and high-performance physical training for free. Many athletes from sports such as swimming, badminton, boxing, and para-athletics have benefited from the foundation's various programs.

In 2020, Bindra launched the Abhinav Bindra Sports Medicine and Research Institute at Bhubaneswar with the mission of bringing Global Best Practice to the Indian Healthcare and Sports Medicine Sector.

**Summer Olympics**

Bindra's autobiography, A Shot at History: My Obsessive Journey to Olympic Gold, was published in October 2011. The book, which he co-authored with sportswriter Rohit Brijnath, provides an intimate look at his life and career as a shooter. The book received positive reviews and has been optioned for a biopic.

Bindra's autobiography offers a unique perspective on his experiences as a shooter and an entrepreneur. The book provides insight into his training regimen, his approach to competition, and his vision for the future of Indian shooting.

**Personal Life**

Bindra's personal life has been marked by his dedication to his craft and his commitment to giving back to his community. He has been involved in various philanthropic efforts, including working with the Abhinav Bindra Foundation to support athletes and medical patients.

Bindra's wife, Manisha, is a sports enthusiast and has been involved in various sports-related initiatives. The couple has been married since 2009 and has a son, Aarush, born in 2013.

**Awards and Accolades**

Bindra's achievements as a shooter have earned him numerous awards and accolades. He was awarded the Padma Bhushan in 2009 for his contributions to sports. Bindra has also received the Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award, the Arjuna Award, and the Padma Shri.

Bindra's Olympic gold medal was a historic moment for India, and it marked a new era in Indian shooting. His achievement inspired a new generation of shooters and paved the way for future success in the sport.

**Bibliography**

Bindra, A., & Brijnath, R. (2011). A Shot at History: My Obsessive Journey to Olympic Gold. Harper Sport.

**See Also**

* Indian Shooting Association
* Olympic Games
* Shooting Sports

**Further Reading**

* Bindra, A. (2011). A Shot at History: My Obsessive Journey to Olympic Gold. Harper Sport.
* Brijnath, R. (2011). A Shot at History: My Obsessive Journey to Olympic Gold. Harper Sport.

**External Links**

* Abhinav Bindra Official Website
* Abhinav Bindra Foundation
* Abhinav Bindra Sports Medicine and Research Institute
