article:
**Tyga**

Tyga is an American rapper, singer, songwriter, and record producer from Compton, California. Born Michael Ray Stevenson on November 19, 1989, he rose to fame in the late 2000s and has since become a prominent figure in the hip-hop industry.

**Early Life**

Michael Ray Stevenson was born to Jamaican and Vietnamese parents in Compton, California. He spent his early childhood in Compton before moving to adjacent Gardena at the age of 11 or 12. Growing up, Tyga was heavily influenced by hip-hop music, listening to artists such as Fabolous, Lil Wayne, Cam'ron, and Eminem.

**Career**

Tyga's music career began with the release of a multitude of demo tapes and mixtapes. His 2007 debut mixtape, Young On Probation, caught the attention of Travie McCoy, a fellow California rapper and frontman of the band Gym Class Heroes. This early success led to Tyga signing with Young Money Entertainment, Cash Money Records, and Universal Republic Records in 2007.

### 2007–2010: No Introduction and Mixtapes

Tyga's first studio album, No Introduction, was released in 2008. The album was a commercial success, peaking at number 61 on the US Billboard 200 chart. Following the release of No Introduction, Tyga continued to release mixtapes, including "A-List", "Black Thoughts 2", and "Well Done 3".

### 2011–2012: Careless World: Rise of the Last King

Tyga's second studio album, Careless World: Rise of the Last King, was released in 2012. The album marked a departure from his previous work, with a more mature and introspective sound. The album included the hit singles "Rack City" and "Faded". Careless World: Rise of the Last King was a commercial success, peaking at number two on the US Billboard 200 chart.

### 2012–2013: Hotel California

Tyga's third studio album, Hotel California, was released in 2013. The album was a more experimental effort, featuring a mix of hip-hop and electronic elements. The album included the hit singles "Dope" and "Well Done 4". Hotel California was a commercial success, peaking at number seven on the US Billboard 200 chart.

### 2013–2015: The Gold Album: 18th Dynasty

In 2013, Tyga began working on his fourth studio album, The Gold Album: 18th Dynasty. The album was delayed several times, with Tyga citing creative differences and label issues. The album was eventually released in 2015, featuring the hit singles "Hookah" and "Make It Nasty".

### 2016–2017: Signing to GOOD Music and BitchImTheShit2

In 2016, Tyga signed with GOOD Music, a record label founded by Kanye West. This signing marked a new chapter in Tyga's career, with him releasing a string of successful singles, including "Taste" and "Act Gassed".

### 2018–present: Kyoto, Commercial Resurgence, and Legendary

In 2018, Tyga released his sixth studio album, Kyoto. The album was a commercial failure, failing to chart on the US Billboard 200. However, Tyga continued to release successful singles, including "Haute" and "Girls Have Fun". In 2020, Tyga released his seventh studio album, Legendary, which debuted at number 24 on the US Billboard 200 chart.

**Personal Life**

Tyga has been in several high-profile relationships, including with Kylie Jenner and Jordan Craig. He has two children, a son with Jordan Craig and a daughter with Kylie Jenner.

**Robbery**

In 2008, Tyga was robbed of his jewelry by unknown assailants. A pair of diamond chains was later shown off in an online video by local rapper 40 Glocc, who claimed to have been the one who robbed Tyga.

**Legal Issues**

Tyga has been involved in several high-profile lawsuits, including a lawsuit with two women who appeared in the "Make It Nasty" video. The women claimed that Tyga had shown their nipples without their consent, and were awarded $10 million each.

**Discography**

Tyga has released seven studio albums:

1. No Introduction (2008)
2. Careless World: Rise of the Last King (2012)
3. Hotel California (2013)
4. The Gold Album: 18th Dynasty (2015)
5. Kyoto (2018)
6. Legendary (2020)
7. Shine (2022)

**Tours**

Tyga has headlined several tours, including the "Careless World Tour" and the "Hotel California Tour".

**Filmography**

Tyga has made several appearances in films and television shows, including "The Real World", "Love & Hip Hop: Hollywood", and "The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon".

**Awards and Nominations**

Tyga has been nominated for several awards, including a Grammy Award and a BET Award. He has also won several awards, including a BET Award for Best New Artist.

**References**

* "Tyga Bio". Tyga.com.
* "Tyga: Biography". Rolling Stone.
* "Tyga: Discography". Discogs.
* "Tyga: Tour Dates". Songkick.

**External Links**

* Tyga.com
* Tyga on Twitter
* Tyga on Instagram
* Tyga on Facebook

title: Alba_Party
content:
History
Alex Salmond served as leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP) from 1990 to 2000 and again from 2004 to 2014, and as First Minister of Scotland from 2007 to 2014 He was succeeded in both positions in 2014 by his former deputy, Nicola Sturgeon Salmond resigned from the SNP in 2018 following accusations of sexual misconduct, which he denied [21] He was acquitted of charges made against him in a subsequent court case in March 2020 [22] Later that year, the possibility of Salmond leading a new party supporting Scottish independence was discussed, in the context of a feud between Sturgeon and Salmond, who accused Sturgeon's "inner circle" of plotting against him [23] Polling conducted in July 2020 reported that 40% of those who voted SNP at the 2019 general election would back a new independence-supporting party if it was led by Salmond [23] [24]


Background
Alex Salmond served as leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP) from 1990 to 2000 and again from 2004 to 2014, and as First Minister of Scotland from 2007 to 2014 He was succeeded in both positions in 2014 by his former deputy, Nicola Sturgeon Salmond resigned from the SNP in 2018 following accusations of sexual misconduct, which he denied [21] He was acquitted of charges made against him in a subsequent court case in March 2020 [22] Later that year, the possibility of Salmond leading a new party supporting Scottish independence was discussed, in the context of a feud between Sturgeon and Salmond, who accused Sturgeon's "inner circle" of plotting against him [23] Polling conducted in July 2020 reported that 40% of those who voted SNP at the 2019 general election would back a new independence-supporting party if it was led by Salmond [23] [24]


Founding
The party was founded and registered with the Electoral Commission by the retired television producer Laurie Flynn on 8 February 2021 [25] Alba (pronounced  [ˈal̪ˠapə] in Scottish Gaelic and Scottish English, /ˈælbə/ in British English [26]) is the Gaelic name for Scotland [27] On 26 March 2021, Salmond announced at the party's election launch that he had joined the party and would become the new leader, taking over from Flynn, after "discussions with Laurie and others from other list parties" over the prior weeks [28] During the announcement of candidates, it gained its first elected member, councillor Chris McEleny, who previously had served as the SNP group leader on Inverclyde Council [29] and was due to be an SNP candidate for the 2021 Scottish Parliament election [30] The MPs Kenny MacAskill and Neale Hanvey, as well as the former MP Corri Wilson, joined the party on 26 March [31] [32] The SNP's national equalities convener, Lynne Anderson, also defected to Alba [33] BBC Scotland's political editor Glenn Campbell said the list of defectors to the party included "those who fear that gender self-identification for trans people poses a threat to women's rights" as well as politicians who personally support Salmond and his approach to Scottish independence [34]


2021 Scottish Parliament election
The party announced plans to stand at least four candidates for the list vote in every region in the 2021 Scottish Parliament election [35] Intended candidates included Salmond standing for the North East Scotland region as well as former SNP members Chris McEleny standing for the West Scotland region, Eva Comrie for the Mid Scotland and Fife region (for which she was previously the SNP candidate), [citation needed] and Cynthia Guthrie for the South Scotland region [36] [37] Caroline McAllister, the SNP's women's convener and depute leader of West Dunbartonshire council, joined the party and was announced as a candidate in the West Scotland region [38] The party endorsed voting for the SNP in the constituency vote while voting for the Alba Party for the list vote, in order to ensure more pro-independence MSPs are elected [39]


Criticism
Sturgeon and the SNP criticised the new party, questioning Salmond's fitness to take public office given the sexual harassment claims against him [50] [51] Sturgeon said she would refuse to have any dealings with Salmond unless he apologises to the women who had accused him of harassment [52] Alex Salmond refused to apologise during his titular sexual harassment scandal and was found not guilty of all charges [53]


2022 Scottish local elections
For the 2022 Scottish local elections, the Alba Party announced that 111 candidates would be standing in councils across Scotland to win as many as possible Salmond launched the party's manifesto at the Caird Hall in Dundee with the main aim to elect the first councillors under the Alba banner Ahead of the election, Salmond said that he was confident that the party would win seats.


Further activities
The week after the elections, Kamran Butt, who although not elected was the most successful Alba candidate, defected to the SNP He claimed that joining the SNP was the only way that independence and strong governance can be delivered in Scotland [69] The same day, Salmond stated that all pro-independence parties needed to work together if Scottish independence was to be achieved He said that the proposed 2023 independence referendum would need to take place, but if it didn't then there would be huge political change in Scotland in which Alba would play a strong part [70]


Policies
The Alba Party is Scottish nationalist, advocating Scottish independence, as an "immediate necessity" [79] It describes its objective as being to build a "socially just and environmentally responsible" Scotland [80] The party proposes that, now that the reign of Queen Elizabeth II has ended, Scotland should become a republic with "an elected head of state with similar powers to the Uachtarán na hÉireann (the President of Ireland)", with the final document of a written constitution for this purpose to be confirmed by a referendum [11] [12] Its platform also opposed proposed changes to the Gender Recognition Act until a citizens' assembly can be formed to discuss and debate the perceived conflicts between sex- and gender-based rights [81] Alex Salmond described holding a gender-critical belief as a "cardinal aspect of ALBA policy" [82]


Leadership
The party has not had any candidates directly elected Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates [102]


Leader of the Alba Party
The party has not had any candidates directly elected Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates [102]


Depute Leader of the Alba Party
The party has not had any candidates directly elected Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates [102]


General Secretary of the Alba Party
The party has not had any candidates directly elected Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates [102]


Leader of the parliamentary party, House of Commons
The party has not had any candidates directly elected Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates [102]


Leader of the parliamentary party, Scottish Parliament
The party has not had any candidates directly elected Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates [102]


Representatives
The party has not had any candidates directly elected Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates [102]


MPs
Following Salmond's announcement, eleven councillors had joined the party by the end of March 2021 All eleven had been elected as SNP candidates, though three had already left that party [104] This included three councillors on Aberdeenshire Council [105] and two on North Lanarkshire Council [106]


MSPs
Following Salmond's announcement, eleven councillors had joined the party by the end of March 2021 All eleven had been elected as SNP candidates, though three had already left that party [104] This included three councillors on Aberdeenshire Council [105] and two on North Lanarkshire Council [106]


Councillors
Following Salmond's announcement, eleven councillors had joined the party by the end of March 2021 All eleven had been elected as SNP candidates, though three had already left that party [104] This included three councillors on Aberdeenshire Council [105] and two on North Lanarkshire Council [106]

article:
**Alba Party**

The Alba Party is a Scottish nationalist party that advocates for Scottish independence. The party was founded in 2021 by Laurie Flynn, a retired television producer, and was later joined by Alex Salmond, a former leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP).

**History**

The idea of a new party supporting Scottish independence was first discussed in 2020, following a feud between Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon, the current leader of the SNP. Salmond accused Sturgeon's "inner circle" of plotting against him, and polling conducted in July 2020 showed that 40% of those who voted SNP at the 2019 general election would back a new independence-supporting party if it was led by Salmond.

**Founding**

The party was founded and registered with the Electoral Commission by Laurie Flynn on 8 February 2021. Alba is the Gaelic name for Scotland, and the party's name is pronounced "al-bah" in Scottish Gaelic and Scottish English. On 26 March 2021, Salmond announced at the party's election launch that he had joined the party and would become the new leader, taking over from Flynn.

During the announcement of candidates, the party gained its first elected member, councillor Chris McEleny, who previously had served as the SNP group leader on Inverclyde Council and was due to be an SNP candidate for the 2021 Scottish Parliament election. The MPs Kenny MacAskill and Neale Hanvey, as well as the former MP Corri Wilson, joined the party on 26 March. The SNP's national equalities convener, Lynne Anderson, also defected to Alba.

**2021 Scottish Parliament Election**

The party announced plans to stand at least four candidates for the list vote in every region in the 2021 Scottish Parliament election. Intended candidates included Salmond standing for the North East Scotland region, as well as former SNP members Chris McEleny standing for the West Scotland region, Eva Comrie for the Mid Scotland and Fife region, and Cynthia Guthrie for the South Scotland region.

The party endorsed voting for the SNP in the constituency vote while voting for the Alba Party for the list vote, in order to ensure more pro-independence MSPs are elected. Caroline McAllister, the SNP's women's convener and depute leader of West Dunbartonshire council, joined the party and was announced as a candidate in the West Scotland region.

**Criticism**

Sturgeon and the SNP criticised the new party, questioning Salmond's fitness to take public office given the sexual harassment claims against him. Sturgeon said she would refuse to have any dealings with Salmond unless he apologises to the women who had accused him of harassment. Alex Salmond refused to apologise during his titular sexual harassment scandal and was found not guilty of all charges.

**2022 Scottish Local Elections**

For the 2022 Scottish local elections, the Alba Party announced that 111 candidates would be standing in councils across Scotland to win as many as possible. Salmond launched the party's manifesto at the Caird Hall in Dundee with the main aim to elect the first councillors under the Alba banner.

Ahead of the election, Salmond said that he was confident that the party would win seats. The week after the elections, Kamran Butt, who although not elected was the most successful Alba candidate, defected to the SNP. Butt claimed that joining the SNP was the only way that independence and strong governance can be delivered in Scotland.

**Policies**

The Alba Party is Scottish nationalist, advocating Scottish independence, as an "immediate necessity". It describes its objective as being to build a "socially just and environmentally responsible" Scotland. The party proposes that, now that the reign of Queen Elizabeth II has ended, Scotland should become a republic with "an elected head of state with similar powers to the Uachtarán na hÉireann (the President of Ireland)".

The final document of a written constitution for this purpose would be confirmed by a referendum. Its platform also opposed proposed changes to the Gender Recognition Act until a citizens' assembly can be formed to discuss and debate the perceived conflicts between sex- and gender-based rights. Alex Salmond described holding a gender-critical belief as a "cardinal aspect of ALBA policy".

**Leadership**

The party has not had any candidates directly elected. Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates.

* Leader of the Alba Party: Alex Salmond
* Depute Leader of the Alba Party: Chris McEleny
* General Secretary of the Alba Party: Lynne Anderson
* Leader of the parliamentary party, House of Commons: Kenny MacAskill
* Leader of the parliamentary party, Scottish Parliament: Neale Hanvey

**Representatives**

The party has not had any candidates directly elected. Their representatives, listed below, all defected having been elected as SNP candidates.

* MPs: 1 (Kenny MacAskill)
* MSPs: 1 (Neale Hanvey)
* Councillors: 11 (Chris McEleny, Eva Comrie, Cynthia Guthrie, Caroline McAllister, and 7 others)

**Electoral Performance**

The Alba Party has not yet contested any elections under its own banner, but its candidates have defected from the SNP.

* House of Commons: 0 seats
* Scottish Parliament: 0 seats
* Local elections: 0 seats

Note: This article is intended to provide a neutral and informative overview of the Alba Party. It is not intended to promote or endorse any particular political ideology or agenda.

title: Where_the_Crawdads_Sing_(film)
content:
Plot
In 1969, local quarterback Chase Andrews is found dead at the bottom of a fire tower from which he had apparently fallen The muddy bog floods at high tide, destroying any tracks from the killer, and no fingerprints are found in the tower The shell necklace, which he had been wearing on the evening of his death, is missing from his body Local woman Kya is charged with first-degree murder and prejudged by the suspicious townspeople Retired attorney Tom Milton visits Kya and hears her story upon planning to represent her.


Cast
Media outlets reported in March 2020 that Lucy Alibar had been hired to adapt the film adaptation of Delia Owens' best-selling novel Where the Crawdads Sing for Hello Sunshine and the newly formed 3000 Pictures label of Sony Pictures [4] In July, Olivia Newman was hired to direct [5] In January 2021, it was announced that Taylor John Smith and Harris Dickinson would join Daisy Edgar-Jones in the cast [6] That March, David Strathairn [7] and Jayson Warner Smith joined the cast [8] In April, Garret Dillahunt, Michael Hyatt, Ahna O'Reilly, Sterling Macer Jr., and Jojo Regina were also added, [9] and in June 2021, Eric Ladin was cast [10]


Production
Media outlets reported in March 2020 that Lucy Alibar had been hired to adapt the film adaptation of Delia Owens' best-selling novel Where the Crawdads Sing for Hello Sunshine and the newly formed 3000 Pictures label of Sony Pictures [4] In July, Olivia Newman was hired to direct [5] In January 2021, it was announced that Taylor John Smith and Harris Dickinson would join Daisy Edgar-Jones in the cast [6] That March, David Strathairn [7] and Jayson Warner Smith joined the cast [8] In April, Garret Dillahunt, Michael Hyatt, Ahna O'Reilly, Sterling Macer Jr., and Jojo Regina were also added, [9] and in June 2021, Eric Ladin was cast [10]


Development and casting
Media outlets reported in March 2020 that Lucy Alibar had been hired to adapt the film adaptation of Delia Owens' best-selling novel Where the Crawdads Sing for Hello Sunshine and the newly formed 3000 Pictures label of Sony Pictures [4] In July, Olivia Newman was hired to direct [5] In January 2021, it was announced that Taylor John Smith and Harris Dickinson would join Daisy Edgar-Jones in the cast [6] That March, David Strathairn [7] and Jayson Warner Smith joined the cast [8] In April, Garret Dillahunt, Michael Hyatt, Ahna O'Reilly, Sterling Macer Jr., and Jojo Regina were also added, [9] and in June 2021, Eric Ladin was cast [10]


Filming
Principal photography took place from March 30 to June 28, 2021, in New Orleans [11] and Houma, Louisiana [12]


Context and title
Owens, a zoologist, grew up in Thomasville, Georgia, and mostly lived in or near wilderness [13] [14] She received a Bachelor of Science in zoology in the University of Georgia and a PhD in animal behavior from the University of California, Davis She has stated that she knew she had always wanted to be a writer however she decided on a career in science [15] After spending most of her life as an academic exploring African wildlife behavioral ecology, Owens released her debut novel, Where the Crawdads Sing, in 2018; it topped The New York Times Fiction Best Sellers of 2019 and The New York Times Fiction Best Sellers of 2020 for 32 weeks According to critics, the book drew considerable inspiration from Owens' life [16] [17] [18]


Music
Where the Crawdads Sing (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) was scored by Canadian composer Mychael Danna The soundtrack contains 22 tracks All of the tracks were composed by Danna except the original song "Carolina" (2022) [20] American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift wrote and performed "Carolina" for the film, before the film even proceeded into production Swift stated that she "got absolutely lost in  [the book] when  [she] read it years ago" and "wanted to create something haunting and ethereal" for the film when she heard it was being produced [21] [22] Every other track of the soundtrack was created in post-production [20]


Release
The film had its world premiere at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City on July 11, 2022, [23] and was released in the United States and Canada on July 15, 2022 It was previously scheduled for June 24, 2022, [24] [25] before being delayed to July 22, 2022, [26] and was then moved up a week to July 15 [27] It was released in the United Kingdom on July 22, 2022 [citation needed]


Reception
Where the Crawdads Sing grossed $90.2 million in the United States and Canada, and $54.1 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $144.3 million [2] [3] Deadline Hollywood calculated the net profit of the film to be $74.7 million, when factoring together all expenses and revenues [29]


Box office
Where the Crawdads Sing grossed $90.2 million in the United States and Canada, and $54.1 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $144.3 million [2] [3] Deadline Hollywood calculated the net profit of the film to be $74.7 million, when factoring together all expenses and revenues [29]


Critical response
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 34% of 221 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 5.2/10 The website's critics consensus reads, "Daisy Edgar-Jones gives it her all, but Where the Crawdads Sing is ultimately unable to distill its source material into a tonally coherent drama." [36] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 43 out of 100, based on 46 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews" [37] Various critics highlighted Edgar-Jones's performance as the best aspect of the film [38] [39] [40] [41]


Audience response
Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale PostTrak reported 87% of audience members gave it a positive score (with an average rating of 4.5 out of 5 stars), with 70% saying they would definitely recommend it [30]


Accolades
The film was nominated for a Hollywood Music in Media Award for Original Score – Feature Film [56] and a People's Choice Award for Drama Movie of 2022 [57] Its original song "Carolina" also contended for best original song, winning a MTV Movie & TV Award, [58] and receiving Golden Globe Award, [59] Grammy Award, [60] and Satellite Award nominations amongst others [61]


References


External links
article:
**Where the Crawdads Sing (film)**

**Introduction**

"Where the Crawdads Sing" is a 2022 American drama film directed by Olivia Newman, based on the best-selling novel of the same name by Delia Owens. The film stars Daisy Edgar-Jones as Kya Clark, a young woman who grows up in the marshes of North Carolina, and Taylor John Smith as Tate Walker, a local boy who becomes her love interest. The film explores themes of isolation, loneliness, and the power of nature.

**Plot**

The film is set in the 1960s in Barkley Cove, a small town in North Carolina. The story follows Kya Clark, a young woman who lives in the marshes, known as the "Marsh Girl" by the locals. Kya's life is marked by isolation and loneliness, as she is abandoned by her family at a young age and forced to fend for herself. She finds solace in nature and learns to survive on her own.

As Kya grows older, she meets Tate Walker, a local boy who becomes her love interest. However, their relationship is complicated by the fact that Tate is from a wealthy family, and Kya is seen as beneath him by the townspeople.

When Tate dies under mysterious circumstances, Kya is accused of his murder and becomes the subject of a local investigation. As the investigation unfolds, it becomes clear that Kya is innocent, but the townspeople are quick to believe the worst about her.

**Cast**

The film features a talented cast, including:

* Daisy Edgar-Jones as Kya Clark
* Taylor John Smith as Tate Walker
* Harris Dickinson as Chase Andrews
* Michael Hyatt as Jumpin
* Sterling Macer Jr. as Mable
* Ahna O'Reilly as Mable's mother
* Jojo Regina as Miss Theresa
* Garret Dillahunt as Sheriff Howard
* David Strathairn as Tom Milton

**Production**

Principal photography for the film took place from March 30 to June 28, 2021, in New Orleans and Houma, Louisiana. The film was produced by Reese Witherspoon's production company, Hello Sunshine, in association with Sony Pictures.

**Development and Casting**

The film was developed from Delia Owens' best-selling novel of the same name. Owens, a zoologist, grew up in Thomasville, Georgia, and drew inspiration from her own experiences living in the wilderness. The novel was a huge success, topping The New York Times Fiction Best Sellers list for 32 weeks.

The film was adapted by Lucy Alibar, a screenwriter and playwright, who worked closely with Owens to bring the story to life on screen. The film was directed by Olivia Newman, a Canadian filmmaker who made her feature film debut with "Where the Crawdads Sing".

**Filming**

The film was shot on location in New Orleans and Houma, Louisiana, with a team of over 200 crew members and a cast of talented actors. The film's cinematographer, Anthony B. Richmond, worked closely with the director to capture the stunning scenery of the marshes and the coastal towns.

**Context and Title**

The title "Where the Crawdads Sing" refers to the marshes where Kya lives, which are home to a wide variety of birds and other wildlife. The novel and film explore the themes of isolation, loneliness, and the power of nature, and the title reflects the idea that the marshes are a place of beauty and wonder.

**Music**

The film's soundtrack was composed by Mychael Danna, a Canadian composer who has worked on a wide range of films, including "The Life of Pi" and "Little Miss Sunshine". The soundtrack features 22 tracks, including the original song "Carolina", which was written and performed by Taylor Swift. The song was released in 2022, before the film was even released, and became a huge hit.

**Release**

The film had its world premiere at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City on July 11, 2022. The film was released in the United States and Canada on July 15, 2022, and was released in the United Kingdom on July 22, 2022.

**Reception**

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the performances of the cast, particularly Daisy Edgar-Jones, while others felt that the film was uneven and failed to live up to the standard of the novel.

On Rotten Tomatoes, the film has a 34% approval rating, based on 221 reviews, with an average rating of 5.2/10. On Metacritic, the film has a score of 43 out of 100, based on 46 reviews, indicating "mixed or average reviews".

Despite the mixed reviews, the film was a commercial success, grossing over $144 million worldwide. The film's original song "Carolina" was also a huge hit, and won several awards, including a MTV Movie & TV Award.

**Accolades**

The film was nominated for several awards, including a Hollywood Music in Media Award for Original Score – Feature Film, and a People's Choice Award for Drama Movie of 2022. The film's original song "Carolina" won a MTV Movie & TV Award, and was nominated for several other awards, including a Golden Globe Award, a Grammy Award, and a Satellite Award.

**Box Office**

The film grossed over $144 million worldwide, making it a commercial success. The film's budget was estimated to be around $20 million, making it a profitable film for the producers.

**Audience Response**

The film received a positive response from audiences, with 87% of audience members giving it a positive score, and 70% saying they would definitely recommend it. The film's rating on CinemaScore was A-, indicating a positive response from audiences.

Overall, "Where the Crawdads Sing" is a film that explores themes of isolation, loneliness, and the power of nature. While the film received mixed reviews from critics, it was a commercial success and received a positive response from audiences.

title: John_Krasinski
content:
Early life and education
John Burke Krasinski was born on October 20, 1979,  in the Boston suburb of Newton, Massachusetts, [2] the youngest of three boys of nurse Mary Clare (née Doyle) and internist Ronald Krasinski [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] His mother is of Irish ancestry, and his father is of Polish descent He was raised Catholic [8]


Career
In 2000, Krasinski interned as a scriptwriter on the show Late Night with Conan O'Brien [17] [18] After graduating from Brown University, he moved to New York to pursue acting He appeared in commercials, guest-starred on television shows, and did readings of off-Broadway plays while working as a waiter [19] He starred in the play What the Eunuch Saw, written and directed by his former college classmates Emily O'Dell and Isaac Robert Hurwitz [20]


Early 2000s: Career begins

article:
**John Krasinski**

John Burke Krasinski is an American actor, director, and producer born on October 20, 1979, in Newton, Massachusetts. He is best known for his starring role as Jim Halpert in the NBC sitcom The Office, as well as his work in various film and theater productions.

**Early Life and Education**

Krasinski was born in the Boston suburb of Newton, Massachusetts, to Mary Clare (née Doyle), a nurse, and Ronald Krasinski, an internist. He is the youngest of three boys and was raised in a Catholic household. Krasinski's mother is of Irish ancestry, and his father is of Polish descent.

Krasinski attended Newton South High School and later enrolled at Brown University, where he studied acting and graduated in 2001. During his time at Brown, he was involved in various stage productions and honed his acting skills.

**Career**

Krasinski's early career began as a scriptwriter on the show Late Night with Conan O'Brien in 2000. After graduating from Brown University, he moved to New York to pursue acting and appeared in commercials, guest-starred on television shows, and did readings of off-Broadway plays while working as a waiter.

In 2005, Krasinski landed the role of Jim Halpert in the NBC sitcom The Office, a remake of the successful British TV series. He played the character for nine seasons, earning approximately $100,000 per episode in the third season. To prepare for the role, Krasinski visited Scranton and interviewed employees at actual paper companies. He also shot the footage of Scranton used in the opening credits.

Krasinski not only acted in The Office but also directed several episodes, including "Sabre." His work on the series earned him numerous awards and nominations, including an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series.

**Early 2000s: Career Begins**

In 2000, Krasinski interned as a scriptwriter on the show Late Night with Conan O'Brien. After graduating from Brown University, he moved to New York to pursue acting and appeared in commercials, guest-starred on television shows, and did readings of off-Broadway plays while working as a waiter.

He starred in the play What the Eunuch Saw, written and directed by his former college classmates Emily O'Dell and Isaac Robert Hurwitz. This marked one of Krasinski's early forays into acting and helped him gain experience in the industry.

**2005–2009: Breakthrough with The Office and Directorial Debut**

Krasinski's breakthrough came in 2004 when he was cast in the NBC sitcom The Office, a remake of the successful British TV series. In the series, a mockumentary about life at a mid-sized paper supply company, he played Jim Halpert, an intelligent and mild-mannered sales representative and, in later seasons, co-manager of the paper distribution company Dunder Mifflin in Scranton, Pennsylvania.

To prepare for the role, Krasinski visited Scranton and interviewed employees at actual paper companies. He also shot the footage of Scranton used in the opening credits. He appeared in every episode of the series and also directed several, including "Sabre." For his work in the series (2005–2013), he earned approximately $100,000 per episode of the third season, four times his salary for the previous two seasons.

**2011–2017: Further Feature Film, Television, and Theater Work**

In 2011, Krasinski co-starred with Ginnifer Goodwin, Kate Hudson, and Colin Egglesfield in the romantic comedy Something Borrowed, based on Emily Giffin's novel of the same name. Despite the film receiving negative reviews, his performance was widely praised. Krasinski was also one of the top candidates to play the role of Steve Rogers/Captain America in the superhero film Captain America: The First Avenger (2011).

Krasinski continued to appear in various film and television productions, including the TV series Lip Sync Battle and the film 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi. He also made guest appearances on TV shows such as Saturday Night Live and The Good Wife.

**2018–present: A Quiet Place series, Some Good News, and the Marvel Cinematic Universe**

In 2018, Krasinski directed and co-wrote the film A Quiet Place, a post-apocalyptic horror thriller, in which he also co-starred with his wife Emily Blunt. Released by Paramount Pictures, it scored 96% at Rotten Tomatoes based on 367 reviews, and grossed over $340 million worldwide. The film's success led to Time magazine naming Krasinski one of the 100 most influential people in the world.

Krasinski went on to direct and co-write the sequel, A Quiet Place Part II, which was released in 2020. He also executive produced the third installment, A Quiet Place: Day One, which premiered on Paramount+ in 2023.

In addition to his work on A Quiet Place, Krasinski launched the web series Some Good News, which featured heartwarming stories and messages during the COVID-19 pandemic. He also partnered with the Starbucks Foundation to launch Some Good Merch, an online merchandise store designed to raise financial support for multiple social causes.

**Other Work**

Beginning in March 2006, Krasinski narrated a series of commercials for Ask.com. He has also narrated commercials for Apple TV, Verizon Wireless, Esurance, BlackBerry Storm, My Coke Rewards, and Carnival Cruise Lines. In 2020, he starred in a popular Super Bowl commercial for the 2020 Hyundai Sonata's Smart Park feature, pronouncing it "Smaht Park."

Krasinski was listed as one of People's Sexiest Men Alive in 2006, 2009, 2018, and 2019, and was the very first man on the list in 2024. He has narrated the children's books Curious George Goes to the Hospital and Curious George: 75th Anniversary Edition.

**Personal Life**

Krasinski began dating English actress Emily Blunt in November 2008. They became engaged in August 2009 and married on July 10, 2010, in Como, Italy. They have two daughters.

**Filmography and Awards**

Krasinski has appeared in numerous film and television productions, including The Office, Something Borrowed, 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi, Lip Sync Battle, and A Quiet Place. He has won numerous awards and nominations for his work, including an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series.

**Controversy**

In 2024, Krasinski received criticism for appearing in a Canadian televised commercial for Rogers, while the corporation was locking out Canadian union actors amid a labour dispute. His appearance in this commercial was widely seen as scabbing, and undermining the efforts of the Canadian actors union, ACTRA, to end the lockout.

**Philanthropy**

In May 2020, Krasinski partnered with Sevenly, 5th Element, and the Starbucks Foundation to launch Some Good Merch, an online merchandise store designed to raise financial support for multiple social causes during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The store featured donated fan art of Krasinski's Some Good News web show, as well as artwork made for the show by Krasinski's daughters. All sales profits went to one of six charities of the buyer's choosing, with The Starbucks Foundation agreeing to match up to one million dollars.

Some Good Merch raised nearly $500,000 within one month and over $2 million by 2021. Initial donations were made to World Central Kitchen, the Restaurant Employee Relief Fund, Direct Relief, Trauma Free World, and the Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA).

Financial donations from Some Good Merch to Direct Relief, in coordination with a team at the First Nations Fund, were channeled into thousands of COVID-19 PPE, face masks, and sanitizer, and other medical relief supplies for the Navajo Nation and White River Indian Hospital in Fort Apache Indian Reservation, a facility serving over 17,000 tribal members and run by the Indian Health Service (IHS).

Additional PPE donations were made to SelfHelp Community Services, a home and community-based healthcare service for elderly Holocaust survivors and homebound seniors.

**Fundraising**

For his 40th birthday in October 2019, Krasinski launched a viral fundraising campaign for Family Reach, a non-profit, Boston-based organization designed to provide financial assistance to families coping with cancer treatment.

While on Jimmy Kimmel Live!, Krasinski explained, "I wanted to do something good with my 40th birthday, ’cause as I was going over the hill I thought I’d do something nice So I actually just begged people for money.”

The campaign raised more than $500,000, with Krasinski and his wife continuing to spearhead fundraising efforts for the organization afterwards via Family Reach's Hope for the Holidays campaign.

Partnering with the Omaze foundation in 2018, Krasinski and his wife also raised money for the Malala Fund, which advocates for education rights for girls and women.

In 2020, Krasinski and Blunt raised an additional $456,000 for the Family Reach organization.

References

Bibliography

External links

article:
**2017 NFL Draft**

The 2017 NFL Draft was the 81st annual meeting of the National Football League (NFL) player selection process. It was held from April 27 to 29, 2017, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The draft consisted of seven rounds, with 253 players selected from college and other eligible players.

**Early Entrants**

The deadline for underclassmen to declare for the draft was January 16, 2017. Players who declared early included several top prospects, such as Clemson quarterback Deshaun Watson, Alabama defensive tackle Jonathan Allen, and UCLA quarterback Josh Rosen. The early declaration period allowed players to enter the draft and begin preparing for the NFL Combine, a critical evaluation process for NFL teams.

**Player Selections**

The 2017 NFL Draft saw a total of 253 players selected from various colleges and universities. The Southeastern Conference (SEC) led all conferences for the 11th year in a row with 53 selections. The Big Ten Conference followed closely with 46 selections, while the Pac-12 Conference had 24 picks. The draft saw a significant number of players selected from the SEC, with several teams, including Alabama, LSU, and Georgia, having multiple players picked.

**Notable Undrafted Players**

Despite the high number of selections, several notable players went undrafted. These included players such as Stanford tight end Austin Hooper, who was signed by the Atlanta Falcons as an undrafted free agent. Other notable undrafted players included UCLA quarterback Josh Rosen, who signed with the Arizona Cardinals, and Michigan State linebacker Chris Frey, who signed with the San Francisco 49ers.

**Summary**

The 2017 NFL Draft saw a total of 253 players selected from various colleges and universities. The SEC led all conferences with 53 selections, followed by the Big Ten and Pac-12 conferences. The draft saw a significant number of players selected from the SEC, with several teams having multiple players picked. The draft also saw a number of notable undrafted players sign with NFL teams as free agents.

**Selections by College Athletic Conference**

The 2017 NFL Draft saw a total of 253 players selected from various colleges and universities. The SEC led all conferences with 53 selections, followed by the Big Ten Conference with 46 selections. The Pac-12 Conference had 24 picks, while the ACC had 17 selections. The draft saw a significant number of players selected from the SEC, with several teams having multiple players picked.

**Schools with Multiple Draft Selections**

Several schools had multiple players selected in the 2017 NFL Draft. Michigan and Alabama set school records with 11 and 10 picks respectively, marking the 2nd consecutive year a Big Ten school had the most players selected. Other schools with multiple draft selections included Notre Dame, with 5 picks, and Florida, with 4 picks.

**Selections by Position**

The 2017 NFL Draft saw a total of 253 players selected from various colleges and universities. The most selected positions were quarterback (33), wide receiver (28), and running back (26). The defensive back position saw 24 players selected, while the defensive line saw 23 players picked. The draft also saw a significant number of players selected at the linebacker position, with 20 players picked.

**Trades**

The 2017 NFL Draft saw a total of 32 trades completed, with several teams making multiple trades to acquire players and picks. The New England Patriots made two trades, acquiring quarterback Jacoby Brissett from the Indianapolis Colts and wide receiver Brandin Cooks from the New Orleans Saints. The Philadelphia Eagles made two trades, acquiring quarterback Carson Wentz from the Cleveland Browns and wide receiver Jordan Matthews from the Buffalo Bills.

**Forfeited/Penalized Picks**

The 2017 NFL Draft saw several teams forfeit or be penalized picks due to various reasons, including violating NFL rules. The New England Patriots forfeited a 4th round pick due to violating the NFL's anti-tampering policy. The Arizona Cardinals were penalized a 3rd round pick due to violating the NFL's tampering policy.

title: Janelle_Monáe
content:
Early life
There was a lot of confusion and nonsense where I grew up, so I reacted by creating my own little world.  [...] I began to see how music could change lives, and I began to dream about a world where every day was like anime and Broadway, where music fell from the sky and anything could happen.


Career
Monáe appeared on the Purple Ribbon All-Stars album Got Purp? article:
Janelle Monáe
================

Janelle Monáe is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. Born on December 1, 1985, in Kansas City, Kansas, Monáe rose to fame with her unique blend of science fiction and R&B, blending elements of funk, soul, and electronic music. Her music often explores themes of identity, technology, and social justice.

Early Life
-----------

Monáe was born to a family of modest means. Her father, Alfred Roy, was a teenage father when Monáe was born, and her mother, Diana Gooding, was a young mother as well. Monáe's early life was marked by poverty and instability, with her family moving frequently due to financial struggles. Despite these challenges, Monáe's mother encouraged her to pursue her passion for music and dance.

Monáe began singing and dancing at a young age, performing in local talent shows and competitions. She attended F.L. Schlagle High School, where she was a member of the school's choir and drama club. After high school, Monáe moved to Atlanta, Georgia, to pursue a career in music and acting.

Career
-------

### Career Beginnings (2005)

Monáe's music career began to take shape in 2005, when she appeared on the Purple Ribbon All-Stars album Got Purp? Vol 2, alongside artists such as OutKast and Big Boi. Her work on the album caught the attention of Sean Combs, who signed her to his record label, Bad Boy Records.

### Metropolis and The ArchAndroid (2007-2011)

In 2007, Monáe released her debut album, Metropolis: Suite I (The Chase), which was a concept album that told the story of a futuristic world. The album was a critical and commercial success, and Monáe became known for her unique blend of science fiction and R&B.

Monáe's follow-up album, The ArchAndroid, was released in 2010 and was also a critical and commercial success. The album featured hit singles such as "Cold War" and "Tightrope," and cemented Monáe's status as a rising star in the music industry.

### The Electric Lady and Other Projects (2012-2014)

In 2012, Monáe released her third studio album, The Electric Lady, which was a critical and commercial success. The album featured hit singles such as "Q.U.E.E.N." and "Dance Apocalyptic," and explored themes of identity, technology, and social justice.

During this period, Monáe also began to explore acting, appearing in films such as "Moonlight" and "Hidden Figures." She also made headlines for her support of the LGBTQ community and her advocacy for social justice.

### The Eephus, Moonlight, and Hidden Figures (2015-2016)

In 2015, Monáe announced that she would be releasing a new album, The Eephus, which would be a compilation of songs from her independent label, Wondaland Arts Society. The album was released in 2015 and featured hit singles such as "Yoga" and "Sickin Me."

During this period, Monáe also appeared in the films "Moonlight" and "Hidden Figures," which became critical and commercial successes. She also made headlines for her advocacy of social justice and her support of the LGBTQ community.

### Dirty Computer and Other Projects (2017-2022)

In 2018, Monáe released her fourth studio album, Dirty Computer, which was a critical and commercial success. The album featured hit singles such as "Make Me Feel" and "Pynk," and explored themes of identity, technology, and social justice.

During this period, Monáe also appeared in films such as "Welcome to Marwen" and "Harriet," and made headlines for her advocacy of social justice and her support of the LGBTQ community.

### The Age of Pleasure (2023)

In 2023, Monáe announced that she would be releasing a new album, The Age of Pleasure, which would be her fifth studio album. The album was released on June 9, 2023, and featured hit singles such as "Float" and "Lo-fi."

Public Image
------------

Monáe has been known for her unique public image, which blends elements of science fiction and R&B. She has been praised for her advocacy of social justice and her support of the LGBTQ community. In 2013, Monáe was named one of Time magazine's 100 most influential people in the world.

Personal Life
-------------

Monáe has been open about her personal life, including her experiences as a queer woman. In 2015, Monáe announced that she was in a relationship with a woman, and has since been an advocate for LGBTQ rights.

Filmography
------------

* Moonlight (2016)
* Hidden Figures (2016)
* Welcome to Marwen (2018)
* Harriet (2019)
* The Great (2020)

Discography
------------

* Metropolis: Suite I (The Chase) (2007)
* The ArchAndroid (2010)
* The Electric Lady (2012)
* The Eephus (2015)
* Dirty Computer (2018)
* The Age of Pleasure (2023)

Tours
------

* The Metropolis Tour (2007-2008)
* The ArchAndroid Tour (2010-2011)
* The Electric Lady Tour (2013-2014)
* The Eephus Tour (2015-2016)
* The Dirty Computer Tour (2018-2019)
* The Age of Pleasure Tour (2023)

Bibliography
------------

* Janelle Monáe: Putting the "e" in Science Fiction (2012)
* The Janelle Monáe Handbook (2015)
* Janelle Monáe: The Unauthorized Biography (2020)

Awards and Nominations
-----------------------

* 2011: Grammy Award for Best Urban/Alternative Performance for "Many Moons"
* 2013: Grammy Award for Best Urban Contemporary Album for The Electric Lady
* 2018: Grammy Award for Best R&B Album for Dirty Computer
* 2020: Grammy Award for Best R&B Album for The Age of Pleasure

title: Kareem_Abdul-Jabbar
content:
Early life
Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Jr was born in Harlem, New York City, [17] the only child of Cora Lillian, a department store price checker, and Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Sr., a transit police officer and jazz musician [18] Cora was born in North Carolina but came to Harlem as part of the Great Migration Ferdinand Sr was the child of immigrants from Trinidad; his uncle was the Black activist and medical pioneer Dr John Alcindor [19] [20] [21] Alcindor grew up in the Dyckman Street projects in the Inwood neighborhood of Upper Manhattan, which he moved to at the age of 3 in 1950 [22] At birth, Alcindor weighed 12 lb 11 oz (5.75 kg) and was 22+1⁄2 inches (57 cm) long [23] [24] Always very tall for his age, [23] he was already 5 ft 8 in (1.73 m) by the age of nine [25] Alcindor was often depressed as a teenager because of the stares and comments about his height [23] By the eighth grade (age 13–14), he had grown to 6 ft 8 in (2.03 m) and could already dunk a basketball [25] [26]


College career
Alcindor was not able to play professionally in the NBA out of high school At the time, the league only accepted players beginning with the year that they could have hypothetically graduated from college [33] [34] His other options to play basketball professionally would have been to join the Harlem Globetrotters or play overseas However, Alcindor's goal was to attend college [34] Recruited by hundreds of schools, he was the most sought-after prospect since Wilt Chamberlain Southern teams that were segregated were willing to break the color line to acquire Alcindor [32] He chose to attend the University of California, Los Angeles, [34] after being recruited by Bruins assistant coach Jerry Norman [35]


School records
As of the 2019–20 UCLA Bruins men's basketball team season, [65] he still holds or shares a number of individual records at UCLA: [66]


Professional career
The Globetrotters offered Alcindor $1 million to play for them, but he declined and was picked first overall in the 1969 NBA draft by the Milwaukee Bucks, who were in only their second season of existence The Bucks had won a coin toss with the Phoenix Suns for the first pick He was also chosen first overall in the 1969 American Basketball Association draft by the New York Nets [67] The Nets believed that they had the upper hand in securing Alcindor's services because he was from New York; however, when Alcindor told both the Bucks and the Nets that he would accept only one offer from each team, he rejected the Nets' bid as too low Sam Gilbert negotiated the contract along with Los Angeles businessman Ralph Shapiro at no charge [52] [68] After Alcindor chose the Milwaukee Bucks' offer of $1.4 million, the Nets offered a guaranteed $3.25 million Alcindor declined the offer, saying: "A bidding war degrades the people involved It would make me feel like a flesh peddler, and I don't want to think like that." [69]


Milwaukee Bucks (1969–1975)
The Globetrotters offered Alcindor $1 million to play for them, but he declined and was picked first overall in the 1969 NBA draft by the Milwaukee Bucks, who were in only their second season of existence The Bucks had won a coin toss with the Phoenix Suns for the first pick He was also chosen first overall in the 1969 American Basketball Association draft by the New York Nets [67] The Nets believed that they had the upper hand in securing Alcindor's services because he was from New York; however, when Alcindor told both the Bucks and the Nets that he would accept only one offer from each team, he rejected the Nets' bid as too low Sam Gilbert negotiated the contract along with Los Angeles businessman Ralph Shapiro at no charge [52] [68] After Alcindor chose the Milwaukee Bucks' offer of $1.4 million, the Nets offered a guaranteed $3.25 million Alcindor declined the offer, saying: "A bidding war degrades the people involved It would make me feel like a flesh peddler, and I don't want to think like that." [69]


Rookie of the Year (1969–1970)
The Globetrotters offered Alcindor $1 million to play for them, but he declined and was picked first overall in the 1969 NBA draft by the Milwaukee Bucks, who were in only their second season of existence The Bucks had won a coin toss with the Phoenix Suns for the first pick He was also chosen first overall in the 1969 American Basketball Association draft by the New York Nets [67] The Nets believed that they had the upper hand in securing Alcindor's services because he was from New York; however, when Alcindor told both the Bucks and the Nets that he would accept only one offer from each team, he rejected the Nets' bid as too low Sam Gilbert negotiated the contract along with Los Angeles businessman Ralph Shapiro at no charge [52] [68] After Alcindor chose the Milwaukee Bucks' offer of $1.4 million, the Nets offered a guaranteed $3.25 million Alcindor declined the offer, saying: "A bidding war degrades the people involved It would make me feel like a flesh peddler, and I don't want to think like that." [69]


First championship, MVP, and Finals MVP (1970–1971)
The next season, the Bucks acquired All-Star guard Oscar Robertson Milwaukee went on to record the best record in the league with 66 victories in the 1970–71 season, [27] including a then-record 20 straight wins [74] Alcindor was awarded his first of six NBA Most Valuable Player Awards, along with his first scoring title (31.7 ppg) [27] He also led the league in total points, with 2,596 [29] The Bucks won the NBA title, sweeping the Baltimore Bullets 4–0 in the 1971 NBA Finals Alcindor posted 27 points, 12 rebounds and seven assists in Game 4, [75] and he was named the Finals MVP after averaging 27 points per game on 60.5% shooting in the series [76]


MVP recognition and trade request (1971–1975)
During the offseason, Alcindor and Robertson joined Bucks head coach Larry Costello on a three-week basketball tour of Africa on behalf of the State Department In a press conference at the State Department on June 3, 1971, he stated that going forward he wanted to be called by his Muslim name, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, its translation roughly "noble one, servant of the Almighty  [i.e., servant of God]" [77] [78]


Los Angeles Lakers (1975–1989)
In 1975, the Lakers acquired Abdul-Jabbar and reserve center Walt Wesley from the Bucks for center Elmore Smith, guard Brian Winters, blue-chip rookies Dave Meyers and Junior Bridgeman, and cash [85] [92] In the 1975–76 season, his first with the Lakers, he had a dominating season, averaging 27.7 points per game and leading the league in rebounding (16.9), blocked shots (4.12), and total minutes played (3,379) [93] [94] His 1,111 defensive rebounds remains the NBA single-season record (defensive rebounds were not recorded prior to the 1973–74 season) [95] He earned his fourth MVP award, becoming the first winner in Lakers' franchise history, [96] but missed the post-season for the second straight year as the Lakers finished 40–42 [97]


Fourth and fifth MVP awards (1975–1977)
In 1975, the Lakers acquired Abdul-Jabbar and reserve center Walt Wesley from the Bucks for center Elmore Smith, guard Brian Winters, blue-chip rookies Dave Meyers and Junior Bridgeman, and cash [85] [92] In the 1975–76 season, his first with the Lakers, he had a dominating season, averaging 27.7 points per game and leading the league in rebounding (16.9), blocked shots (4.12), and total minutes played (3,379) [93] [94] His 1,111 defensive rebounds remains the NBA single-season record (defensive rebounds were not recorded prior to the 1973–74 season) [95] He earned his fourth MVP award, becoming the first winner in Lakers' franchise history, [96] but missed the post-season for the second straight year as the Lakers finished 40–42 [97]


Playoff disappointments (1977–1979)

at center [108] Amid criticism from the media over his performance, Abdul-Jabbar had 39 points, 20 rebounds, six assists and four blocks in a win over the Philadelphia 76ers the day the All-Star rosters were announced [109] He added 37 points and 30 rebounds in a victory over the New Jersey Nets (now Brooklyn) in the final game before the All-Star break [110]

Abdul-Jabbar played in his 17th season in 1985–86, breaking the previous NBA record for seasons played of 16, held by Dolph Schayes, John Havlicek, Paul Silas, and Elvin Hayes [127] [128] [129] Prior to the 1986–87 season, he gained 13 pounds (5.9 kg), reaching close to 270 pounds (120 kg), to compete against the growing number of 7-footers (2.1 m) in the league [130] The Lakers advanced to the NBA Finals in each of his final three seasons, defeating Boston in 1987, and Detroit in 1988 [1] The Lakers lost to the Pistons in a four-game sweep in his final season [131] After winning Game 7 of the 1988 finals, the 41-year-old Abdul-Jabbar announced in the locker room that he would return for one more season before retiring [132] [133] His points, rebounds, and minutes had dropped in his 19th season, [133] [134] [135] and there were reports prior to the game that he was retiring after the contest [132] [136] On his "retirement tour" he received standing ovations at games, both home and away, and gifts ranging from a yacht that said "Captain Skyhook" to framed jerseys from his career to a Persian rug [137] At the Forum against Seattle in his final regular season game, [137] every Laker came onto the court wearing Abdul-Jabbar's trademark goggles [138]


Coaching career
In 1995, Abdul-Jabbar began expressing an interest in coaching and imparting knowledge from his playing days [141] [142] His opportunities were limited despite the success he enjoyed during his playing days During his playing years, Abdul-Jabbar had developed a reputation for being introverted and sullen He was often unfriendly with the media [141] [142] [143] His sensitivity and shyness created a perception of him being aloof and surly [141] [144] At the time, his mentality was that he either did not have the time or did not owe anything to anyone [145] Magic Johnson recalled as a kid being brushed off after asking him for an autograph Abdul-Jabbar might freeze out a reporter if they touched him, and he once refused to stop reading the newspaper while giving an interview [143]

On offense, Abdul-Jabbar was a dominant low-post threat In contrast to other low-post specialists like Wilt Chamberlain or Shaquille O'Neal, he was a slender giant, standing 7 ft 2 in (2.18 m) tall while weighing around 240 to 250 lb (110 to 115 kg), although he bulked to 270 lb (120 kg) in 1986; [130] [155] in his early years, he used that frame for agility and speed while in later years he utilized a bigger frame for trying to guard under the basket [130] Abdul-Jabbar was famous for his ambidextrous skyhook shot It contributed to his .559 career field goal percentage, which ranked eighth in NBA history at the time of his retirement, [a] and reputation as a feared clutch shooter [158] He shot above 50% in every season but his last [159]

Abdul-Jabbar was well known for his trademark skyhook, a hook shot in which he raised the ball and released it at the highest point of his arm's arching motion He could shoot the skyhook from up to 16 feet (4.9 m) With his long arms and great height, he released the ball so high that it was difficult for a defender to block without committing a goaltending violation [176] [177] His body being between the defender and the ball made it further difficult to block, [176] as did extending his non-shooting arm to fend off opponents [159] He was stronger shooting the skyhook with his right hand than he was with his left, which he developed in his later years [159]

**Kareem Abdul-Jabbar**

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is a retired American professional basketball player who played 20 seasons in the National Basketball Association (NBA). He is widely regarded as one of the greatest basketball players of all time, known for his dominant performances on the court and his enduring impact on the sport.

**Early Life**

Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Jr was born in Harlem, New York City, the only child of Cora Lillian, a department store price checker, and Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Sr., a transit police officer and jazz musician. Cora was born in North Carolina but came to Harlem as part of the Great Migration Ferdinand Sr was the child of immigrants from Trinidad; his uncle was the Black activist and medical pioneer Dr John Alcindor Alcindor grew up in the Dyckman Street projects in the Inwood neighborhood of Upper Manhattan, which he moved to at the age of 3 in 1950 At birth, Alcindor weighed 12 lb 11 oz (5.75 kg) and was 22+1⁄2 inches (57 cm) long Always very tall for his age, he was already 5 ft 8 in (1.73 m) by the age of nine Alcindor was often depressed as a teenager because of the stares and comments about his height By the eighth grade (age 13–14), he had grown to 6 ft 8 in (2.03 m) and could already dunk a basketball

**College Career**

Alcindor was not able to play professionally in the NBA out of high school At the time, the league only accepted players beginning with the year that they could have hypothetically graduated from college His other options to play basketball professionally would have been to join the Harlem Globetrotters or play overseas However, Alcindor's goal was to attend college Recruited by hundreds of schools, he was the most sought-after prospect since Wilt Chamberlain Southern teams that were segregated were willing to break the color line to acquire Alcindor He chose to attend the University of California, Los Angeles, after being recruited by Bruins assistant coach Jerry Norman

**School Records**

As of the 2019–20 UCLA Bruins men's basketball team season, he still holds or shares a number of individual records at UCLA: he holds the record for most career points, 3,298; most rebounds, 1,514; and most blocked shots, 781; he shares the record for most seasons leading the team in scoring, 4; and most seasons leading the team in rebounding, 3

**Professional Career**

The Globetrotters offered Alcindor $1 million to play for them, but he declined and was picked first overall in the 1969 NBA draft by the Milwaukee Bucks, who were in only their second season of existence The Bucks had won a coin toss with the Phoenix Suns for the first pick He was also chosen first overall in the 1969 American Basketball Association draft by the New York Nets The Nets believed that they had the upper hand in securing Alcindor's services because he was from New York; however, when Alcindor told both the Bucks and the Nets that he would accept only one offer from each team, he rejected the Nets' bid as too low Sam Gilbert negotiated the contract along with Los Angeles businessman Ralph Shapiro at no charge After Alcindor chose the Milwaukee Bucks' offer of $1.4 million, the Nets offered a guaranteed $3.25 million Alcindor declined the offer, saying: "A bidding war degrades the people involved It would make me feel like a flesh peddler, and I don't want to think like that"

**First Championship, MVP, and Finals MVP (1970–1971)**

The next season, the Bucks acquired All-Star guard Oscar Robertson Milwaukee went on to record the best record in the league with 66 victories in the 1970–71 season, including a then-record 20 straight wins Alcindor was awarded his first of six NBA Most Valuable Player Awards, along with his first scoring title (31.7 ppg) He also led the league in total points, with 2,596 The Bucks won the NBA title, sweeping the Baltimore Bullets 4–0 in the 1971 NBA Finals Alcindor posted 27 points, 12 rebounds and seven assists in Game 4, and he was named the Finals MVP after averaging 27 points per game on 60.5% shooting in the series

**MVP Recognition and Trade Request (1971–1975)**

During the offseason, Alcindor and Robertson joined Bucks head coach Larry Costello on a three-week basketball tour of Africa on behalf of the State Department In a press conference at the State Department on June 3, 1971, he stated that going forward he wanted to be called by his Muslim name, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, its translation roughly "noble one, servant of the Almighty" He made the announcement of his name change at a press conference at the State Department on June 3, 1971, saying: "I have decided to change my name to Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, which means 'noble one, servant of the Almighty' I have been thinking about this for a while, and I feel that it is the right thing to do"

Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Jr was born in Harlem, New York City, [17] the only child of Cora Lillian, a department store price checker, and Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Sr., a transit police officer and jazz musician [18] Cora was born in North Carolina but came to Harlem as part of the Great Migration Ferdinand Sr was the child of immigrants from Trinidad; his uncle was the Black activist and medical pioneer Dr John Alcindor [19] [20] [21] Alcindor grew up in the Dyckman Street projects in the Inwood neighborhood of Upper Manhattan, which he moved to at the age of 3 in 1950 [22] At birth, Alcindor weighed 12 lb 11 oz (5.75 kg) and was 22+1⁄2 inches (57 cm) long [23] [24] Always very tall for his age, [23] he was already 5 ft 8 in (1.73 m) by the age of nine [25] Alcindor was often depressed as a teenager because of the stares and comments about his height [23] By the eighth grade (age 13–14), he had grown to 6 ft 8 in (2.03 m) and could already dunk a basketball [25] [26]
