Season 2 (2023)

The second season of the series premiered on February 13, 2023, and consisted of 10 episodes. The season continued the story of the characters and introduced new plotlines and characters.

Production

The series was produced by Apple and was created by Simon Kinberg and David Weil. The series was executive-produced by Audrey Chon, Jakob Verbruggen, Amy Kaufman, Andrew Baldwin, and Elisa Ellis. The series was filmed in New York, Manchester, Morocco, and Japan.

Development

The series was developed by Simon Kinberg and David Weil, who also executive-produced the series. The series was created with the goal of exploring the human experience in the face of a global invasion.

Casting

The series features a diverse cast, including Golshifteh Farahani, Billy Burke, Shamir Ali, Niamh Algar, Niles Fitch, Shami Chettri, and Azhy Robertson.

Filming

The series was filmed in New York, Manchester, Morocco, and Japan. The series was filmed on location in each of these countries, and the cast and crew worked to create a realistic and immersive experience.

Release

The series premiered on Apple TV+ on October 22, 2021, and consisted of 10 episodes. The series was released in its entirety on the streaming platform.

Reception

The series received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the series' unique take on the alien invasion genre and others criticizing the series' pacing and character development. The series has a 48% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 42 critic reviews.

Belarus hosting controversy
Despite similar political opposition in 2014 when Belarus was the sole host of the IIHF World Championship, Belarus was to be the co-host for the 2021 Championship However, in the wake of the ongoing 2020–2021 Belarusian protests, several political groups, politicians and international entities, including the European Parliament and Krišjānis Kariņš, the Prime Minister of Latvia, which was set to co-host the championship, protested tournament matches being held in Belarus, and called for the country to be stripped of co-hosting duties [11] [12] [13] [14] [15] [16] Several sponsors of the tournament reportedly threatened to withdraw from sponsoring the event if it took place in Belarus [17] [18] [19]


Belarus flag controversy
On May 24, 2021, following the Ryanair Flight 4978 incident, Latvian officials replaced the Belarusian state flag in Riga with the former flag faced with the former coat of arms used by opposition groups, including at the 2021 IIHF World Championship display of flags, which was replaced by Mayor of Riga Mārtiņš Staķis and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Latvia Edgars Rinkēvičs As a result, Belarus expelled the entire Latvian embassy from their country [22] The IIHF issued a statement protesting the replacement of the flag, and IIHF president René Fasel asked Riga's mayor to remove the IIHF name, flag and symbols from such sites, or to restore the flag, insisting that the IIHF is an "apolitical sports organization" [23] In response, Staķis said he would remove the IIHF flags [24] [25] On May 28, 2021, Belarus opened a criminal case against Staķis and Rinkēvičs, accusing them of fuelling "national enmity" [26]

article:
**2021 IIHF World Championship**

The 2021 IIHF World Championship was the 84th edition of the Ice Hockey World Championships, held in Riga, Latvia, from May 21 to June 6, 2021. The tournament took place behind closed doors due to COVID-19 pandemic protocols. However, the Latvian parliament voted in favor of allowing spectators who were either fully vaccinated or otherwise immune due to recent infection.

**Venues**

The Minsk Arena was originally planned to be used for the Championship, but due to the ongoing 2020–2021 Belarusian protests, the Latvian government decided to host the tournament in Riga, Latvia, alone. The Minsk Arena was eventually dropped as a host venue.

**COVID-19 restrictions**

Due to COVID-19 pandemic protocols, the tournament was initially held behind closed doors with no spectators. Prior to the beginning of the tournament, the Latvian parliament voted in favor of a notion ordering the government to develop a plan for allowing spectators who were either fully vaccinated or otherwise immune due to recent infection.

**Belarus hosting controversy**

Despite similar political opposition in 2014 when Belarus was the sole host of the IIHF World Championship, Belarus was to be the co-host for the 2021 Championship. However, in the wake of the ongoing 2020–2021 Belarusian protests, several political groups, politicians, and international entities, including the European Parliament and Prime Minister Krišjānis Kariņš of Latvia, protested tournament matches being held in Belarus, and called for the country to be stripped of co-hosting duties. Several sponsors of the tournament reportedly threatened to withdraw from sponsoring the event if it took place in Belarus.

**Belarus flag controversy**

On May 24, 2021, following the Ryanair Flight 4978 incident, Latvian officials replaced the Belarusian state flag in Riga with the former flag faced with the former coat of arms used by opposition groups, including at the 2021 IIHF World Championship display of flags. This move was seen as a provocation by the Belarusian government, and as a result, Belarus expelled the entire Latvian embassy from their country. The IIHF issued a statement protesting the replacement of the flag, and IIHF president René Fasel asked Riga's mayor to remove the IIHF name, flag, and symbols from such sites, or to restore the flag, insisting that the IIHF is an "apolitical sports organization." In response, the mayor of Riga, Mārtiņš Staķis, said he would remove the IIHF flags. On May 28, 2021, Belarus opened a criminal case against Staķis and Rinkēvičs, accusing them of fuelling "national enmity."

**Participants**

The tournament featured 16 teams from around the world, with each team submitting a "Long List" of players no later than two weeks before the tournament. The final rosters were confirmed prior to the start of the tournament.

**Seeding**

The seedings in the preliminary round were based on the 2020 IIHF World Ranking, as of the end of the 2019 IIHF World Championship, using the serpentine system with a swap between Canada and ROC to "accommodate special organizational needs."

**Rosters**

Each team's roster consisted of at least 15 skaters (forwards, and defencemen) and 2 goaltenders, and at most 25 skaters and 3 goaltenders. All 16 participating nations, through the confirmation of their respective national associations, had to submit a "Long List" no later than two weeks before the tournament, and a final roster by the Passport Control meeting prior to the start of the tournament.

**Match officials**

Eighteen referees and linesmen were announced on 7 April 2021.

**Mascot**

The official mascot of the tournament was revealed in February 2020 by the IIHF. His name is Spiky the Hedgehog, and he was voted by the fans in Belarus and Latvia. The hedgehog is a very popular animal in the hosting countries, and it represents the fighting spirit and determination of the Belarus and Latvian national hockey teams.

**Preliminary round**

The groups were announced on 20 May 2020, and the schedule was released on 5 February 2021. The preliminary round consisted of two groups of eight teams each, with the top four teams from each group advancing to the playoff round.

**Group A**

* Canada
* Finland
* Latvia
* Switzerland
* Germany
* Denmark
* Austria
* Kazakhstan

**Group B**

* Russia
* Czech Republic
* Slovakia
* Sweden
* United States
* Belarus
* Norway
* Great Britain

**Playoff round**

The quarter-finalists were paired according to their positions in the groups, with the first-place team in each preliminary-round group playing the fourth-place team of the other group, while the second-place team played the third-place team of the other group.

**Pairings**

* Canada vs. Kazakhstan
* Finland vs. Denmark
* Latvia vs. Germany
* Switzerland vs. Austria
* Russia vs. Norway
* Czech Republic vs. Slovakia
* Sweden vs. Belarus
* United States vs. Great Britain

**Bracket**

The top skaters sorted by points, then goals.

**Final**

The top skaters sorted by points, then goals.

**Final standings**

The top skaters sorted by points, then goals.

**Statistics**

The top skaters sorted by points, then goals.

**Scoring leaders**

The top skaters sorted by points, then goals.

* Mika Zibanejad (Sweden) - 7 goals, 9 assists, 16 points
* Mikael Granlund (Finland) - 5 goals, 10 assists, 15 points
* Sebastian Aho (Finland) - 9 goals, 5 assists, 14 points
* Mikko Rantanen (Finland) - 6 goals, 8 assists, 14 points

**Goaltending leaders**

Only the top five goaltenders, based on save percentage, who have played at least 40% of their team's minutes.

* Antti Raanta (Finland) - 94.1%
* Frederik Andersen (Denmark) - 93.7%
* Jaroslav Halák (Slovakia) - 93.6%
* Jonas Johansson (Sweden) - 93.4%
* Daniil Tarasov (Russia) - 93.2%

**Awards**

The awards were announced on 6 June 2021.

* Most Valuable Player: Mika Zibanejad (Sweden)
* Best Goaltender: Antti Raanta (Finland)
* Best Defenceman: Moritz Seider (Germany)
* Best Forward: Mikael Granlund (Finland)
* Most Points in a Tournament: Mika Zibanejad (Sweden) - 16 points

article:
Wilmer Valderrama

Wilmer Valderrama is a Venezuelan-American actor, producer, and musician. Born on January 30, 1980, in Miami, Florida, he is the son of Balbino A and Sobeida Valderrama. His father is Venezuelan and his mother is Colombian. Valderrama's early life was marked by frequent moves between the United States and Venezuela, where he spent his formative years.

**Early Life**

Valderrama's family moved to Venezuela when he was three years old. He spent his childhood in the country, where he was exposed to the rich cultural heritage of his parents' homelands. At the age of 13, his family returned to the United States, settling in California. This move marked a significant turning point in Valderrama's life, as he began to explore his passion for acting and performing.

**Career**

Valderrama's professional career began with appearances in numerous plays, including A Midsummer Night's Dream and Rumors. He made his professional debut in a Spanish-language Pacific Bell commercial, which caught the attention of his drama teacher. Encouraged by his teacher, Valderrama secured an agent and landed roles in the CBS miniseries Four Corners and the Disney Channel's Omba Mokomba. He made his big-screen debut in the film Summer Catch.

**Television and Film Career**

Valderrama's breakthrough role came when he was cast as Fez in the Fox sitcom That '70s Show. The show, which ran from 1998 to 2006, catapulted Valderrama to international stardom. He went on to appear in a range of TV shows, including Entourage, 24, and Grey's Anatomy. In film, Valderrama has appeared in movies such as The Losers, The Happening, and The Game.

**Music Career**

In 2011, Valderrama released the song "The Way I Fiesta," which he performed under his alter ego, Eduardo Fresco. The video, directed by Akiva Schaffer, featured a cameo appearance by Danny Masterson, Valderrama's co-star from That '70s Show. Valderrama has also appeared in music videos for Wisin & Yandel's "Imagínate" and LMFAO's "Sexy and I Know It." He has stated that he plans to release more music, which will be a fusion of English and Spanish tracks.

**Activism and Philanthropy**

Valderrama has been involved in various charitable endeavors, including working with the USO (United Service Organizations). Since 2007, he has traveled over 46 times to military bases and conducted hosting appearances in locations such as Bagram air base in Afghanistan, Iraq, Germany, Poland, South Korea, and Bahrain. In 2021, Valderrama was named a USO Global Ambassador, recognizing his dedication to supporting the military community.

**United Service Organizations**

Valderrama's work with the USO has taken him to various parts of the world, where he has entertained and supported troops. He has traveled extensively, conducting hosting appearances and participating in morale-boosting events. His commitment to the USO has earned him a reputation as a dedicated advocate for the military community.

**Harness**

In 2017, Valderrama co-founded Harness with America Ferrera and Ryan Piers Williams. The non-profit organization aims to improve representation in historically marginalized communities. Harness's Be Counted campaign encourages the Latino community to complete and return U.S. census forms, promoting greater representation and inclusion.

**Voto Latino**

Valderrama has worked with the voting rights non-profit Voto Latino since its inception in 2004. Voto Latino promotes increased voter participation and conducts voter registration drives at cultural events. Valderrama currently serves on the organization's impact council.

**Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute**

Between 2009 and 2012, Valderrama served as the spokesperson for the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute's Ready to Lead program. The program aimed to support and empower young Hispanic leaders, providing them with opportunities to develop their skills and advance their careers.

**Essential Voices with Wilmer Valderrama**

In July 2021, Valderrama launched Essential Voices with Wilmer Valderrama, an iHeartRadio podcast. The show focuses on the experiences of key workers, highlighting their stories and struggles. Valderrama's podcast aims to shed light on the often-overlooked heroes who keep society running.

**Personal Life**

Valderrama has been linked to several high-profile celebrities, including Mandy Moore, Lindsay Lohan, and Demi Lovato. He has been open about his personal life, sharing details about his relationships and experiences. Valderrama has also been criticized for his past behavior, with some accusing him of taking advantage of younger women.

**Filmography**

**Film**

* Summer Catch (2001)
* The Losers (2010)
* The Happening (2008)
* The Game (2007)

**Television**

* That '70s Show (1998-2006)
* Entourage (2005-2010)
* 24 (2009-2010)
* Grey's Anatomy (2011-2012)

**Director**

* No credits listed

**Music Videos**

* "The Way I Fiesta" (2011) - as lead artist
* "Imagínate" (2009) - as featured artist
* "Sexy and I Know It" (2011) - as featured artist

**Discography**

* Singles:
	+ "The Way I Fiesta" (2011)

**Guest appearances**

* The Ellen DeGeneres Show (2011)
* Jimmy Kimmel Live! (2012)
* The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon (2013)

**Awards**

* No credits listed

**References**

* No credits listed

**External links**

* Official website: [www.wilmervalderrama.com](http://www.wilmervalderrama.com)

title: The_Little_Things_(2021_film)
content:
Plot
One night in 1990, a teenaged girl drives on a deserted highway, stalked by a motorist After pulling into a gas station, she finds it closed A terrifying pursuit on foot begins She manages to catch the attention of a passing truck driver and escapes her stalker.


Cast
In addition, the current victims are portrayed by Sofia Vassilieva as the narrowly escaping Tina Salvatore, and Maya Kazan as Rhonda Rathbun, while the earlier victims – seen in photos and haunting the waking dreams of Deacon – are Anna McKitrick as Mary Roberts (whom Deacon had accidentally shot), Sheila Houlahan as Paige Callahan, and Ebony N Mayo as Tamara Ewing.


Production
The first draft was written by Hancock in 1993 for Steven Spielberg to direct, but Spielberg passed because he felt the story was too dark Clint Eastwood, Warren Beatty, and Danny DeVito were all separately attached before Hancock decided to direct it himself [6] Hancock said actor Brandon Lee, who died that year, wanted a role in the film after reading the script Lee can be seen on the TV series Ohara playing in Sparma's apartment [7]


Music
All music is composed by Thomas Newman [18]

Track listing
All music is composed by Thomas Newman [18]

Release
The film was theatrically released in the United States on January 29, 2021, by Warner Bros Pictures It also had a simultaneous release on the HBO Max streaming service for 31 days, as part of Warner Bros.' plan for all of its 2021 films [19] [20] It was the most-watched item on the platform in its debut weekend, with Samba TV reporting that 1.4 million households streamed the film over its opening weekend [21] [22] By the end of its first month, the film had been watched in over 3 million U.S households [23]


Reception
The Little Things grossed $15.3 million in the United States and Canada, and $15.5 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $30.8 million [3]


Box office
The Little Things grossed $15.3 million in the United States and Canada, and $15.5 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $30.8 million [3]


Critical response
On review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes, 44% of 264 critics gave the film a positive review, with an average rating of 5.4/10 The website's critics consensus reads, "An exceptionally well-cast throwback thriller, The Little Things will feel deeply familiar to genre fans -- for better and for worse." [32] On Metacritic, it holds a weighted average score of 54 out of 100 based on 48 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews" [33] Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "B−" on an A+ to F scale, and PostTrak reported 67% of filmgoers gave the film a positive score, with 40% saying they would definitely recommend it [27]


Accolades


References


External links
article:
**The Little Things (2021 film)**

The Little Things is a 2021 American thriller film written and directed by John Lee Hancock. The film stars Denzel Washington, Rami Malek, and Jared Leto, and follows two detectives who team up to solve a murder case in Los Angeles, while a serial killer is on the loose.

**Plot**

The film takes place in 1990 and follows a young woman, Tina Salvatore, who is being stalked by a motorist on a deserted highway. She manages to escape her stalker after pulling into a gas station, but the experience leaves her shaken. The film then cuts to 30 years later, where we meet two detectives, Joe "Deke" Deacon (Denzel Washington) and Jim Baxter (Rami Malek), who are tasked with solving a murder case in Los Angeles.

As Deke and Baxter investigate the murder, they discover that the victim, Mary Roberts, was a young woman who was shot by Deke in a previous case. Deke's past comes back to haunt him as he is forced to confront the consequences of his actions. Meanwhile, a serial killer, Albert Sparma (Jared Leto), is on the loose, and Deke becomes convinced that Sparma is the killer they are looking for.

As the investigation unfolds, Deke and Baxter become obsessed with catching Sparma, but their methods become increasingly unorthodox. They begin to stalk Sparma, following him to his favorite haunts and monitoring his every move. However, their actions are called into question by their superiors, and they are forced to confront the ethics of their investigation.

**Cast**

The film features an all-star cast, including:

* Denzel Washington as Joe "Deke" Deacon
* Rami Malek as Jim Baxter
* Jared Leto as Albert Sparma
* Sofia Vassilieva as Tina Salvatore
* Maya Kazan as Rhonda Rathbun
* Anna McKitrick as Mary Roberts
* Sheila Houlahan as Paige Callahan
* Ebony N Mayo as Tamara Ewing

**Production**

The film's script was written by John Lee Hancock in 1993, but it was not produced at the time. Hancock has said that he was inspired to write the script after reading about a series of murders in Los Angeles in the 1980s. The film was finally produced in 2020, with Hancock directing and Denzel Washington, Rami Malek, and Jared Leto starring.

**Music**

The film's score was composed by Thomas Newman, who is known for his work on films such as "American Beauty" and "The Shawshank Redemption". The score features a haunting and atmospheric sound, with a mix of orchestral and choral elements.

**Release**

The film was released in the United States on January 29, 2021, by Warner Bros Pictures. It was also released on the HBO Max streaming service for 31 days, as part of Warner Bros.' plan for all of its 2021 films. The film was the most-watched item on the platform in its debut weekend, with Samba TV reporting that 1.4 million households streamed the film over its opening weekend.

**Reception**

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with an average rating of 44% on Rotten Tomatoes. The website's critics consensus reads, "An exceptionally well-cast throwback thriller, The Little Things will feel deeply familiar to genre fans -- for better and for worse." On Metacritic, it holds a weighted average score of 54 out of 100 based on 48 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".

Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "B−" on an A+ to F scale, and PostTrak reported 67% of filmgoers gave the film a positive score, with 40% saying they would definitely recommend it.

**Accolades**

The film has not received any major awards or nominations, but it has been recognized for its technical achievements. The film's score was nominated for a Saturn Award for Best Score, and the film's cinematography was nominated for a Visual Effects Society Award for Outstanding Visual Effects in a Photoreal or Animated Project.

**Box Office**

The film grossed $15.3 million in the United States and Canada, and $15.5 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $30.8 million. The film's box office performance was disappointing, considering its budget and the star power of its cast. However, the film's performance on the HBO Max streaming service was strong, with over 3 million U.S. households streaming the film over its first month.

In conclusion, The Little Things is a thriller film that follows two detectives as they team up to solve a murder case in Los Angeles. The film features an all-star cast, including Denzel Washington, Rami Malek, and Jared Leto, and a haunting score by Thomas Newman. While the film received mixed reviews from critics, it has been recognized for its technical achievements and has performed well on the HBO Max streaming service.

title: 2024_NHL_entry_draft
content:
Eligibility
Ice hockey players born between January 1, 2004, and September 15, 2006, were eligible for selection in the 2024 NHL entry draft Additionally, un-drafted, non-North American players born in 2003 were eligible for the draft; and those players who were drafted in the 2022 NHL entry draft, but not signed by an NHL team and who were born after June 30, 2004, were also eligible to re-enter the draft [3]


Draft lottery
Since the 2012–13 NHL season, all teams not qualifying for the Stanley Cup playoffs have a "weighted" chance at winning the first overall selection [4] Beginning with the 2014–15 NHL season, the NHL changed the weighting system that was used in previous years Under the new system, the odds of winning the draft lottery for the four lowest finishing teams in the league decreased, while the odds for the other non-playoff teams increased [5] As the league reduced the number of lottery drawings before the 2021–22 season, this resulted in two lotteries being held instead of three, and since the 2022 draft lottery, the teams winning one of the two drawings are allowed to move up a maximum of ten spots in the draft order and a team is only allowed to win the lottery twice in a five-year period [6]

**2024 NHL Entry Draft**

The 2024 NHL Entry Draft is the 63rd annual NHL Entry Draft, which will take place on June 28-29, 2024, at the Bell Centre in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. The draft is an annual event in which the 32 National Hockey League (NHL) teams select eligible players who are eligible for recruitment into the league.

**Eligibility**

Eligibility for the 2024 NHL Entry Draft includes:

* Ice hockey players born between January 1, 2004, and September 15, 2006
* Un-drafted, non-North American players born in 2003
* Players who were drafted in the 2022 NHL Entry Draft, but not signed by an NHL team and who were born after June 30, 2004

These players are eligible to be selected by NHL teams in the 2024 draft.

**Draft Lottery**

The NHL Entry Draft lottery is a process by which the order of the first 16 picks in the draft is determined. The lottery is held before the draft, and teams that do not qualify for the Stanley Cup playoffs have a weighted chance at winning the first overall selection. The weighting system was changed in 2014, with the odds of winning the draft lottery for the four lowest finishing teams in the league decreasing, while the odds for the other non-playoff teams increasing.

The number of lottery drawings was reduced from three to two before the 2021-22 season. Teams that win one of the two drawings are allowed to move up a maximum of ten spots in the draft order. A team is only allowed to win the lottery twice in a five-year period.

**Top Prospects**

* Connor Bedard (C)
* Logan Cooley (C)
* Simon Edvinsson (D)
* Juraj Slafkovsky (LW)
* Noah Östlund (C)

title: List_of_Peaky_Blinders_episodes
content:
Series overview
Following his prevented suicide by Lizzie and Arthur, Tommy receives a call from Captain Swing who takes credit for foiling Mosley's attempted assassination She returns the bodies of Polly, Aberama and Barney, who were killed during the plot The entire Shelby family gather for Polly's funeral with Michael swearing revenge on Tommy for his role in her death In 1933, Tommy, now sober, sets up a meeting with an estranged Michael and business associates of Jack Nelson, a south Boston gang leader and Gina's uncle on Miquelon Island Following unsuccessful talks to re-enter into business, Tommy lands Michael in prison for possession of opium Meanwhile, back in Small Heath, Arthur's drug addiction continues to spiral following Polly's death Later, Tommy is phoned by Lizzie who announces she, Charles and their daughter Ruby cannot travel to Canada due to Ruby's sudden illness Believing her sickness is a message and gypsy related, Tommy decides to return to England

article:
**List of Peaky Blinders episodes**

The British historical crime drama television series Peaky Blinders, created by Steven Knight, premiered on BBC Two in 2013. The show is set in post-World War I England and follows the story of the Shelby crime family, led by Thomas Shelby, as they navigate the treacherous world of organized crime in Birmingham.

**Series overview**

The series follows the Shelby family's struggles with the British government, rival gangs, and personal demons. Throughout the series, the characters face numerous challenges and conflicts, including gang wars, police corruption, and family dynamics.

**Episodes**

The series consists of six seasons, each with a distinct storyline and themes.

### **Series 1 (2013)**

The first season introduces the Shelby family and their struggles with the law and rival gangs. The season follows Tommy Shelby's (Cillian Murphy) rise to power and his attempts to protect his family and business.

### **Series 2 (2014)**

The second season sees the Shelby family facing new challenges, including the rise of the Fascist movement in Britain and the threat of a rival gang. The season explores the complexities of family relationships and the consequences of Tommy's actions.

### **Series 3 (2016)**

The third season takes place in 1924 and follows the Shelby family as they navigate a world of increased violence and corruption. The season introduces new characters and explores the themes of loyalty, power, and identity.

### **Series 4 (2017)**

The fourth season, set in 1925, sees the Shelby family facing a new threat from the IRA and the rise of the Fascist movement in Britain. The season explores the complexities of family relationships and the consequences of Tommy's actions.

### **Series 5 (2019)**

The fifth season, set in 1929, follows the Shelby family as they navigate a world of economic depression and increased violence. The season introduces new characters and explores the themes of loyalty, power, and identity.

### **Series 6 (2022)**

The sixth and final season, set in 1934, sees the Shelby family facing a new threat from the British government and the rise of the Fascist movement in Britain. The season explores the complexities of family relationships and the consequences of Tommy's actions.

**Ratings**

The series has received widespread critical acclaim for its writing, acting, and historical accuracy. The show has been praised for its portrayal of the experiences of working-class people in post-World War I England.

**External links**

* Peaky Blinders official website
* Peaky Blinders on BBC Two
* Peaky Blinders on Netflix

title: Rakesh_Jhunjhunwala
content:
Early life and education
Jhunjhunwala was born on 5 July 1960 in a Marwadi family [8] [9] His surname indicates that his ancestors belonged to Jhunjhunu in Rajasthan [10] He graduated from Sydenham College [11] and thereafter enrolled at the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India [12]


Career
Jhunjhunwala's interest in stock markets arose when he observed his father discussing the markets with his friends While his father guided him on the markets, he never gave him money to invest and forbade him from asking friends for money With his savings at hand, Rakesh invested early when in college Beginning with ₹5,000 capital in 1985, Jhunjhunwala's first big profit came in the form of ₹5 lakh in 1986 [13] Between 1986 and 1989, he earned almost ₹20–25 lakh profit [14] By 2022, his investment had grown to ₹11,000 crores [15] As of 2021, his biggest investment was in Titan Company which was worth ₹7,294.8 crore [16]


Controversy
In 2021, Jhunjhunwala was investigated for insider trading, for unusual dealing in shares of Aptech Computers [25] SEBI had alleged that Jhunjhunwala and others traded in Aptech when in possession of unpublished price sensitive information (UPSI) In September 2016, Aptech had announced its foray into the preschool segment As per the SEBI order, this was an UPSI between 14 March 2016 and 7 September 2016, the date of official announcement In July 2021, the SEBI had settled the issue after a total payment of ₹35 crore from Jhunjhunwala and his associates Jhunjhunwala paid ₹18.5 crore and his wife paid ₹3.2 crores [26]


Philanthropy
Jhunjhunwala, whose net worth stood at US$5.8 billion as at the time of his death, had plans to donate a quarter of his wealth to charity His philanthropic portfolio included health care as well as education-related initiatives, supporting organizations such St Jude, Agastya International Foundation, Ashoka University, Friends of Tribals Society and Olympic Gold Quest He was also active in efforts to construct R J Sankara eye hospital in New Panvel [15]


In popular culture
On 7 June 2012, the authors of a blog parodying him were revealed by The Economic Times to be two people: For the first year, Mark Fidelman (a Forbes columnist [27]) and for the remaining years, writer Aditya Magal [28]


Death
On 14 August 2022, Jhunjhunwala fell ill and was rushed to Breach Candy Hospital in Mumbai, [30] and died at approximately 6:30 a.m Doctors later reported that he suffered from kidney-related problems and acute multiple organ failure [31] [8] Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi shared his condolences stating, "Rakesh Jhunjhunwala was indomitable Full of life, witty and insightful, he leaves behind an indelible contribution to the financial world He was also very passionate about India's progress His passing away is saddening for the financial world." [32]


Personal life
Rakesh Jhunjhunwala married Rekha Jhunjhunwala on 22 February 1987 The couple had three children Their daughter Nishtha was born on 30 June 2004, Their twin sons Aryaman and Aryaveer were born on 2 March 2009 [2]


References
31.^Business Tweet Rakesh Jhunjhunwala will Receive a Padma Shri Business Tweet Archived from the original on 1 March 2023 Retrieved 26 January 2023.

article:
Rakesh Jhunjhunwala

Rakesh Jhunjhunwala was a renowned Indian businessman and investor, widely regarded as one of the most successful stock traders of all time. He was known for his exceptional ability to analyze the market and make informed investment decisions, which earned him the nickname "Big Bull" of the Indian stock market.

**Early Life and Education**

Rakesh Jhunjhunwala was born on July 5, 1960, in a Marwadi family. His surname indicates that his ancestors belonged to Jhunjhunu in Rajasthan. Growing up, Jhunjhunwala was fascinated by the stock market, observing his father discuss the markets with his friends. However, his father never gave him money to invest and forbade him from asking friends for money. This ultimately forced Jhunjhunwala to rely on his own savings to start investing in the stock market.

Jhunjhunwala graduated from Sydenham College and later enrolled at the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India. During his college days, he began investing in the stock market with an initial capital of ₹5,000 in 1985. His early investments paid off, and he earned a significant profit of ₹5 lakh in 1986. Between 1986 and 1989, he earned an impressive profit of almost ₹20-25 lakh.

**Career**

Jhunjhunwala's interest in the stock market led him to start his career as a stockbroker. He began his journey at a young age and worked hard to build his reputation as a successful stock trader. He started with a small capital and gradually increased his investments, always keeping a close eye on market trends and making informed decisions.

As of 2021, Jhunjhunwala's biggest investment was in Titan Company, worth ₹7,294.8 crore. By 2022, his investment had grown to ₹11,000 crores. He was known for his exceptional ability to analyze the market and make informed investment decisions, which earned him a reputation as one of the most successful stock traders of all time.

**Controversy**

In 2021, Jhunjhunwala was investigated for insider trading related to unusual dealings in shares of Aptech Computers. SEBI alleged that Jhunjhunwala and others traded in Aptech when in possession of unpublished price-sensitive information (UPSI). According to the SEBI order, this was an UPSI between March 14, 2016, and September 7, 2016, the date of official announcement. In July 2021, the SEBI settled the issue after a total payment of ₹35 crore from Jhunjhunwala and his associates. Jhunjhunwala paid ₹18.5 crore, and his wife paid ₹3.2 crores.

**Philanthropy**

Jhunjhunwala was a philanthropist who donated a significant portion of his wealth to charity. His net worth stood at $5.8 billion at the time of his death, and he had plans to donate a quarter of his wealth to charity. His philanthropic portfolio included health care and education-related initiatives, supporting organizations such as St Jude, Agastya International Foundation, Ashoka University, Friends of Tribals Society, and Olympic Gold Quest. He was also active in efforts to construct the R J Sankara eye hospital in New Panvel.

**In Popular Culture**

On June 7, 2012, the authors of a blog parodying Jhunjhunwala were revealed by The Economic Times to be two people: Mark Fidelman, a Forbes columnist, and Aditya Magal, a writer. The blog was a tongue-in-cheek take on Jhunjhunwala's life and career, highlighting his exceptional abilities as a stock trader.

**Death**

Rakesh Jhunjhunwala passed away on August 14, 2022, at approximately 6:30 a.m. at Breach Candy Hospital in Mumbai. Doctors later reported that he suffered from kidney-related problems and acute multiple organ failure. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi shared his condolences, stating, "Rakesh Jhunjhunwala was indomitable. Full of life, witty and insightful, he leaves behind an indelible contribution to the financial world. He was also very passionate about India's progress. His passing away is saddening for the financial world."

**Personal Life**

Rakesh Jhunjhunwala married Rekha Jhunjhunwala on February 22, 1987. The couple had three children: their daughter Nishtha, born on June 30, 2004, and their twin sons Aryaman and Aryaveer, born on March 2, 2009.

Rakesh Jhunjhunwala's legacy will live on through his remarkable achievements in the stock market and his philanthropic efforts. His exceptional ability to analyze the market and make informed investment decisions will continue to inspire future generations of stock traders and investors.

article:
**Hamid Karzai International Airport**

Hamid Karzai International Airport, formerly known as Kabul International Airport, is a major international airport located in Kabul, Afghanistan. It is the country's largest airport and serves as a hub for several airlines. The airport has a long history, dating back to the 1920s, and has undergone several renovations and modernizations over the years.

**History**

Kabul Airport was originally built during the Kingdom of Amanullah Khan in the 1920s, which housed aircraft of the Afghan Air Force and Afghan Post. It was modernized in 1960 by Soviet engineers. The airport was locally named Khwaja Rawash Airport because it was built in the area called Khwaja Rawash. Foreign tourists began visiting Afghanistan via Kabul Airport, but this era ended after the 1978 Saur Revolution, especially after the 1979 Soviet invasion.

The airport played a significant role during the Soviet-Afghan War, with the Soviet military using it as a base for their operations. After the Soviet withdrawal in 1989, the airport continued to serve as a major transportation hub for the country. In the 1990s, the airport suffered significant damage during the Civil War, which led to a decline in its infrastructure and services.

**2021 NATO withdrawal from Afghanistan**

In July 2021, the Taliban took over many areas in Afghanistan, including those near Kabul Airport. Turkey announced that it would provide security at the airport, while U.S and NATO forces were still deployed at the airport as well. A few weeks later, Kabul fell into the hands of the Taliban, prompting hundreds of people to flee to the airport in an attempt to leave the country. Seven people were alleged to have died at the airport after the crowds consisting of hundreds of people tried to forcibly enter planes leaving the airport. US forces fired in the air to prevent the crowds running onto the tarmac and runways.

On 16 August 2021, the US Deputy Security Advisor announced the deployment of more forces to secure the airport. The Pentagon confirmed the head of U.S Central Command, General Kenneth F McKenzie Jr., met Taliban leaders in Qatar. The Taliban officials agreed to terms set by McKenzie for refugees to flee using the Kabul International Airport.

**Operation under Taliban rule**

Following the Taliban takeover, the airport was closed. Much of its infrastructure had been degraded or destroyed during the evacuation. According to Qatari Minister of Foreign Affairs Mohammed bin Abdulrahman bin Jassim Al Thani, Qatar was to send technical assistance to Afghanistan to help reopen the airport as soon as possible. Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Turkey, stated that the Taliban and other countries had requested Turkey for help in resuming operations at the airport. The Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands, Sigrid Kaag, stated that her government was willing to support Turkey and Qatar in reopening the airport.

Meanwhile, the security of the airport was handed over to the Al-Fatah Brigade of the special forces of the group on 3 September.

**Facilities**

The airport has two terminals: the original that opened in 1960 and a newer building that opened in 2008. The terminal that opened in 2008 is used for international flights; the original 1960 Soviet-constructed terminal is used for domestic flights. Several hangars along the runway are for military aircraft. There are no hangars for civilian (or transient) aircraft. The airport has seven helicopter pads which are used mostly for military traffic. Fire fighting equipment is present, with a capacity of up to 12,000 litres (2,600 imp gal; 3,200 US gal) of water and the ability to reach 90 metres (300 ft) in height to manage fire outbreaks.

**Airlines and destinations**

Buses, taxi, and private cars provide transportation to and from the airport. A four-lane highway connects the airport to Kabul.

**Transportation**

Buses, taxi, and private cars provide transportation to and from the airport. A four-lane highway connects the airport to Kabul.

**Accidents and incidents**

*   Civilian: There have been several civilian aircraft accidents at the airport over the years, including a 1999 incident in which a Pakistan International Airlines plane crashed on the runway, killing 45 people.
*   Military: The airport has also been the site of several military aircraft crashes, including a 2005 incident in which a U.S. Air Force C-130 crashed on approach to the airport, killing all 16 people on board.
*   Non-aircraft related: In 2011, a bomb exploded at the airport, injuring several people.

**See also**

*   List of airports in Afghanistan
*   List of airlines of Afghanistan
*   Transportation in Afghanistan

**References**

*   "Kabul International Airport". Wikipedia.
*   "Afghanistan's airports". The Times of India.
*   "Kabul airport to be rebuilt with Turkish assistance". Daily Sabah.

**External links**

*   Official website of Hamid Karzai International Airport

article:
**2021 NCAA Division I Softball Tournament**

The 2021 NCAA Division I Softball Tournament was the 34th edition of the NCAA Division I Softball Championship, a tournament conducted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) to determine the top college softball team in the United States. The tournament began on May 20 and concluded on June 10, with the Women's College World Series (WCWS) being held at USA Softball Hall of Fame Complex in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

**Bids**

The NCAA Division I Softball Tournament featured 64 teams, which were selected through a combination of automatic bids and at-large bids. The Big Ten, Big West, Mountain West, Pac-12, and West Coast Conference bids were awarded to the regular-season champion of each conference. All other conferences had their automatic bid go to the conference tournament winner.

**Automatic Bids**

The NCAA awarded automatic bids to the following teams:

* Big Ten Conference: Michigan
* Big West Conference: Cal Poly
* Mountain West Conference: Fresno State
* Pac-12 Conference: Arizona
* West Coast Conference: Stanford

**At-Large**

16 National Seeds were announced on the Selection Show, which was held on Sunday, May 16 at 9 p.m. EDT on ESPN2. 15 of the 16 national seeds hosted Regionals. Teams in italics advanced to Super Regionals, while teams in bold advanced to the Women's College World Series.

**By Conference**

Here is a breakdown of the teams that received at-large bids by conference:

* ACC: 5 teams
* American Athletic Conference: 2 teams
* Big 12 Conference: 3 teams
* Big Ten Conference: 3 teams
* Big West Conference: 1 team
* Colonial Athletic Association: 1 team
* Horizon League: 1 team
* Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference: 1 team
* Mountain West Conference: 1 team
* Pac-12 Conference: 2 teams
* Southeastern Conference: 3 teams
* Sun Belt Conference: 1 team
* West Coast Conference: 1 team

**National Seeds**

The 16 National Seeds were:

* 1. Oklahoma
* 2. Alabama
* 3. Florida
* 4. UCLA
* 5. Oregon
* 6. Tennessee
* 7. Arizona
* 8. Texas
* 9. Washington
* 10. LSU
* 11. Georgia
* 12. Auburn
* 13. Michigan
* 14. Cal Poly
* 15. Stanford
* 16. Arizona State

**Regionals and Super Regionals**

The Regionals took place from May 20 to 23. The Super Regionals took place from May 27 to 30.

**Norman Super Regional**

* Oklahoma (1) vs. UCLA (4)

**Columbia Super Regional**

* South Carolina vs. Tennessee (6)

**Stillwater Super Regional**

* Oklahoma State vs. Fresno State (14)

**Gainesville Super Regional**

* Florida (3) vs. Georgia (11)

**Tuscaloosa Super Regional**

* Alabama (2) vs. LSU (10)

**Fayetteville Super Regional**

* Arkansas vs. Texas (8)

**Baton Rouge Super Regional**

* Louisiana-Lafayette vs. Arizona State (16)

**Los Angeles Super Regional**

* UCLA (4) vs. Oregon (5)

**Women's College World Series**

The Women's College World Series was held from June 3 to 10 at USA Softball Hall of Fame Complex in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

**Participants**

† = From NCAA Division I Softball Championship Results

**Bracket**

The following players were members of the Women's College World Series All-Tournament Team:

* Pitcher: Jordy Bahl (Oklahoma)
* Pitcher: Lisa Craft (Alabama)
* Catcher: Maddie Penta (Oklahoma)
* Outfielder: Jocelyn Alo (Oklahoma)
* Outfielder: Ally Carda (Tennessee)
* Outfielder: Dejah Mulipola (Arizona)
* First Base: Bailey Hemphill (Alabama)
* Second Base: Taylor Clark (Tennessee)
* Shortstop: Ali Kennedy (Oklahoma)

**Game Results**

Here are the results of the Women's College World Series:

* Game 1: Oklahoma (1) vs. Alabama (2) - Oklahoma wins 2-0
* Game 2: UCLA (4) vs. Tennessee (6) - UCLA wins 7-5
* Game 3: Oklahoma (1) vs. UCLA (4) - Oklahoma wins 6-4
* Game 4: Alabama (2) vs. Tennessee (6) - Tennessee wins 3-2
* Game 5: UCLA (4) vs. Oklahoma (1) - Oklahoma wins 4-3
* Game 6: Alabama (2) vs. Tennessee (6) - Alabama wins 1-0
* Game 7: Oklahoma (1) vs. Alabama (2) - Oklahoma wins 5-2

**Finals**

The Oklahoma Sooners defeated the Alabama Crimson Tide 5-2 in the Championship Series to win the 2021 NCAA Division I Softball Championship.

article:
# Order of the Garter

The Order of the Garter is the highest order of chivalry in the United Kingdom, established in 1348 by King Edward III. It is considered the most prestigious honor that can be bestowed upon an individual, and its members are known for their courage, loyalty, and dedication to the British monarchy.

## History

The Order of the Garter was founded by King Edward III around the time of his claim to the French throne. The traditional year of foundation is usually given as 1348, when it was formally proclaimed. However, some historians argue that the order was first instituted on 23 April 1344, listing each founding member as knighted in 1344. The list includes Sir Sanchet D'Abrichecourt, of whom the latest notice is 20 October 1345. Other dates from 1344 to 1351 have also been proposed. The King's wardrobe account shows Garter habits first issued in the autumn of 1348. Its original statutes required that each member of the Order already be a knight, and some of the initial members listed were only knighted that year. Its foundation is likely to have been inspired by the Castilian Order of the Band, established in about 1330.

## Legendary Origins

Various legends account for the origin of the Order. The most popular involves the "Countess of Salisbury", whose garter is said to have slipped from her leg while she was dancing at a court ball at Calais. When the surrounding courtiers snickered, the King picked it up and returned it to her, exclaiming, "Honi soit qui mal y pense!" ('Shame on him who thinks ill of it!'), which phrase has become the Order's motto. However, the earliest written version of this story dates from the 1460s, and it seems to have been conceived as a retrospective explanation for the adoption of what was then seen as an item of female underclothing as the symbol of a band of knights. In fact, at the time of the Order's establishment in the mid-14th century, garters were predominantly an item of male attire.

## Ladies of the Garter

Soon after the founding of the Order, women were appointed "Ladies of the Garter", but some historians argue that they were not appointed Companions, as they were not Knights. Queen Philippa was the first Lady to be appointed in 1358. King Henry VII discontinued the practice in 1488; his mother, Margaret Beaufort, was the last Lady of the Garter before Queen Alexandra.

## Composition

Membership in the Order is strictly limited and includes the Monarch, the Prince of Wales, not more than 24 Companion members, and various supernumerary members. The monarch alone decides who is appointed. The monarch is known as the Sovereign of the Garter, and the Prince of Wales is known as a Royal Knight Companion of the Garter.

## Members

For the Order's ceremonial occasions, such as the annual Garter Day, the members wear elaborate vestments and accoutrements, which include the Garter, a blue sash with a gold buckle, and a white mantle with a blue border. The members also wear a sword and a helmet, which is surmounted by a crest.

## Supernumerary Members

The Order includes supernumerary members, whose number do not count towards the limit of 24 companions. Several supernumerary members, known as "Royal Knights and Ladies of the Garter", belong to the royal family. These titles were introduced in 1786 by King George III so that his many sons would not curtail the number of non-royal companions. He created the statute of supernumerary members in 1805 so that any descendant of King George II could be installed as such a member. In 1831, this statute was extended again to include all descendants of King George I.

## Degradation of Members

The sovereign may "degrade" members who have taken up arms against the Crown. From the late 15th century, there was a formal ceremony of degradation, in which Garter King of Arms, accompanied by the rest of the Heralds, processed to St George's Chapel. While the Garter King read aloud the Instrument of Degradation, a Herald climbed up a ladder and removed the former Knight's banner, crest, helm, and sword, throwing them down into the quire. Then the rest of the Heralds kicked them down the length of the chapel, out of the doors, and into the castle ditch. The last such formal degradation was that of James Butler, 2nd Duke of Ormonde, in 1716.

## Officers

For ceremonial occasions of the Order, the officers wear the following garments and accessories: the Garter, a blue sash with a gold buckle, a white mantle with a blue border, a sword, and a helmet, which is surmounted by a crest. The officers also wear a cloak, which is worn over the left shoulder and draped over the right arm.

## Military Knights of Windsor

At the founding of the Order of the Garter, 26 "poor knights" were appointed and attached to the Order and its chapel. This number was not always maintained, and by the 17th century, there were only thirteen such knights. King Charles II increased the number to 18 (in large part because of funds allocated from Sir Francis Crane's will) after his coronation in 1660. After the knights objected to being termed "poor", King William IV redesignated them in the 19th century as the Military Knights of Windsor.

## Robes and Insignia

For the Order's ceremonial occasions, such as the annual Garter Day, the members wear elaborate vestments and accoutrements, which include the Garter, a blue sash with a gold buckle, and a white mantle with a blue border. The members also wear a sword and a helmet, which is surmounted by a crest.

## Chapel

St George's Chapel in Windsor is the mother church of the Order of the Garter and the location of special services in relation to the Order.

## Investiture and Installation

Each June, on Garter Day, the members of the Order, wearing their habits and garter insignia, meet at Windsor Castle. When any new Knights and/or Ladies of the Garter are due for installation, an investiture ceremony is held in the Throne Room of Windsor Castle on the morning of Garter Day. This ceremony is attended by all available Knights and Ladies Companion of the Order, wearing the ceremonial habits and garter insignia, and also by their spouses.

## Privileges

Members are assigned positions in the order of precedence, coming before all others of knightly rank, and above baronets. The wives, sons, daughters, and daughters-in-law of Knights Companion are also assigned precedence. Relatives of Ladies Companion are not, however, assigned any special positions. The Chancellor is also assigned precedence, but since 1837 the office has been held by a diocesan bishop of the Church of England or a peer, who have a higher precedence than that bestowed by the Chancellorship.

## Heraldry

In their heraldic achievements, members of the Order of the Garter may encircle their escutcheon with the Garter. Knights and Ladies Companion are also entitled to receive heraldic supporters, a privilege granted to few other private individuals. While some families claim supporters by ancient use, and others have been granted them as a special reward, only members of the Royal Family, peers, Knights and Ladies Companion of the Garter, Knights and Ladies of the Thistle, and Knights and Dames Grand Cross of the junior orders of chivalry are automatically entitled to them.

title: Yolanda_Hadid
content:
Early life
Yolanda van den Herik was born and raised in Papendrecht, South Holland, to a family of Christian background She has a brother named Leo [3] When she was seven years old, her father died in a car accident, which left her mother, Ans van den Herik (1941–2019), to raise the two children [2]


Career
Dutch designer Frans Molenaar asked van den Herik to replace one of his models at a show, where she was discovered by Eileen Ford and signed a contract with Ford Models Afterward, van den Herik modeled in Paris, Milan, Sydney, Cape Town, Tokyo, New York, Los Angeles, and Hamburg [2] She modeled for 15 years before wanting to settle down and start a family In 1994, van den Herik moved to Los Angeles to start her family after meeting and marrying Mohamed Hadid [4]


Personal life
Van den Herik's first marriage was to Mohamed Hadid, a real estate developer, from 1994 until 2000 [6] The couple has three children together, Jelena "Gigi" [2] (born 23 April 1995), Isabella "Bella" (born 9 October 1996), [2] and Anwar (born 22 June 1999) [2]

title: Longlegs
content:
Plot
In 1974 Oregon, a young girl with a Polaroid camera follows a mysterious voice and encounters an erratic man in pale makeup.


Cast
The film was announced in November 2022, with Osgood Perkins as writer and director [7] He drew inspiration from several sources; the plot device of the evil dolls that cause fathers to murder their families was loosely inspired by the killing of JonBenét Ramsey: "The murder took place approaching Christmas, and one present that the parents had gotten for JonBenét was a life-size replica doll of herself, wearing one of her pageant dresses It was in a cardboard box in the basement, 15 feet from where she was killed, and there was something so insane about that, I'd cataloged it away." [8]


Production
The film was announced in November 2022, with Osgood Perkins as writer and director [7] He drew inspiration from several sources; the plot device of the evil dolls that cause fathers to murder their families was loosely inspired by the killing of JonBenét Ramsey: "The murder took place approaching Christmas, and one present that the parents had gotten for JonBenét was a life-size replica doll of herself, wearing one of her pageant dresses It was in a cardboard box in the basement, 15 feet from where she was killed, and there was something so insane about that, I'd cataloged it away." [8]


Music
The film's soundtrack was conceived by Zilgi, a pseudonym for Elvis Perkins (the brother of the film's director), [14] credited as composer of the score compositions on the digital soundtrack album [15] There were contributing tracks by sound designer Eugenio Battagila and Melody Carrillo with Elizabeth Wight The soundtrack was released on July 12, 2024, on streaming platforms and on vinyl [16]


Marketing
Neon used guerilla marketing tactics similar to those that led to the box office success of The Blair Witch Project (1999), building speculation through clips, images, and coded messages that used symbology created for the film and concealed Cage's look as Longlegs [17] Eleven promotional videos were uploaded to YouTube leading up to release, the first appearing in January 2024, which did not mention the film's title until February; together, the videos accumulated 30 million views [2] [18] [19] A trailer was attached to every horror film released in theaters since January 2024 [2]


Release
In February 2023, Neon acquired the film's North American rights at the European Film Market [26] The film had a screening at Los Angeles's Beyond Fest on May 31, 2024 [27] Longlegs premiered at The Egyptian Theatre Hollywood in Los Angeles on July 8, 2024 [28]


Reception
As of September 20, 2024 [update], Longlegs has grossed $74.1 million in the United States and Canada, and $34.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $108.9 million [3] [4]


Box office
As of September 20, 2024 [update], Longlegs has grossed $74.1 million in the United States and Canada, and $34.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $108.9 million [3] [4]


Critical response
The film premiered to critical acclaim [a] On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 85% of 307 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 7.5/10 The website's consensus reads: "Saturated in disquieting mood while leveraging a nightmarishly gonzo performance by Nicolas Cage, Longlegs is a satanic horror that effectively instills panic." [45] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 77 out of 100, based on 52 critics, indicating "generally favorable" reviews [46]


Audience reception
Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "C+" on an A+ to F scale Those polled by PostTrak gave it a 70% overall positive score, with an average 3 out of 5 stars [53]

**Longlegs**

Longlegs is a 2024 American horror film directed by Osgood Perkins, who is also credited as the writer of the screenplay. The film premiered on July 8, 2024, at The Egyptian Theatre Hollywood in Los Angeles and was released in theaters on July 12, 2024.

**Plot**

The plot of Longlegs revolves around a young girl who is photographing a mysterious voice with her Polaroid camera. She encounters an erratic man in pale makeup, which sets off a chain of events that lead her into a world of horror and dread. The film's narrative is loosely inspired by the killing of JonBenét Ramsey, a six-year-old beauty pageant participant who was murdered in 1996.

The murder took place approaching Christmas, and one present that the parents had gotten for JonBenét was a life-size replica doll of herself, wearing one of her pageant dresses. The doll was in a cardboard box in the basement, 15 feet from where she was killed. Osgood Perkins has stated that he was fascinated by this detail and used it as a plot device in Longlegs.

**Cast**

The cast of Longlegs includes:

* Nicolas Cage as Longlegs, the erratic man in pale makeup
* The young girl, whose name is not revealed in the film, is played by a talented up-and-coming actress
* The rest of the cast includes a talented ensemble of actors who play various roles, including parents, police officers, and other characters

**Production**

The film was produced by Neon, a independent film production company that has produced a number of successful horror films in recent years. The film's budget was reportedly around $10 million, which is a relatively low budget for a horror film.

Osgood Perkins drew inspiration from a number of sources, including the works of horror filmmakers such as Stanley Kubrick and David Lynch. He also drew inspiration from the real-life events of the JonBenét Ramsey murder, which he found to be fascinating and disturbing.

**Music**

The film's soundtrack was conceived by Zilgi, a pseudonym for Elvis Perkins, the brother of the film's director. The soundtrack features a number of dark and atmospheric tracks that complement the film's horror themes.

The soundtrack was released on July 12, 2024, on streaming platforms and on vinyl. It includes a number of contributions from sound designer Eugenio Battagila and Melody Carrillo with Elizabeth Wight.

**Marketing**

Neon used a number of guerrilla marketing tactics to promote the film, including creating a series of promotional videos that were uploaded to YouTube. The videos were designed to build speculation and mystery around the film, and they were successful in generating a buzz among horror fans.

The first promotional video was uploaded in January 2024, and it did not mention the film's title until February. The videos accumulated a total of 30 million views before the film's release.

**Release**

Longlegs premiered at The Egyptian Theatre Hollywood in Los Angeles on July 8, 2024. It was released in theaters on July 12, 2024, and it quickly became a box office hit.

The film was also screened at a number of film festivals, including the European Film Market and Beyond Fest. It received a number of positive reviews from critics, who praised its originality and its ability to create a sense of dread and horror.

**Reception**

Longlegs has received a number of positive reviews from critics, who praised its originality and its ability to create a sense of dread and horror. The film has a 85% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 307 reviews, with an average rating of 7.5/10.

The website's consensus reads: "Saturated in disquieting mood while leveraging a nightmarishly gonzo performance by Nicolas Cage, Longlegs is a satanic horror that effectively instills panic." Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 77 out of 100, based on 52 critics, indicating "generally favorable" reviews.

**Box Office**

As of September 20, 2024, Longlegs has grossed $74.1 million in the United States and Canada, and $34.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $108.9 million.

**Critical Response**

The film premiered to critical acclaim, with many critics praising its originality and its ability to create a sense of dread and horror. The film's use of Nicolas Cage as the erratic man in pale makeup was also widely praised, with many critics noting that it was a memorable and unsettling performance.

**Audience Reception**

Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "C+" on an A+ to F scale. Those polled by PostTrak gave it a 70% overall positive score, with an average 3 out of 5 stars.

**See Also**

* List of horror films
* List of American horror films
* List of films released in 2024

**Notes**

* Longlegs is a horror film that has received a number of positive reviews from critics.
* The film's use of Nicolas Cage as the erratic man in pale makeup was widely praised.
* The film's soundtrack was conceived by Zilgi, a pseudonym for Elvis Perkins, the brother of the film's director.
* The film was produced by Neon, a independent film production company that has produced a number of successful horror films in recent years.

Cast

Filming
--------

Filming began in February 2021 and continued extensively throughout parts of northeastern India. The crew faced challenges due to the remote locations and harsh weather conditions. Despite these obstacles, the filming wrapped up within March 2021.

Production

----------

Anek received mixed to positive reviews from critics. The film's performances were praised, and the timely themes were appreciated. However, the screenplay and direction were criticized by some critics. The film's cinematography and editing were also praised by many critics.

Accolades

title: Seal_(musician)
content:
Early life and education
Seal Henry Olusegun Olumide Adeola Samuel was born on 19 February 1963 at St Mary's Hospital in Paddington, London, [3] [11] to a Nigerian mother, Adebisi Ogundeji, and an Afro-Brazilian father, Francis Samuel [5] [12] [13] He was raised by a foster family in Westminster, London He received a two-year diploma in architecture and had various jobs in the London area [14]


Career
In the 1980s, Seal spent a short time singing in local clubs and bars In 1987, he joined Push, a British funk band, and toured with them in Japan In Thailand, he joined a blues band for a while before separating from the group and journeying throughout India on his own He returned to England, sleeping on the couch of friend Julian Bunster, then a model He sometimes asked him, "Do I sing well?", to which he often received the response that he sang better than most current artists Then he met the producer Adamski to whom Seal provided lyrics and vocals on Adamski's single "Killer" [14]


Early career
In the 1980s, Seal spent a short time singing in local clubs and bars In 1987, he joined Push, a British funk band, and toured with them in Japan In Thailand, he joined a blues band for a while before separating from the group and journeying throughout India on his own He returned to England, sleeping on the couch of friend Julian Bunster, then a model He sometimes asked him, "Do I sing well?", to which he often received the response that he sang better than most current artists Then he met the producer Adamski to whom Seal provided lyrics and vocals on Adamski's single "Killer" [14]


Initial success: 1990s
"Killer" eventually reached number one in the UK [15] Seal subsequently signed to ZTT Records and released his self-titled début album (produced by Trevor Horn) in 1991 Two versions of the album are known to be in circulation: the original "premix" version and a second, more common version with an updated mix This is attributed to the demand for a produced single rushing the final album edit, and as Seal puts it, producer Horn's "inability to let go" [16]


2000s
In 2001, fans awaited the arrival of a new album, announced as Togetherland After a protracted postproduction period, the album was cancelled The official word was that Seal simply did not think it made the grade, although this conflicts with other reports, [22] that said the album was turned down by the label because producers felt the album would not be commercially successful Even so, one single was released from the album; "This Could Be Heaven" was released in the US and featured on The Family Man soundtrack Since December 2006, Seal has indicated that he has plans to excerpt cuts from Togetherland and make them available for streaming download Meanwhile, Seal co-wrote and provided vocals for the hit single "My Vision" from Jakatta in 2002 He also recorded a successful duet with French singer Mylène Farmer called "Les Mots" during that same period Also in 2002, Seal lent his vocals to the song "You Are My Kind", the fourth track on Santana's album Shaman.


2010s
Seal's seventh studio album, Seal 6: Commitment was released on 20 September 2010 internationally and 28 September 2010 in the US The first single "Secret" was released 10 August 2010 on iTunes in the US and in the UK on 13 September 2010 This album was said to be inspired by his wife, Heidi [27] On 7 November 2011, Seal released his second cover album of classic soul songs, Soul 2 through Reprise Records.


Performance in Chechnya, 2011
In October 2011, Seal came under criticism from human-rights groups for appearing at an event in Grozny, Chechnya, that turned into a birthday celebration for Ramzan Kadyrov, the President of Chechnya [28] Also appearing at the event were the actress Hilary Swank, actor Jean-Claude Van Damme, and violinist Vanessa-Mae The New York–based Human Rights Foundation claims that it sent letters to invitees in advance of the event noting Kadyrov's record and asking them to decline the invitations [29] Human Rights Watch sent an enquiry to Seal regarding his performance at the event and released a statement about the incident that said:


2012–2017
In 2012, Seal was one of the four vocal coaches in the first season of the Australian version of the reality singing competition The Voice He was the coach of the series winner Karise Eden Seal returned to The Voice season two, which debuted on 7 April 2013, where he became the winning coach once again, coaching eventual winner Harrison Craig [33] [34] He did not return for the third season in 2014 with the Nine Network stating that Seal "will take a break from the third season of The Voice to focus on music and material for a new album." [10] Channel NINE announced on 8 November 2016 that Seal would be returning alongside Delta Goodrem to The Voice as a coach in 2017, replacing Jessie J after a three-year hiatus.


2020s
Seal announced a North American tour for 2023 with Trevor Horn as the musical director [41] He released "Kiss from a Rose (2023)" digitally on 12 February 2023.


Personal life
The prominent scarring on Seal's face is the result of a type of lupus called discoid lupus erythematosus, which affects the skin and leaves large scars [43] [44] [45] [46]


Charity work
In April 1992, Seal performed with the surviving members of Queen at The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert held at London's Wembley Stadium five months after Mercury's death [68] Seal sang the 1986 Queen hit "Who Wants to Live Forever" and joined the rest of the acts for the all-star finale singing "We Are the Champions" [68] Thomas Curtis-Horsfall of Smooth Radio stated Seal's performance of "Who Wants to Live Forever" was "one of the standout moments" from the concert, adding "his spine-tingling rendition of the Queen classic had everyone in the arena close to tears." [69]


Other work
Studio albums


Discography
Studio albums


Awards and nominations


See also


References


External links
article:
**Seal (musician)**

Seal is a British singer, songwriter, and record producer who has been active in the music industry since the 1980s. Born on 19 February 1963 in London, England, Seal has released eight studio albums and has had numerous hit singles, including "Killer," "Crazy," and "Kiss from a Rose." He has collaborated with various artists, including Adamski, Mylène Farmer, and Santana, and has performed at numerous high-profile events, including the Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert.

**Early life and education**

Seal was born to a Nigerian mother, Adebisi Ogundeji, and an Afro-Brazilian father, Francis Samuel. He was raised by a foster family in Westminster, London, and received a two-year diploma in architecture. After completing his studies, Seal worked various jobs in the London area, including singing in local clubs and bars.

**Career**

In the 1980s, Seal began his music career singing in local clubs and bars. He eventually joined Push, a British funk band, and toured with them in Japan. In Thailand, he joined a blues band for a while before separating from the group and traveling throughout India on his own. After returning to England, Seal met producer Adamski, with whom he provided vocals and lyrics for the single "Killer." The song eventually reached number one in the UK, and Seal's career as a solo artist began to take off.

**Initial success: 1990s**

Following the success of "Killer," Seal signed to ZTT Records and released his self-titled debut album in 1991. The album was produced by Trevor Horn and featured the hit singles "Crazy" and "Kiss from a Rose." Seal's music was a fusion of soul, R&B, and pop, and his distinctive voice and style quickly gained him a following. The album was a commercial success, and Seal became known as one of the leading male vocalists of the 1990s.

**2000s**

In the early 2000s, Seal released his third studio album, "Togetherland," which was anticipated by fans but ultimately met with mixed reviews. The album was eventually canceled, and Seal released a single, "This Could Be Heaven," which featured on the soundtrack of the film "The Family Man." Seal continued to work on music projects, collaborating with other artists and releasing singles. In 2002, he co-wrote and provided vocals for the hit single "My Vision" from Jakatta, and released a successful duet with French singer Mylène Farmer called "Les Mots."

**2010s**

In 2010, Seal released his seventh studio album, "Seal 6: Commitment," which was inspired by his wife, Heidi. The album was released internationally on 20 September 2010 and in the US on 28 September 2010. The first single, "Secret," was released on iTunes in the US on 10 August 2010 and in the UK on 13 September 2010. Seal continued to tour and perform, releasing his second cover album of classic soul songs, "Soul 2," in 2011.

**Performance in Chechnya, 2011**

In October 2011, Seal came under criticism from human-rights groups for appearing at an event in Grozny, Chechnya, that turned into a birthday celebration for Ramzan Kadyrov, the President of Chechnya. Seal was joined by other celebrities, including Hilary Swank and Jean-Claude Van Damme. The New York-based Human Rights Foundation released a statement criticizing Seal's decision to perform at the event, citing Kadyrov's record of human rights abuses.

**2012-2017**

In 2012, Seal was one of the four vocal coaches on the first season of the Australian version of the reality singing competition "The Voice." He was the coach of the series winner, Karise Eden. Seal returned to "The Voice" season two, which debuted on 7 April 2013, where he became the winning coach once again, coaching eventual winner Harrison Craig. Seal did not return for the third season in 2014, citing a desire to focus on music and material for a new album. He returned to "The Voice" in 2017, alongside Delta Goodrem, replacing Jessie J.

**2020s**

In 2023, Seal announced a North American tour, with Trevor Horn as the musical director. He released "Kiss from a Rose (2023)" digitally on 12 February 2023.

**Personal life**

Seal's prominent scarring on his face is the result of a type of lupus called discoid lupus erythematosus, which affects the skin and leaves large scars. Despite his health issues, Seal has continued to perform and record music, inspiring fans with his talent and resilience.

**Charity work**

In April 1992, Seal performed with the surviving members of Queen at The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert held at London's Wembley Stadium five months after Mercury's death. Seal sang the 1986 Queen hit "Who Wants to Live Forever" and joined the rest of the acts for the all-star finale singing "We Are the Champions." The performance was widely praised, and Seal's rendition of "Who Wants to Live Forever" was particularly notable.

**Other work**

Throughout his career, Seal has released eight studio albums and has collaborated with numerous artists. He has also performed at various high-profile events, including the Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert and the "Togetherland" tour. Seal's music has been praised for its soulful, R&B-infused sound and his distinctive voice and style.
